{{current|date=November 2018}} {{original research|date=November 2018}} [[File:2018 Baraboo High boys junior prom group.jpg|alt=A group of about sixty boys on courthouse steps. Many have raised their right hand in an apparent Nazi salute. One is displaying a white power hand sign.|thumb|2018 [[Baraboo High School]] boys junior prom group photo]]
On November 11 and 12, 2018, a photograph of a group of [[Baraboo High School]] boys, many with their arms raised in what what looks like the [[Nazi salute]], went viral on social media. The photographer and one student deny there was any political intent or that insult was intended, describing it as innocuous gesture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/baraboo-high-school-nazi-salute-photo-student-refused-to-participate/|title=Wisconsin student who refused to participate in apparent Nazi salute speaks out|work=CBS NEWS|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fox47.com/news/local/interview-student-in-baraboo-photo-speaks-out|title=Interview: Student in Baraboo photo speaks out|work=Fox47|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}}</ref> Another student in the photo, who did not raise his hand, stated that he recognized instantly that his peers were making a Nazi salute.
One of the boys in the photograph, who did not raise his hand, later described experiencing years of racist comments at the school and another, who also did not raise his hand, described enduring years of bullying that went unaddressed by the school administration.
Several meetings have been held or scheduled to address the incident. The controversy broke at a time when, nationwide, hate speech and nationalism are rising, two weeks after eleven Jews were killed in the [[Pittsburgh synagogue shooting]], and two years after Baraboo school district had reported a steep increase in racial harassment complaints.
==History== On Sunday November 11, 2018, a group photograph of about sixty male [[Baraboo High School]] students, many giving what looks like a [[Nazi salute]], was shared on social media, and by the next morning it was viral on Twitter.<ref name=Madison.com>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wiscnews.com/baraboonewsrepublic/news/local/update-nazi-salutes-appear-to-be-used-in-group-photo/article_3224ea4a-7423-5fc1-b2ca-20159f7129e5.html|title=Parents address school board as Nazi salutes in Baraboo High School prom photo spark outrage online|website=[[Baraboo News Republic]]|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref> The photo, which had been taken six months earlier before the junior prom, was condemned by the [[Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum|Auschwitz Memorial]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/nov/12/wisconsin-schools-investigation-after-photo-shows-boys-giving-nazi-salute|title=Wisconsin school district investigates photo of boys giving Nazi salute|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref> State Senator [[Jon Erpenbach]], and Wisconsin Governor-elect [[Tony Evers]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2018/11/12/us/ap-us-nazi-salute-students-the-latest.html|title=The Latest: Wisconsinites Rally for Love After Nazi Photo|website=[[The New York Times]]|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wbay.com/content/news/Wisconsin-district-investigates-boys-apparent-Nazi-salute-500290341.html|title=Wisconsin district investigates boys’ apparent Nazi salute|publisher=WBAY|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref> and it attracted international media attention.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wiscnews.com/baraboonewsrepublic/news/local/education/baraboo-student-in-viral-photo-says-he-was-shocked-and/article_7e252871-bee3-5900-981d-47d7a2667ca2.html|title=Baraboo student in viral photo says he was 'shocked and confused' as classmates made Nazi salute, blames imitation|last=Endres|first=Susan|work=Baraboo News Republic|access-date=2018-11-25}}</ref> [[Baraboo School District]] Administrator Lori M. Mueller issued a statement that said in part, "The photo of students posted to #BarabooProud is not reflective of the educational values and beliefs of the School District of Baraboo. The District will pursue any and all available and appropriate actions, including legal, to address."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nbc15.com/content/news/District-responds-to-viral-photo-of-Baraboo-students-possibly-making-anti-semitic-gesture-500281042.html|title=Community distressed, divided after photo of Baraboo boys' alleged Nazi salute goes viral|publisher=NBC News 15|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref>
==Bullying== The only black student in the photo, who did not salute, says he has heard racist comments for years at the school. "People are making jokes all the time. Like, throughout middle school, people slinging the 'N-word' with the hard 'r'."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wisn.com/article/baraboo-jonathan-schieber-nazi-salute-photo-racism-bullying-25097169/25097169|title=Black Baraboo student says he's worn headphones to drown out N-word at school|date=2018-11-14|publisher=WISN|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> Another student in the photo, who did not salute, said on Twitter, "I knew what my morals were, and it was not to salute something I firmly didn't believe in. ... These classmates have bullied me since entering middle school. ... Nothing has been done, and my question is wi(ll) anything ever be done?"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/school-launches-investigation-prom-picture-students-appearing-perform-nazi-salute-goes-viral-193759971.html?guccounter=1|title=School launches investigation after prom picture of students appearing to perform Nazi salute goes viral|publisher=Yahoo! News|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
==The salute== The photographer is quoted as saying he told the students to give the "hi" sign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbc15.com/content/news/B-500883111.html|title="Baraboo Gathers:" Community gathers to heal after photo controversy|publisher=NBC News 15|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> A student in the front row, Jason Ramos, who did not salute, confirms this and supports another student who says that none of the boys knew what "high sign" meant. Ramos recognized instantly that his peers were making a Nazi salute. Both of these students are sure most of the boys in the photo are not racist and did not mean to make a Nazi salute. He said he believes one student thought it would be funny to give the salute, "One hand shot up and then everyone else went with, so it was kind of like 'monkey see, monkey do.'"<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wiscnews.com/baraboonewsrepublic/news/local/education/baraboo-student-in-viral-photo-says-he-was-shocked-and/article_7e252871-bee3-5900-981d-47d7a2667ca2.html|title=Baraboo student in viral photo says he was 'shocked and confused' as classmates made Nazi salute, blames imitation|last=Endres|first=Susan|work=Baraboo News Republic|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
==The community's response== In a rally on the steps of the [[Sauk County Courthouse]] (where the photo was taken) on November 12 (the day the image was going viral) young local businesspeople and BHS students chanted "Love, not hate".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/lifestyle/royals/people-chant-love-not-hate-at-baraboo-rally/vp-BBPDwxR|title=People chant 'love, not hate' at Baraboo rally|publisher=MSN|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> There was a large gathering of community members in the Baraboo Civic Center on November 15 to talk about healing and how to create change.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cbs58.com/news/we-need-to-pause-and-reflect-baraboo-community-looking-for-change-after-nazi-salute-photo|title=‘We need to pause and reflect’: Baraboo community looking for change after Nazi salute photo|publisher=CBS 58|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> On November 16, Milwaukee's [[Rufus King High School]], which includes Jewish and Muslim students, posted a picture of 50 students and about 15 staff giving the [[American Sign Language]] sign for "I love you" as well as hand signs for [[Peace_symbols#V_sign|peace]] and [[Hand heart|hearts]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/local/milwaukee/2018/11/19/milwaukee-high-school-reacts-baraboo-nazi-photo-message-love/2054145002/|title=In response to Nazi salute photo from Baraboo, one Milwaukee high school wants to spread a message of love|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
On November 19, the first in a three-step program of community meetings called Baraboo Gathers was held by the Baraboo School District, city leaders and community members. Between two and three hundred attended, including some students who were in the photo. School District Administrator Mueller "acknowledged bullying is a problem in most school districts, including Baraboo, and said leaders are committed to doing better", and she called for [[Restorative justice|restorative practices]]. "While the photo 'as alleged' is an issue of free speech, she said the students involved need to repair the damage they’ve done." The second meeting in the series is scheduled for November 29. At that meeting the audience will be invited to comment. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wiscnews.com/baraboonewsrepublic/news/local/baraboo-leaders-take-defensive-apologetic-tone-over-controversial-photo/article_97350467-b375-5b73-9796-d799e179e3c6.html#1|title=Baraboo leaders take defensive, apologetic tone over controversial photo|last=Endres|first=Susan|work=Baraboo News Republic|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbc15.com/content/news/B-500883111.html|title="Baraboo Gathers:" Community gathers to heal after photo controversy|publisher=NBC News 15|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
==Historical context== The photo went viral just two weeks after eleven Jews were killed and seven wounded in [[Pittsburgh synagogue shooting|an antisemitic mass shooting at Pittsburgh's Tree of Life synagogue]], at a time when nationalist and hate speech were rising in the United States,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.jsonline.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/11/12/nazi-salute-baraboo-high-school-boys-wisconsin/1975695002/|title=Male students at an (almost) all-white high school gave a Nazi salute. Now officials want to figure out why.|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref> and two years after the Baraboo school district had reported a steep increase in racial harassment complaints.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.postcrescent.com/story/news/2018/11/20/before-nazi-salute-picture-baraboo-schools-racial-complaints-rise/2016640002/|title=Before Nazi salute picture, Baraboo schools saw a rise in racial complaints|work=Post-Crescent Media|access-date=2018-11-24}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{update|date=June 2013}} [[Image:Ted Williams Tunnel Boston (0208).jpg|right|thumb|upright=1.3|Boston traffic crawls over a closed [[Ted Williams Tunnel]] entrance in Boston during [[rush hour]] on July 11, 2006, a day after the collapse.]] The '''Big Dig ceiling collapse''' occurred on July 10, 2006, when a concrete ceiling panel and debris weighing {{convert|26|shtn|kg}} and measuring {{convert|20|by|40|ft|m}} fell in Boston's [[Fort Point Channel]] Tunnel (which connects to the [[Ted Williams Tunnel]]).<ref>{{cite web | title=Why Did It Fail? | url=http://www.foundationperformance.org/pastpresentations/FowlerPresSlides-10Nov10.pdf | accessdate=2014-04-16 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140419011826/http://www.foundationperformance.org/pastpresentations/FowlerPresSlides-10Nov10.pdf | archivedate=2014-04-19 | df= }}</ref> The panel fell on a car traveling on the two-lane ramp connecting northbound I-93 to eastbound I-90 in [[South Boston]], killing a passenger and injuring the driver. Investigation and repair of the collapse caused a section of the [[Big Dig]] project to be closed for almost a full year, causing chronic traffic backups.
==Cause== The east ends of the westbound and eastbound connector tunnels were designed and constructed in the same manner. Both ends of the tunnel were built sooner than the connecting section to allow the D Street bridge above to be constructed sooner. The end sections were not designed to incorporate a hanging ceiling system like that used in the connecting section.
The collapse of the ceiling structure began with the simultaneous [[Creep (deformation)|creep-type]] failure of several [[Anchor bolt|anchors]] embedded in [[epoxy]] in the tunnel's roof slab. Each of the panel's intersecting connection points consists of several individual bolts anchored into the roof slab concrete. The failure of a group of anchors set off a [[chain reaction]] which caused other adjacent connection groups to creep then fail, dropping {{convert|26|shtn|kg}} of concrete to the roadway below.
Numerous problems with this same system of bolts and epoxy in the Ted Williams Tunnel had been previously revealed in a 1998 (Massachusetts) Office of the Inspector General report. Not only were the bolts too short, but the epoxy used to glue the bolts into the concrete was not up to standard.<ref>{{cite news | first=Sean P. | last=Murphy |author2=Scott Allen | title=Workmanship and design of tunnel are called into question |url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/12/workmanship_and_design_of_tunnel_are_called_into_question | publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2006-07-12 | accessdate=4 July 2017| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060720004605/http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/12/workmanship_and_design_of_tunnel_are_called_into_question/ | archivedate=July 20, 2006<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= y}}</ref> The state [[Massachusetts Turnpike|Turnpike Authority]] and the [[Federal Highway Administration]], citing the ongoing criminal investigation, refused requests received after the accident to release documents relating to the work conducted along the Seaport connector, including:<ref name=Wedge />
*Deficiency reports that would have shown problems flagged during initial work on the tunnel. *Construction change orders that would have shown costly repairs and contract revisions that occurred because of deficiencies. *Inspection reports and other documents that would show who would have knowledge of the workmanship and building material quality.
One year earlier, US House Representative [[Stephen Lynch (politician)|Stephen Lynch]] also had trouble obtaining records regarding the Big Dig tunnel leaks for the Congress' [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform|Committee on Government Oversight]].<ref name=Wedge>{{cite news | first=Dave | last=Wedge | author2=Casey Ross | url=http://news.bostonherald.com/localRegional/view.bg?articleid=148110 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060715211430/http://news.bostonherald.com/localRegional/view.bg?articleid=148110 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2006-07-15 | title=From Big Dig officials: Info under wraps | publisher=The Boston Herald | date=2006-07-13 | accessdate=2006-07-18 | df= }}</ref>
==Aftermath and response== [[Image:Boston traffic re-routed Ted Williams tunnel, 2006.jpg|thumb|right|Overflow traffic on I-90 (eastbound at the [[South Bay Interchange]]), after the rightmost lanes leading into the tunnel were blocked off]] After the ceiling collapse, [[Massachusetts Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Thomas Reilly|Tom Reilly]] described the tunnel as a [[crime scene]] and issued subpoenas to the companies and individuals responsible for the tunnel construction and testing. Governor [[Mitt Romney]] returned from a vacation in [[New Hampshire]] to view the condition of the tunnels.<ref>{{cite news | first=Jay | last=Lindsay | url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/07/11/reilly_big_dig_collapse_is_crime_scene/ | archive-url=https://archive.is/20101230130508/http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/07/11/reilly_big_dig_collapse_is_crime_scene/ | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2010-12-30 | title=Reilly: Big Dig collapse is crime scene | publisher=boston.com |date=2006-07-11 | accessdate=4 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bostonherald.com/localPolitics/view.bg?articleid=148121|title=Mitt’s MIA as bigs dig into tunnel tragedy|last=Atkins|first=Kimberly|date=2006-07-13|work=[[Boston Herald]]|publisher=[[bostonherald.com]]|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060715211417/http://news.bostonherald.com/localPolitics/view.bg?articleid=148121|archive-date= 2006-07-15|accessdate=4 July 2017}}</ref>
The Governor ordered connecting roads that lead into the Fort Point Channel Tunnel and several ramps to the westbound section from within the city be closed. These closures caused dramatic overflow congestion throughout the city<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/13/city_girds_as_connector_shuts_indefinitely/|title=City girds as connector shuts indefinitely|last=Daniel|first=Mac|date=2006-07-13|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=[[boston.com]]|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060715070504/http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/13/city_girds_as_connector_shuts_indefinitely/|archive-date= 2006-07-15|accessdate=4 July 2017|location=[[Boston]]}}</ref> as motorists sought alternate routes to and from [[Logan International Airport]] and several other key arterial routes. Beyond the difficulties posed within the city, the Fort Point Channel Tunnel and [[Ted Williams Tunnel]] link the [[Massachusetts Turnpike]] and [[Interstate 93]] to Logan, so this also blocked a key inbound link for airport travelers coming from outside the city, forcing them to seek alternate routes like the [[Callahan Tunnel]] or follow poorly marked detours that wound through the city, often resulting in additional travel times of one hour or more.
The legislature approved the governor's plan to assume oversight of the investigation into the collapse (as Romney had only gained office in 2003, long after any decisions about the construction had been made, he was seen as a good choice for an independent investigator), taking responsibility away from the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority, and additionally allocating $20 million for a "stem to stern" safety review of the Central Artery system. At the request of all the members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation, the [[National Transportation Safety Board]] dispatched a six-member civil engineering team to Boston to inspect the accident scene and determine whether a full-scale investigation was warranted.
== Problems identified == Safety inspections following the accident identified 242 potentially dangerous bolt fixtures supporting the ceiling tiles in the [[Interstate 90]] connector tunnel.<ref>{{cite news | first=Raja | last=Mishra |author2=Sean P. Murphy | url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/14/many_more_flaws_detected_romney_to_take_over_probe/ | title=Many more flaws detected; Romney to take over probe; Loose ceiling fixtures number in hundreds | publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2006-07-14 | accessdate=4 July 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060721104018/http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/14/many_more_flaws_detected_romney_to_take_over_probe/| archivedate= 21 July 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= y}}</ref> As problems throughout the tunnels were identified, various sections of roadway were closed and re-opened to make repairs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2006/07/20/massachusetts-governor-orders-partial-shutdown-ted-williams-tunnel.html|title=Massachusetts Governor Orders Partial Shutdown of Ted Williams Tunnel|date=2006-07-20|work=[[Fox News]]|publisher=[[foxnews.com]]|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160316153745/http://www.foxnews.com/story/2006/07/20/massachusetts-governor-orders-partial-shutdown-ted-williams-tunnel.html|archive-date= 2016-03-16|accessdate=4 July 2017|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://cbs4boston.com/topstories/local_story_201125108.html| title=Romney Shuts Down Part Of Ted Williams Tunnel| publisher=WBZ-TV CBS 4 |date=2006-07-20 | accessdate=2006-07-20}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> New concerns about ceiling fans, weighing approximately three tons each, used to circulate air throughout the tunnel system, were also identified.<ref>{{cite news | first=Raja | last=Mishra | url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/26/stability_of_ramps_massive_fans_in_question/| title=Stability of ramps' massive fans in question | publisher=Boston Globe |date=2006-07-26 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110522141309/http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/26/stability_of_ramps_massive_fans_in_question/|archive-date= 2011-05-22| accessdate=4 July 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
The [[National Transportation Safety Board]] released a report on the one-year anniversary of the disaster, that attributed the major cause of the collapse to "[[Creep (deformation)|epoxy creep]]".<ref>{{NTSB|article=Accident Report Ceiling Collapse in the Interstate 90 Connector Tunnel|url=http://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/HAR0702.aspx|accessdate=2015-03-14}}</ref> On August 8, 2007, a [[Suffolk County, Massachusetts|Suffolk County]] Grand Jury indicted epoxy company Powers Fasteners, Inc., on one charge of [[involuntary manslaughter]], with the maximum penalty in Massachusetts being a fine of one thousand dollars.<ref>{{cite news | first=Casey | last=Ross | url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2007/08/epoxy_company_hit_big_dig_indictment| title=Epoxy company hit with Big Dig indictment | publisher=Boston Herald |date=2007-08-08 | accessdate=4 July 2017}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
The epoxy used in the D Street portal that failed cost $1,287.60. The cost to redesign, inspect, and repair all of the tunnels after the collapse was $54 million.<ref>{{cite episode|series=Modern Marvels|title=Engineering Disaster 21 |year=2007 |publisher=History Channel}}</ref>
==Political fallout== On July 13, 2006, the leaders of the [[Massachusetts General Court|state legislature]], [[Massachusetts Senate|Senate]] President [[Robert Travaglini]] and [[Massachusetts House of Representatives|House]] Speaker [[Salvatore DiMasi|Sal DiMasi]], called upon [[Massachusetts Turnpike|Turnpike Authority]] chairman [[Matthew J. Amorello]], who provided oversight of the project, to consider stepping down from his position and accepting a diminished role.<ref name="lesser">{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02E7D61E30F937A25754C0A9609C8B63|title=Loose Tunnel Bolts Count In Hundreds, Officials Say|last=Belluck|first=Pam|last2=Zezima |first2=Katie|date=2006-07-14|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[nytimes.com]]|language=English|accessdate=4 July 2017}}</ref> Governor Romney and Attorney General Reilly both called for the resignation of Amorello. This stance was supported in editorials in Boston's two major newspapers, the ''[[Boston Herald]]''<ref>{{cite news |author=''Boston Herald'' editorial staff |url=http://news.bostonherald.com/editorial/view.bg?articleid=147940 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060714205436/http://news.bostonherald.com/editorial/view.bg?articleid=147940 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2006-07-14 |title=Tunnel tragedy was no accident |publisher=Boston Herald |date=2006-07-12 |accessdate=2006-07-18 |df= }}</ref> and ''[[The Boston Globe]]''.<ref>{{cite news | author=''Boston Globe'' editorial staff | url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/editorials/articles/2006/07/12/time_to_go/| title=Time to go | publisher=Boston Globe |date=2006-07-12 | accessdate=2006-07-20}}{{Subscription required |via=[[The Boston Globe]]}}</ref> On July 18, Amorello was presented with a formal list of charges that Romney intended to use to justify Amorello's removal.<ref>{{cite news | author=''Boston Globe''<!--Original page useless.-->|url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/25/in_violation_of_your_duty/|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080516010753/http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/25/in_violation_of_your_duty/|archive-date= 2008-05-16|access-date= 4 July 2017| title='In violation of your duty:' ''Excerpts from Governor Mitt Romney's July 17 letter to Matthew J. Amorello, chairman of the Turnpike Authority''| publisher=Boston Globe | page=B5 |date=2006-07-25}}</ref>
Amorello made an unsuccessful effort to ask the [[Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court]] to postpone the removal hearing before Romney.<ref>{{cite news | first=Andrea | last=Estes | url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2006/07/25/amorello_failed_at_big_dig_letter_says/| title=Amorello failed at Big Dig, letter says | publisher=Boston Globe | page=B1+ |date=2006-07-25 | accessdate=2006-07-25}}</ref> On July 27, 2006, after the Supreme Judicial Court rejected his request and shortly before the hearing was to have begun, Armorello announced his intention to resign as Chairman of the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority effective August 15, 2006.
Massachusetts Secretary of Transportation [[John Cogliano]] also came under fire after he chose to hire [[Bechtel|Bechtel/Parsons Brinckerhoff]], the company that was responsible for overseeing the original construction of the tunnel, to inspect the repairs.<ref name=Ross>{{cite news|last=Ross|first=Casey|title=Mitt passes buck on Bechtel hiring ; Blames Cogiliano for `mistake'|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/1152362271.html?dids=1152362271:1152362271&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT|accessdate=2011-08-12|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=October 27, 2006}}</ref> The hiring of Bechtel/Parsons Brinckerhoff resulted in an inquiry from the [[Office of Inspector General for the Department of Transportation]]. Cogliano admitted that he regretted reusing the firm and the state promised not to hire any Bechtel/Parsons Brinckerhoff employees to work on repairs in the I-90 tunnel.<ref>{{cite news|last=Allen|first=Scott|title=Official regrets reuse of firm; Big Dig error, Cogliano says|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/1150846731.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT|accessdate=2011-08-12|newspaper=Boston Globe|date=October 25, 2006}}</ref>
==Lawsuits== On November 27, 2006, departing Attorney General Tom Reilly announced that the state would launch a civil suit over the collapse of the ceiling in the Ted Williams Tunnel. The Commonwealth will be seeking over $150 million from project manager Bechtel/Parsons Brinckerhoff, builder [[Modern Continental|Modern Continental Construction Co.]] and the manufacturer of the epoxy used to hold the ceiling bolts.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20061127/us_nm/massachusetts_bigdig_dc Mass. to sue Big Dig firms over tunnel accident, ''Reuters'', 2006-11-27]</ref>
Attorney General [[Martha Coakley]] on March 1, 2007 named Paul Ware from [[Goodwin Procter]], a Boston law firm to lead the criminal investigation into whether there is criminal culpability in the Big Dig tunnel collapse. Paul Ware will be appointed as a special assistant attorney general.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Coakley tabs private attorney to lead Big Dig criminal probe |url=http://www1.whdh.com/news/articles/local/BO44760/ |quote=The man chosen to lead the criminal investigation into last summer's deadly Big Dig tunnel ceiling collapse was a prosecutor in the Iran-Contra affair and more recently in the disciplinary hearing against former Superior Court Judge Maria Lopez. |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=March 1, 2007 |accessdate=2007-08-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230093853/http://www3.whdh.com/news/articles/local/BO44760/ |archivedate=December 30, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
On December 24, 2007, the family of Milena Del Valle (who was killed in the collapse) and Angel Del Valle (who was injured) announced that they had reached a settlement with Powers Fasteners, in which they would be paid $6 million.<ref>{{cite news | first=Maria| last=Cramer| url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2006/08/family_of_big_d_1.html | title=Family of Big Dig victim speak about Lawsuit | publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2006-08-30 | accessdate=2006-08-30| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060901153700/http://www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2006/08/family_of_big_d_1.html| archivedate=September 1, 2006<!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The Del Valle family stated, "We are grateful that the Powers family company has done the right thing." Powers denied responsibility, but said that the settlement would "allow the healing process to begin." Powers also stated "We also hope that this will lead others who, unlike Powers, truly were responsible for the accident, to do the same." The Del Valle family still has 14 lawsuits pending against other defendants.<ref name="globe settlement">{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2007/12/24/settlement_reached_in_big_dig_death/?p1=Well_MostPop_Emailed1|title= Settlement reached in Big Dig death|publisher=[[Boston Globe]]|date=2007-12-24|accessdate=2007-12-25 | first=Megan | last=Woolhouse}}</ref>{{update inline|date=January 2014}} In September 2008, the Del Valle family announced that they had reached a $28 million settlement, resolving the lawsuits against all 15 companies involved in construction of the tunnel, including the Massachusetts Turnpike Authority.<ref>{{cite news |last=Slack |first=Donovan |date=2008-10-01 |title=Family to Get $28m in Big Dig death |url=http://www.boston.com/news/traffic/bigdig/articles/2008/10/01/family_to_get_28m_in_big_dig_death/ |newspaper=Boston Globe |access-date=2016-02-03}}</ref>
==Other problems== {{see also|Big Dig#Problems}} There have been other difficulties with the design and construction of the [[Big Dig#Problems|Big Dig project]], including numerous [[leak]]s, dangerous [[guardrail]]s, and the threat of heavy [[lighting fixture]]s also falling from the ceilings.
The [[Georgia DOT]] found that failure of the same epoxy at fault for the ceiling collapse was also to blame for the 2011 fall of a fenced and lighted covered-walkway structure attached to the south side of the relatively new 17th Street Bridge, which links [[Atlantic Station]] to [[Midtown Atlanta]] over [[Interstate 75/85]]. No injuries occurred in that incident, as the collapse was in the overnight hours, with very little traffic on the freeway.<ref name="11alive">{{cite web|url=http://midtown.11alive.com/news/news/98991-midtown-were-all-accountable-says-gdot-about-17th-street-canopy-collapse|title=MIDTOWN | "We're all accountable" says GDOT about 17th Street canopy collapse | News | Midtown News|publisher=midtown.11alive.com|accessdate=2014-07-11}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Ted Williams Tunnel]] * [[Sasago Tunnel]] — Japanese tunnel where a similar ceiling collapse occurred in 2012
== References == {{reflist|2}}

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Cliffhanger.png|200px|right|The standard Cliff Hanger title, this example from the 16 February 1985 issue.]] --> '''''Cliff Hanger''''' is the name of two different 1983 [[comic strip]]s, one published in the [[United Kingdom]] and the other in the [[United States]].
==British version==
The British ''Cliff Hanger'' was written and drawn by [[Jack Edward Oliver]]. It first appeared in the 25 June 1983 issue of the British comics magazine [[Buster (comics)|Buster]].
Watching a television show called 'Now Get Out of This' (a [[parody]] of [[Now Get Out of That]]), Cliff remarks that he thinks he could get out of everything. This is overheard by the '''Evil Spies''', agents of M.E.S.S. (the Mysterious Evil Spies Society). They tell Cliff that he's now a [[guinea pig]] in their traps, and if he doesn't survive, they'll know the traps will be good enough to use against secret agents.
From then on, the premise of the strip every week would be that Cliff is suddenly transported into a dangerous situation by the spies, using the Atomic Matter Transmitter. Three options would be presented to the readers, who would select one by ticking one of the boxes, and turning to another page to see whether their choice was correct or not. For example, in the first strip, Cliff is stranded on a moving artificial desert island. Just as it's about to hit the shore, the [[Ocean current|current]] changes and Cliff is driven back into the [[shark]] infested sea. The choices were 'Take off his shoe and use it to paddle the island to the shore', 'Pull out the tree and use it as a raft' and 'Climb the tree'. A and B were incorrect- using the shoe as a paddle simply sent Cliff round in circles, and pulling out the tree revealed it was plugging a hole, causing the island to sink. The correct answer was C, as Cliff's weight caused the tree to bend over onto the shore, lifting Cliff to safety.
The strip featured several minor background details that would occur in every issue, including a box with a handle, a plaster, the word '[[Acme Corporation|Acme]]', an arrow with another (backwards facing) arrow inside it, a [[warthog]], the initials 'JEO', a [[worm]], and a sign saying "Abolish Tuesdays". A running gag would feature one of the Evil Spies' constant wondering why his counterpart would frequently call him "Ray" even though that wasn't his name, when in fact he was simply referring to one of the gadgets ("Fire the Transporter Ray!"). Another thing of note is that Cliff's jumper often featured the strip number on it, starting with a "1" in the first, and going on well into the hundreds at the end. Over the years, several continuous storylines emerged featuring parodies of popular film and television series of the day, including [[James Bond]], the [[Star Wars]] Trilogy, [[Back to the Future]] and [[List of Transformers TV series|Transformers]]. The strip ended in 1987, replaced by [[Vid Kid]].
However, as Buster moved into the 1990s, the amount of reprints started to dramatically increase, and several old strips began to reappear. Cliff Hanger was one of these, though as J. Edward Oliver was still working for the comic, he was able to turn the originally black and white pages into full colour. With most of the readers unaware that these were reprints, this gave the impression that they were brand new. In February 1998, when the strips started being reprinted for a third time, rather than continue to advertise them as new, the '''Cliff Hanger Classic''' strand was started. Here there would be an afterword at the bottom of the strips, written by Jack, featuring factual information like the original issue dates, background details explained, the most popular television programmes of that week, or the top 5 of that week's [[UK Singles Chart]].
By 1999, virtually the entire comic featured reprints. Because of this, J. Edward Oliver decided to draw one final strip, which appeared in issue 118/99, dated 7–21 July 1999 (the comic had become a fortnightly publication in 1995). Finding the Evil Spies in danger, all three options led to the conclusion that the Evil Spies would never trap Cliff again (if Cliff called the police, the spies would be arrested, if Cliff helped them out, they would stop trapping Cliff as a gesture of thanks, etc.). This issue also featured the final appearance of 'b-mail', the name used at the time for the Letters Page (which Jack also wrote). Cliff's final appearance was in a cameo appearance in the last page of Buster's final issue, which occurred half a year later. Explaining how all the characters ended, and once again drawn by J. Edward Oliver, Cliff was seen mourning the passing of Bernie Banks (the lead character in [[Memory Banks (comic strip)|Memory Banks]], another Buster strip) who had apparently forgotten how to breathe. Symbolising that this was indeed the final issue, his jumper carried the word 'END'.
==American version== The American ''Cliff Hanger'' was written by [[Bruce Jones (comics)|Bruce Jones]] with artwork by [[Al Williamson]]. The title character was a swashbuckling adventurer who crashlands in an unnamed jungle region in the late 1930s and finds himself in a mysterious plot involving a secret research facility.
The strip originally appeared as a back-up feature in the four issue run of [[Somerset Holmes]], a 1983 thriller [[comic book]] also by Jones and Williamson. It has been reprinted in collections of Williamson's artwork.
{{Buster}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use British English|date=September 2015}} A '''Commemoration ball''' is a formal [[Ball (dance)|ball]] held by one of the colleges of the [[University of Oxford]] in the 9th week of [[Trinity Term]], the week after the end of the last Full Term of the academic year, which is known as "Commemoration Week". Commemoration balls are held by different colleges each year, following a cycle by which each college holds a ball every three years.<ref>Balsdon, J.P.V.D.: ''Oxford Life'', page 240. Eyre & Spottiswoode, 1957</ref>
Commemoration Week is so known because of the ceremonies in commemoration of the benefactors of the university that are held then, namely the Commemoration Day sermon formerly held (until 2006) on the Sunday, and the [[Encaenia]] ceremony (where the annual Creweian Oration in honour of benefactors is given) and garden party on the Wednesday of that week. Commemoration Week was formerly one of two occasions when balls were traditionally held, the other being Eights Week, the 5th week of Trinity term when the [[Summer Eights]] rowing races occur. Eights balls are nowadays comparatively rare.
==Definition==
There is no formal definition of a Commemoration ball, but the usual Oxford convention is to refer only to the larger, triennial balls as Commemoration balls. The dress code is usually [[white tie]]. Many other colleges hold smaller events during Commemoration Week that they call summer balls or parties rather than Commemoration balls. These are usually held on an annual or irregular basis, and are usually [[black tie]]. [[Merton College]] holds a triennial winter ball, of which the next will be in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Merton College Winter Ball|url=http://mertonball.com}}</ref>
==Recent and upcoming balls==
In the past, Commemoration balls were held "night after night"<ref>Balsdon, J.P.V.D (supra)</ref> by different colleges during Commemoration Week. With many colleges now holding smaller annual summer balls, Commemoration balls are now held by only some of the larger colleges, who still follow the traditional triennial cycle. [[Oriel College, Oxford|Oriel College]] hosts a ball in the first year of the three-year cycle, and until recently [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]] also did. However [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]] cancelled their ball in 2015 at the last minute downgrading to a smaller affair. Currently, in the second year, there are Commemoration balls held by [[New College, Oxford|New College]] and [[The Queen's College, Oxford|The Queen's College]]. In the third year, there are now four colleges with this honour ([[Worcester College, Oxford|Worcester College]], [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]], [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]], [[St. John's College, Oxford|St. John's College]]).
The 2005 Christ Church Commemoration ball was the first to be held by that college for fifteen years because of an incident at the 1990 ball that led to the Governing Body suspending the ball and replacing it with an annual summer party until 2005. Until 1990 the three great Oxford choral foundations of [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]] (first year), [[New College, Oxford|New College]] (second year) and [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]] (third year) held their "white tie" Commemoration Balls in consecutive years on a triennial basis, each being widely regarded as the most prestigious ball being held in Oxford in that year, but the 1990 incident at [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]] upset the tradition as various other colleges claimed [[Christ Church, Oxford|Christ Church]]'s (third year) slot, and continue to do so after the Christ Church Ball was reinstated in 2005. The cancellation of [[Magdalen College, Oxford|Magdalen College]]'s (first year) Commemoration Ball in 2015, and its reinstatement in the "[[New College, Oxford|New College]]" (second) year of 2016, completed the break with tradition.
In 2013, Balliol College held a Commemoration ball to mark the 750th Anniversary of the College's foundation, the first Commemoration Ball at Balliol since 1969.<ref>{{cite web|title=Balliol 750th Anniversary Commemoration Ball|url=http://balliol750.co.uk|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121213010121/http://www.balliol750.co.uk/|archivedate=13 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Similarly, the commemoration ball hosted by Worcester College on 27 June 2014 was the highlight of celebrations to mark the college's tercentenary.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thetercentenaryball.co.uk/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904030635/http://thetercentenaryball.co.uk/ |archivedate=4 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{update|date = May 2016}} '''Comparisons between the Great Recession and the Great Depression''' explores the experiences in the [[United States]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. On April 17, 2009, head of the IMF [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]] said that there was a chance that certain countries may not implement the proper policies to avoid feedback mechanisms that could eventually turn the recession into a depression. "The free-fall in the global economy may be starting to abate, with a recovery emerging in 2010, but this depends crucially on the right policies being adopted today." The [[IMF]] pointed out that unlike the Great Depression, this recession was synchronized by global integration of markets. Such synchronized recessions were explained to last longer than typical economic downturns and have slower recoveries.{{Cite news|last=Evans |first=Ambrose |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/recession/5166956/IMF-warns-over-parallels-to-Great-Depression.html |title=IMF warns over parallels to Great Depression |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2009-04-16 |accessdate=2010-01-21 | location=London}} The chief economist of the IMF, Dr. [[Olivier Blanchard]], stated that the percentage of workers laid off for long stints has been rising with each downturn for decades but the figures have surged this time. "Long-term unemployment is alarmingly high: in the US, half the unemployed have been out of work for over six months, something we have not seen since the Great Depression." The IMF also stated that a link between rising inequality within Western economies and deflating demand may exist. The last time that the [[economic inequality|wealth gap]] reached such skewed extremes was in 1928-1929.The Telegraph (UK), 2010 Sept. 14, "IMF Fears 'Social Explosion' From World Jobs Crisis: America and Europe face the worst jobs crisis since the 1930s and risk 'an explosion of social unrest' unless they tread carefully, the International Monetary Fund has warned," https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/financialcrisis/8000561/IMF-fears-social-explosion-from-world-jobs-crisis.html ==In the United States== [[Image:1937 to 1943 vs 2008 to 2011.png|thumb|300px|right|alt=1937 to 1943 depression compared to 2008 to 2013 recession, using percentage gained/lost since 1937 and 2008, respectively|[[Dow Jones Industrial Average]] figures for percentage lost in 1937-1943 vs 2008-2011 (based on initial 1937 and 2008 DJIA month end amount, respectively)]] Although some casual comparisons between the [[Great Recession]] and the [[Great Depression]] have been made, there remain large differences between the two events.{{Cite news |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/business/fp/Great+Depression/1388627/story.html |title=Not the Great Depression |last=Bagnall |first=James |date=2009-03-16 |publisher=The Ottawa Citizen |accessdate=2009-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322021337/http://www.ottawacitizen.com/business/fp/Great%2BDepression/1388627/story.html |archivedate=March 22, 2009 |df= }}{{Cite journal|last=Collyns|first=Charles |date=December 2008|title=The Crisis through the Lens of History|url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2008/12/collyns.htm|journal=Finance and Development|volume=45|issue=4}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/world/europe/displaystory.cfm?story_id=13234963|title=Extremist nightmares|author=Charlemagne |date=March 5, 2009|publisher=The Economist|accessdate=2009-03-12}} Actually, if the magnitude of initial shocks was the same in both cases, the recovery from the latest one would be earlier.{{cite book|author=Baten, Jörg |title=A History of the Global Economy. From 1500 to the Present.|date=2016|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=110|isbn=9781107507180}} The consensus among economists in March 2009 was that a depression was not likely to occur.{{Cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/03/25/news/economy/depression_comparisons/index.htm|title=The Great Recession|last=Isidore|first=Chris|date=2009-03-25|publisher=CNN Money|accessdate=2009-04-10}} [[UCLA Anderson]] Forecast director Edward Leamer said on March 25, 2009 that there had not been any major predictions at that time which resembled a second Great Depression:
"We've frightened consumers to the point where they imagine there is a good prospect of a Great Depression. That certainly is not in the prospect. No reputable forecaster is producing anything like a Great Depression."{{Cite news|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/03/25/pm_forecasting_q/|title=The difficulty with economic forecasting|date=2009-03-25|work=Marketplace|publisher=American Public Media|accessdate=2009-03-26}}
Differences explicitly pointed out between the recession and the Great Depression include the facts that over the 79 years between 1929 and 2008, great changes occurred in economic philosophy and policy,{{Cite book| author = John Tatom| title = The Superlative Recession and economic policies| date = 2 February 2009 | url = http://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/13115/1/MPRA_paper_13115.pdf| publisher = MPRA Paper No. 13115}} the stock market had not fallen as far as it did in 1932 or 1982, the 10-year price-to-earnings ratio of stocks was not as low as in the 1930s or 1980s, inflation-adjusted U.S. housing prices in March 2009 were higher than any time since 1890 (including the housing [[Economic boom|booms]] of the 1970s and 1980s),{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/15/weekinreview/15vikas.html?hp|title=Has the Economy Hit Bottom Yet? |last=Bajaj|first=Vikas |date=March 14, 2009 |publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2009-03-15}} the recession of the early 1930s lasted over three-and-a-half years, and during the 1930s the supply of money (currency plus demand deposits) fell by 25% (where as in 2008 and 2009 the Fed "has taken an ultraloose credit stance").{{Cite news|url=http://www.cato.org/pub_display.php?pub_id=10016|date=March 16, 2009|publisher=[[Forbes]]|author=Steve H. Hanke|title=Unconventional Wisdom}} Furthermore, the unemployment rate in 2008 and early 2009 and the rate at which it rose was comparable to most of the recessions occurring after [[World War II]], and was dwarfed by the 25% unemployment rate peak of the Great Depression. However, syndicated columnist and former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury [[Paul Craig Roberts]] claimed in a 2012 column that if all discouraged workers were included in U.S. unemployment statistics, the actual unemployment rate would be 22%, comparable to rates during the Great Depression.{{cn|date=November 2018}} Nobel Prize–winning economist [[Paul Krugman]] predicted a series of depressions in his ''[[The Return of Depression Economics]]'' (1999), based on "failures on the demand side of the economy." On January 5, 2009, he wrote that "preventing depressions isn't that easy after all" and that "the economy is still in free fall."{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/05/opinion/05krugman.html | work=The New York Times | title=Fighting Off Depression | first=Paul | last=Krugman | date=2009-01-05 | accessdate=2010-05-07}} In March 2009, Krugman explained that a major difference in this situation is that the causes of this financial crisis were from the [[shadow banking system]]. "The crisis hasn't involved problems with deregulated institutions that took new risks... Instead, it involved risks taken by institutions that were never regulated in the first place."{{cite web |url=https://ottawacitizen.com/business/fp/Great+Depression/1388627/story.html |title=Not the Great Depression |publisher=Ottawacitizen.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322021337/http://www.ottawacitizen.com/business/fp/Great%2BDepression/1388627/story.html |archivedate=March 22, 2009 |df= }} On February 22, 2009, NYU economics professor [[Nouriel Roubini]] said that the crisis was the worst since the Great Depression, and that without cooperation between political parties and foreign countries, and if poor fiscal policy decisions (such as support of [[zombie bank]]s) are pursued, the situation "could become as bad as the Great Depression."{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Video/playerIndex?id=6932460 |title=Roundtable: Nationalizing the Banks - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date= |accessdate=2010-01-21}} On April 27, 2009, Roubini expressed a more upbeat assessment by noting that "the bottom of the economy [will be seen] toward the beginning or middle of next year."[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/04/26/AR2009042601517.html 'I Am Not Dr. Doom'], Washington Post. On April 6, 2009 [[Vernon L. Smith]] and Steven Gjerstad offered the hypothesis "that a financial crisis that originates in consumer debt, especially consumer debt concentrated at the low end of the wealth and income distribution, can be transmitted quickly and forcefully into the financial system. It appears that we're witnessing the second great consumer debt crash, the end of a massive consumption binge."{{Cite news|last=Gjerstad |first=Steven |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123897612802791281 |title=Steven Gjerstad and Vernon Smith Explain Why the Housing Crash Ruined the Financial System but the Dot-com Collapse Did Not - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2009-04-06 |accessdate=2010-01-21}} In his final press conference as president, [[George W. Bush]] claimed that in September 2008 his chief economic advisors had said that the economic situation could at some point become worse than the Great Depression.{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/01/12/raw-data-transcript-bushs-white-house-press-conference/ |title=George W. Bush Press Conference Transcript, January 12, 2009 |publisher=Foxnews.com |date= 2009-01-12|accessdate=2010-01-21}} A [[tent city]] in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[California]] was described as "images, hauntingly reminiscent of the iconic photos of the 1930s and the Great Depression" and "evocative Depression-era images."{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/3032619/#29603738 |title=NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams: News and videos from the evening broadcast NBC Nightly News with Brian Williams: News and videos from the evening broadcast- msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2010-01-21}} The [[Austrian School of economics]] view is that the size of a bust is based, at least in part, on the size of the preceding credit boom. A check of debt levels prior and during the Great Depression shows debt levels prior to the Great Depression at about 200% of GDP, with a rise to about 300% due to massive government intervention to combat the Depression.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2011/10/slouching_toward_the_1930s.html |title=Immediately prior to the Great Depression US debt was about 200% of GDP. It rose briefly to 300% as a result of massive government interventions to combat the Depression. |publisher=Americanthinker.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-15}} The debt outstanding metric indicates that the Great Recession was not over by mid-2012 and would be worse than the Great Depression; only the first part of that projection turned out to be true by mid-2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2011/10/slouching_toward_the_1930s.html |title=We are headed for an event that history will record as worse than the Great Depression. It is unavoidable. The principal reason for the dire prediction is the level of debt outstanding. |publisher=Americanthinker.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-15}} Current US debt levels are around 400% of GDP and well over the levels seen either before or during the Great Depression.{{cite web|url=http://www.americanthinker.com/2011/10/slouching_toward_the_1930s.html |title=At the beginning of the current downturn, debt was about 370% of GDP. It is about 400% currently |publisher=Americanthinker.com |date= |accessdate=2012-05-15}} According to economist [[Irving Fisher]], the two dominant factors in a depression are over-indebtness to start with and deflation soon after.{{Cite journal|url=https://fraser.stlouisfed.org/title/3596 |title=namely over-indebtness to start with and deflation following soon after. |format=PDF |date= October 1933|accessdate=2014-10-16}} Fed policy to prevent deflation at all costs has been greatly influenced by Fisher's work.{{Cite journal|author=Sponsored by |url=http://www.economist.com/node/13104022?story_id=13104022 |title=Indeed, some say the Fed has learnt Fisher too well |journal=The Economist |date=2009-02-12 |accessdate=2012-05-15}} ==In the United Kingdom== On 10 February 2009, [[Ed Balls]], [[Secretary of State for Children, Schools and Families]] of the [[United Kingdom]], said that "I think that this is a financial crisis more extreme and more serious than that of the 1930s and we all remember how the politics of that era were shaped by the economy."{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/7880189.stm |title=UK | UK Politics | Recession 'worst for 100 years' |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-02-10 |accessdate=2010-01-21}} On 24 January 2009, Edmund Conway, Economics Editor for ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', had written that "The plight facing Britain is uncannily similar to the 1930s, since prices of many assets – from shares to house prices – are falling at record rates [in Britain], but the value of the debt against which they are held remains unchanged."{{Cite news|last=Conway |first=Edmund |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/financetopics/recession/4326894/Britain-on-the-brink-of-an-economic-depression-say-experts.html |title=Britain on the brink of an economic depression, say experts |publisher=Telegraph |date=2009-01-23 |accessdate=2010-01-21 | location=London}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * Barry Eichengreen; Kevin H O’Rourke (2010). [http://www.voxeu.org/article/tale-two-depressions-what-do-new-data-tell-us-february-2010-update#jun09 What do the new data tell us?]. A comparison between today’s global financial crisis to the Great Depression. [[Category:Economics comparisons|Great Recession and the Great Depression]] [[Category:Great Depression]] [[Category:Great Recession]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''Daily Mail'' Circuit of Britain air race}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Use British English|date=October 2017}} The '''''Daily Mail'' Circuit of Britain air race''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] cross-country [[air race]] which took place from 1911 until 1914, with prizes donated by the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' newspaper on the initiative of its proprietor, [[Alfred Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Northcliffe|Lord Northcliffe]]. It was one of [[Daily Mail aviation prizes|several races and awards]] offered by the paper between 1906 and 1925.
The 1911 race took place on 22 July and was a {{convert|1010|mi|km}} event with 11 compulsory stops and a circular route starting and finishing at [[Brooklands]] in Surrey. The winner was [[Jean Louis Conneau|Jean Conneau]] in a [[Blériot XI]] who took 22 hours, 28 minutes to complete the course, an average speed of {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and received the first prize of £10,000. The runner up was [[Jules Védrines]] in a [[Morane-Borel monoplane]] with [[James Valentine (aviator)|James Valentine]], in a [[Deperdussin 1910 monoplane|Deperdussin]], third.
The 1913 race was for British seaplanes and had a first prize of £5,000. Only one aircraft started the course; it was damaged when landing near [[Dublin]], and did not complete the course.
The 1914 race, also offering a prize of £5,000, was to have been held between 1 and 15 August.<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1914/1914%20-%200518.html The ''Daily Mail'' £5,000 Prize][[Flight International|''Flight'']], 15 May 1914</ref> It was cancelled due to the outbreak of the [[First World War]].
==1911 competition== [[File:1911-circuit of Britain-competitors.png|thumb|The competing aircraft]] The 1911 Daily Mail Circuit of Britain was a contest for the fastest completion of a course around Great Britain.<ref name="Times39637" /> The proprietors of the Daily Mail offered a £10,000 prize to any aviator to complete an approximately 1,000 miles circuit of Britain in the shortest time.<ref name="Times39637" /> The contest was run by the [[Royal Aero Club]] and was held between 22 July 1911 and 5 August 1911. Following the success of the £10,000 competition for the [[1910 London to Manchester air race]], the editor announced that a further £10,000 prize would be awarded, it would either be between London and Edinburgh and return or London and Paris and return.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> It was decided that the competition would be a tour round Great Britain and a committee of the Royal Aero Club was formed to set the rules and organize the competition on behalf of the Daily Mail.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> For an entrance fee of £100 the event was open to all licensed aviators, and as well as the Daily Mail prize a number of smaller prizes were also offered.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> The circuit was to start and finish at [[Brooklands]], and the competitors had to land at [[Hendon]], [[Harrogate]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne|Newcastle]], [[Edinburgh]], [[Stirling]], [[Glasgow]], [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]], [[Manchester]], [[Bristol]], [[Exeter]], [[Salisbury]] and [[Brighton]].<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> Four competitors completed the course, the first and winner of the prize was the Frenchman Lieut [[Jean Louis Conneau]], flying under the name of André Beaumont.<ref name="Flight1911-2" />
===Competitors=== {|class="wikitable" |- |Competition Number<ref name="Times39637" /> !Airman<ref name="Times39637" /> !Aeroplane<ref name="Times39637" /> !Notes<ref name="Flight1911-2" /> |- |1 |[[Jean Louis Conneau|André Beaumont]]<!-- France --> |[[Blériot XI]] |Completed course - First to return to Brooklands and winner of the £10,000 prize. Although flying as "André Beaumont" he was a Lieutenant Jean Louis Conneau of the French Navy. |- |2 |H.J.D. Astley |[[Universal Aviation Company Birdling monoplane]] |Landed at [[Irthlingborough]] due to sickness. |- |3 |[[Marcel Brindejonc des Moulinais|Brindejonc des Moulinais]] |[[Morane-Borel monoplane]] |Non-starter - in hospital in France due to an accident |- |4 |R.C. Fenwick |[[Handley Page Type D]] |Aircraft crashed before the start |- |5 |[[John Cyril Porte|Lt. J.C. Porte]], RN |[[1910 Deperdussin monoplane|Deperdussin monoplane]] |Started but crashed after 400 yards |- |6 |Ronald C. Kemp |[[Avro Type D]] |Aircraft crashed before the start |- |7 |C. Compton Paterson<!-- Great Britain --> |[[Grahame-White Baby]] |Retired at Hendon |- |8 |[[Oscar Colin Morison|O.C. Morison]] |Bristol aeroplane |Did not start |- |9 |[[Jules Védrines]] |[[Morane-Borel monoplane]] |Completed course, first to Hendon and was the second to arrive back at Brooklands. |- |10 |[[James Radley]] |[[Antoinette VIII monoplane]] |Did not start |- |11 |G. Blanchet |[[Breguet Type III]] |First stage only completed, damaged aircraft in a forced landing at Streatley. It was repaired but he hit a tree after take off and wrecked the aircraft. |- |12 |Lt. R.A. Cammell, RE |Blériot XI |First stage only completed, retired after a forced landing east of Wakefield. |- |13 |E. Audemars |Blériot XI |First stage only completed, retired after two attempts to travel north from Hendon were stopped by fog. |- |14 |[[James Valentine (aviator)|James Valentine]] |Deperdussin monoplane |Completed course, third to arrive back at Brooklands. |- |15 |[[Grahame Gilmour]] |[[Bristol Type T biplane]] |Withdrew before start after his aviator's licence was suspended |- |16 |[[Eric Gordon England|E.C. Gordon-England]] |Bristol Type T biplane |Engine problems |- |17 |Collyns Price Pizey |Bristol Type T biplane |Delayed at [[Melton Mowbray]] when starting engine after he stopped to change his propeller. Repaired his machine but it was damaged the next day in another attempt to leave Melton Mowbray |- |18 |Pierre Prier |[[Bristol Prier monoplane]] |Crashed before the start |- |19 |[[Howard Pixton|C. Howard Pixton]] |Bristol Type T biplane |Crashed at Spofforth and retired |- |20 |[[Samuel Franklin Cody|S.F. Cody]] |[[Cody Circuit of Britain biplane]] |Completed course as the fourth and last to finish |- |21 |Maurice Tabuteau |Bristol Type T biplane |Did not start |- |22 |F. Conway Jenkins |[[Blackburn Mercury]] |Crashed on take-off |- |23 |Olivier de Montalent |[[Breguet Type III]] |Retired following a forced landing near [[Wetherby]] where he broke his propeller. |- |24 |[[Gustav Hamel]] |Blériot XI |Reached Thornhill, north of Dumfries, before he retired. |- |25 |Lt. H.R.P. Reynolds, RE |[[Howard Wright 1910 Biplane]] |Retired after aircraft was damaged at Harrogate. |- |26 |[[Robert Loraine]] |[[Nieuport monoplane]] |Did not start |- |27 |[[Bentfield Hucks]] |[[Blackburn Mercury]] |Landed at Barton near Luton with engine problems. |- |28 |[[Charles Terres Weymann|C.T. Weymann]] |[[Nieuport monoplane]] |Retired following a forced landing north-east of Leeds |- |29 |H. Wijnmalen |[[Farman HF10 3-Seater Pusher Biplane]] |Failed to start due to engine problems |- |30 |Lt. H. Bier |[[Etrich Taube]] |Aircraft damaged in a landing at Codicote near Hatfield after radiator problems. Only aircraft with a passenger Lt. C. Banfield. |}
===Stage 1 Brooklands to Hendon=== The race began at [[Brooklands]] on 22 July 1911 with a short 20 mile section to [[Hendon Aerodrome]], only 21 of the 30 competitors started and 19 headed for Hendon of which 17 arrived.<ref name="Flight1911-1" />
===Stage 2 Hendon to Edinburgh=== The competitors started to depart on the second stage on 24 July 1911 for the 343 miles from Hendon to Edinburgh with two compulsory stops:<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> *Hendon to Harrogate 182 miles, five made it to Harrogate *Harrogate to Newcastle 68 miles, *Newcastle to Edinburgh 92 miles, the same five later reached Edinburgh.<ref name="Flight1911-2" />
===Stage 3 Edinburgh to Bristol===
Total distance 383 miles with stops at Stirling, Glasgow, Carlisle, and Manchester.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> *Edinburgh to Stirling 31 miles *Stirling to Glasgow 22 miles *Glasgow to Carlisle 86 miles *Carlisle to Manchester 103 miles *Manchester to Bristol 141 miles Five started from Edinburgh but only four made it to Bristol, they were all to complete the contest.<ref name="Flight1911-2" />
===Stage 4 Bristol to Brighton=== Total distance 224 miles with stops at Exeter, Salisbury Plain.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /> *Bristol to Exeter 65 miles *Exeter to Salisbury Plain 83 miles *Salisbury Plain to Brighton 76 miles
===Stage 5 Brighton to Brooklands=== All competitors had to complete the last 40 miles to Brooklands before 19:30 on 5 August 1911. Beaumont was the first to arrive back on 26 July 1911 - 1 hour 10 minutes before his fellow Frenchman Jules Vedrines - he had travelled 1,010 miles in 22 hours 28 min 18 sec. Valentine, arrived back on 4 August 1911 followed the next day by Cody who was the fourth and the last to arrive at Brooklands on 5 August 1911.<ref name="Flight1911-1" /><ref name="Flight1911-2" />
===Prizes=== *Conneau won the £10,000 prize for the first to complete the circuit. He also won the [[Entente Cordiale]] prize of 50 [[Guinea (British coin)|guineas]] (£52.50) from the proprietors of Perrier table water for the first Frenchman to complete the course.<ref name="Times39668" /> *Vedrine, Valentine and Cody all equal shares of prizes from Sir George White, the chairman of the [[British and Colonial Aeroplane Company]] (£250 total) and the [[BP|British Petroleum Company Limited]] (125 guineas total or £43.75 each) for finishing the course.<ref name="Times39668" /> *Cody won a £50 prize from the Northumberland and Durham Aero Club for the first British machine to arrive in Newcastle.<ref name="Times39668" /> *Valentine received a £50 tea service from the [[Harrogate]] Chamber of Trade for the first British aviator to reach Harrogate and a 100 guinea gold cup from the Brighton Hotels Association for the first British aviator to reach Brighton. He also won the Entente Cordiale prize of 50 guineas (£52.50) from the proprietors of Perrier table water for the first Englishman to complete the course.<ref name="Times39668" />
==1913 competition== The 1913 race, offering prize of £5,000, was for floatplanes, which had to be of all-British construction. The course, totalling {{convert|1540|mi|km|abbr=on}} had to be completed within 72 hours, although since no flying was allowed on Sundays this period was in practice a day longer.
The race was divided into the following stages:<ref>[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200864.html ''Daily Mail'' Waterplane Circuit of Britain][[Flight International|''Flight'']] 16 August 1913</ref> *[[Southampton]] to [[Ramsgate]] — {{convert|144|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Ramsgate to [[Great Yarmouth|Yarmouth]] — {{convert|96|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Yarmouth to [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] — {{convert|150|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Scarborough to [[Aberdeen]] — {{convert|218|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Aberdeen to [[Cromarty]] — {{convert|134|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Cromarty to [[Oban]] — {{convert|94|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Oban to [[Dublin]] — {{convert|222|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Dublin to [[Falmouth, Cornwall|Falmouth]] — {{convert|280|mi|km|abbr=on}} *Falmouth to Southampton — {{convert|202|mi|km|abbr=on}}
Entrants included the [[Cody Floatplane|Cody Waterplane]], the [[Radley-England waterplanes|Radley-England Waterplane]] and the [[Sopwith 1913 Circuit of Britain floatplane|Sopwith Circuit of Britain floatplane]]. Cody was killed during a test flight of his design on 7 August when his aircraft broke up in flight, and the Sopwith, flown by [[Harry Hawker]] with [[Harry Kauper]] as passenger, was the only aircraft to start; it retired after being damaged in an emergency landing near [[Dublin]] having completed about two-thirds of the course. Hawker was given a prize of £1,000 for his effort.
==References== ;Notes {{reflist|refs= <ref name="Times39637"> {{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename= "The "Daily Mail" £10,000 Air Race, Order of Starting |section=News |author= |day_of_week=Friday |date=14 July 1911 |page_number=8 |issue=39637 |column=F }}</ref> <ref name="Times39668"> {{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename= The "Daily Mail" Air Race Official List Of The Awards |section=Official Appointments and Notices |author= |day_of_week=Saturday |date=19 August 1911 |page_number=3 |issue=39668 |column=G }}</ref> <ref name="Flight1911-1">{{cite magazine | title=The Daily Mail Circuit of Great Britain |magazine= [[Flight International|Flight]] |pages=626–636| date= 22 July 1911 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200625.html}}</ref> <ref name="Flight1911-2">{{cite magazine | title=The Daily Mail Circuit of Great Britain |magazine= [[Flight International|Flight]] |pages=652–661| date= 29 July 1911 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1911/1911%20-%200650.html}}</ref> }} ;Bibliography *{{cite web | url = http://www.airrace.com/ConciseHist.htm | title = A Concise History of Air Racing | work = Society of Air Racing Historians | accessdate = 2008-08-30 }} *{{cite magazine | url = http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200387.html |magazine=Flight | title = The new Daily Mail prizes | date = 5 April 1913 | accessdate=2008-08-30 | publisher = [[Flight Global]]}}
==External links== * [https://www.britishpathe.com/video/the-great-international-air-contest-for-the-daily/query/daily+mail ''Daily Mail'' Circuit of Britain Air Race] Film of aircraft taking off from [[Brooklands]] 22 July 1911, including John Cyril Porte's accident and other scenes from [[Hendon Aerodrome]] *[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1913/1913%20-%200867.html Map of 1913 route published in ''Flight''] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20170617215220/http://www.exetermemories.co.uk/EM/_events/air_race.php Whipton, a stopping point for contestants in the 1911 contest]

{{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = DigiTour | image = | caption = | location = United States, Canada, United Kingdom | years_active = 2010–present | founders = [[Meridith Valiando Rojas]], [[Christopher Rojas]] | dates = | genre = [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[alternative rock]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]] | website = {{URL|thedigitour.com}} | attendance = 2011: 3,500
2012: 6,000
2013: 18,000
2014: 110,000
2015: 300,000 }} '''DigiTour Media''' is a touring and [[social media]] festival production company, known for producing the world's first [[social media]] tour.{{cite web|author=DigiTour Media LLC |url=http://www.prlog.org/12120651-the-digitour-presents-digifest-nyc-june-1st-at-terminal-5.html |title=The DigiTour Presents: DigiFest NYC - June 1st at Terminal 5 |publisher=PRLog |date=2013-04-17 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiTour events are held in venues such as theaters, amphitheaters, and parking lots or fields upon which the stages and other structures are erected. The tour began as a showcase for social media stars from [[YouTube]], but its roster of performers has now expanded to include [[Vine]], [[Twitter]], and [[Instagram]] stars as well as traditional pop music stars. ==Overview== DigiTour Media produces live events and unique content that features some of the most popular acts on [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2012/02/18/meridith-valiando-is-bringing-youtube-to-concert-halls |title=Meridith Valiando Is Bringing YouTube To Concert Halls |publisher=Forbes |date=2012-02-18 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiFest NYC, a full-day festival property owned by DigiTour, is typically held on the first Saturday of June in New York City.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.fanlala.com/news/digitour-coming-your-city |title=DigiFest NYC is Kicking Off the DigiTour! |publisher=Fanlala.com |date=2013-05-01 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} Many of the acts at DigiTour events do not get their music played on the radio yet continually sell out DigiTour's multiple events with their tens of millions of fans.{{cite web|last=Coscarelli |first=Joe |url=http://nymag.com/news/media/internet-fame/intro-2014-4/ |title=The Weird World of Internet Fame - New York Magazine |publisher=Nymag.com |date=2014-04-20 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiTour has secured multiple brand sponsorships from companies such as [[Intel]], [[Google]], [[Sony]], and [[Gibson]].{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/12/nj-ca-hello-digitour-idUSnPnCGd5RtB+165+PRN20131212 |title=Hello® Teams Up with The DigiTour for Digifest LA 2013 |publisher=Reuters |date=2013-12-12 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} On May 15, 2014, the company announced strategic investments from [[Ryan Seacrest]] and [[Advance Publications]], parent company of [[Conde Nast]].{{cite web|author=Todd Spangler|url=https://variety.com/2014/digital/news/ryan-seacrest-advance-publications-invest-in-digitour-a-youtube-concert-promoter-1201182222/ |title=Ryan Seacrest, Advance Publications Invest in DigiTour, a YouTube Concert Promoter |publisher=Variety |date=2014-05-15 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} ==History== DigiTour Media was founded in 2010 by music executive [[Meridith Valiando Rojas]] and multi-platinum music producer [[Christopher Rojas]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2012/02/18/meridith-valiando-is-bringing-youtube-to-concert-halls/ |title=Meridith Valiando Is Bringing YouTube To Concert Halls |publisher=Forbes |date=2012-02-18 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiTour has produced over 70 events as of 2013,{{cite web|url=http://www.soundctrl.com/digifest-the-youtube-music-festival-hits-nyc-june-1st/ |title=The Youtube Music Festival DigiFest hits NYC June 1st |publisher=SoundCtrl |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}} including all-day festivals, which feature 40–80 artists, as well as month-long tours.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.kidzworld.com/article/25337-the-digitour-youtubes-first-ever-tour |title=The DigiTour: YouTube’s First Ever Tour! |publisher=Kidzworld.com |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} The first DigiTour took place in 2011 and was sponsored by [[YouTube]].{{cite web|url=http://youtube-global.blogspot.com/2011/04/digitour-live-from-google-hq.html |title=Official Blog: The DigiTour: Live from Google HQ! |publisher=Youtube-global.blogspot.com |date=2011-04-07 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} The 27-city tour began with a multi-camera livestream at the [[Google]] Headquarters in Mountainview, California, on April 8, 2011. The 2011 tour's roster of performers had 6 million combined YouTube subscribers and 1 billion combined YouTube views.{{cite web|last=Baldwin |first=Drew |url=http://www.tubefilter.com/2011/12/12/the-digitour-2012/ |title=The Digitour Is Back, Kicking Off Spring 2012 |publisher=Tubefilter.com |date=2011-12-12 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} Pop musician [[Britney Spears]] attended the opening night of the tour at the [[El Rey Theater]].{{cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/236190/britney-spears-goes-undercover-at-l-a-concert |title=Britney Spears Goes Undercover at L.A. Concert | E! Online UK |publisher=Eonline.com |date=2011-04-13 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} The second DigiTour took place in 2012 and traveled to 18 cities including Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Orlando, Toronto, and New York City.{{cite web|url=http://www.hypebot.com/hypebot/2012/02/digitour-2012-brings-youtube-music-stars-to-live-stages.html |title=DigiTour 2012 Brings YouTube Music Stars To Stage |publisher=hypebot |date=2012-02-18 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiTour 2012's roster of performers had 10 million combined YouTube subscribers and 2 billion combined YouTube views. The first DigiFest took place on June 1, 2013, at [[Terminal 5 (venue)|Terminal 5]] in New York City and was headlined by [[Pentatonix]] and Allstar Weekend. The DigiFest roster included over 14 million combined YouTube subscribers and over 3.5 billion YouTube views. DigiTour 2013 showcased the most popular British YouTube personalities. Over 11,000 fans attended shows in Chicago, Toronto, Philadelphia, and New York.{{cite web|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20130828005416/en/British-Coming-DigiTour-2013#.U3BNeC_xL3o |title=The British Are Coming to DigiTour 2013 |publisher=Business Wire |date=2013-08-28 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} DigiFest LA took place on December 14, 2013, and was dubbed the largest YouTube music festival by [[Just Jared]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/main-topics/celebrities/1000873/bella-thorne-rebecca-black-and-noah-cyrus-hit-digifest-la-pics |title=Bella Thorne, Rebecca Black and Noah Cyrus hit DigiFest LA - PICS |publisher=Sugarscape |date= |accessdate=2014-05-21}} The event featured over 50 performances and was headlined by rapper [[Hoodie Allen]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/hello-teams-up-with-the-digitour-for-digifest-la-2013-235608931.html |title=Hello® Teams Up with The DigiTour for Digifest LA... - MONTCLAIR, N.J. and LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12, 2013 /PRNewswire/ |publisher=Prnewswire.com |date=2013-12-12 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} Teen actors [[Bella Thorne]], [[Madison Pettis]], [[Blake Michael]], and [[Jake Short]] also made on-stage appearances, with [[James Maslow]] of [[Big Time Rush]] and [[Darren Criss]] of ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' in attendance.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.fanlala.com/news/we-got-check-out-digifest-la-2013 |title=We Got to Check Out DigiFest LA 2013 |publisher=Fanlala.com |date=2013-12-17 |accessdate=2014-05-21}}{{cite web|url=http://alexisjoyvipaccess.wordpress.com/tag/james-maslow/ |title=James Maslow | alexisjoyvipaccess |publisher=Alexisjoyvipaccess.wordpress.com |date=2013-12-21 |accessdate=2014-05-21}} Nearly
