{{Violence against women}} '''Domestic violence in Pakistan''' is an endemic social and public health problem. According to a study carried out in 2009 by [[Human Rights Watch]], it is estimated that between 20 and 30 percent of women in Pakistan have suffered some form of abuse.<ref name=Gosselin>Cited in: {{cite book|last=Gosselin|first=Denise Kindschi|title=Heavy Hands: An Introduction to the Crime of Intimate and Family Violence|year=2009|publisher=Prentice Hall|isbn=978-0136139034|edition=4th|page=13}}</ref> An estimated 5000 women are killed per year from domestic violence, with thousands of others maimed or disabled.<ref name=Hansar2 /> Women have reported attacks ranging from physical to [[Psychological abuse|psychological]] and sexual abuse from intimate partners.<ref name="Ajmal 2012-04-25">{{cite news|url=http://dawn.com/2012/04/25/domestic-violence-2/|title=Domestic violence|last=Ajmal|first=Umer Bin|date=25 April 2012|newspaper=Dawn|accessdate=28 July 2012}}</ref> In 1998, of the 1974 reported murders, the majority of victims were killed by family members.<ref name="Zaman" /> A survey carried out by the [[Thomson Reuters Foundation]] ranked Pakistan as the third most dangerous country in the world for women, after [[Afghanistan]] and the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]]; it is followed by [[India]] and [[Somalia]].<ref name="Trustlaw">{{cite web|url=http://www.trust.org/trustlaw/news/trustlaw-poll-afghanistan-is-most-dangerous-country-for-women/|title=Trustlaw Poll: Afghanistan is most dangerous country for women|last=Anderson|first=Lisa|date=15 June 2011|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate=31 July 2012}}</ref> The majority of victims of violence have no legal recourse.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Zakar|first=Rubeena|last2=Zakar|first2=Muhammad|last3=Mikolajczyk|first3=Rafael|last4=Kraemer|first4=Alexander|year=2013|title=Spousal Violence Against Women and Its Association With Women's Mental Health in Pakistan|url=|journal=Health Care for Women International|volume=34|issue=9|pages=795–813|via=|doi=10.1080/07399332.2013.794462|pmid=23790086}}</ref> [[Law enforcement in Pakistan|Law enforcement authorities]] do not view domestic violence as a [[crime]] and usually refuse to register any cases brought to them.<ref name=":8" /> Given the very few [[women's shelter]]s in the country, victims have limited ability to escape from violent situations.<ref name=Hansar2>{{cite book|last=Hansar|first=Robert D.|title=Encyclopedia of Domestic Violence|year=2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415969680|edition=1st|editor=Nicky Ali Jackson|chapter=Cross-Cultural Examination of Domestic Violence in China and Pakistan|page=211}}</ref>
== Overview ==
=== Definition === As defined by the [[World Health Organization]], domestic violence encompasses physical and psychological distress including sexual coercive acts towards primarily women by a current or former male intimate partner.<ref>WHO (2005).WHO Multi-Country Study on Women’s Health and Domestic Violence against Women. Geneva: World Health Organization</ref>
The landmark Domestic Violence (Prevention and Protection) Act passed in 2012 by the Pakistani Senate defines domestic violence as including, “all acts of gender based and other physical or psychological abuse committed by a respondent against women, children or other vulnerable persons…”<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.af.org.pk/Important%20Courts'%20judgement/Women%20protection%20against%20domestic%20violence%20bil%2013pages.pdf|title=Domestic Violence Prevention and Protection Act|last=|first=|date=2012|website=|access-date=}}</ref> The definition then further specifies assault, attempt at assault, criminal force, criminal intimidation, emotional, psychological, and verbal abuse, harassment, stalking, sexual abuse, physical abuse, and economic abuse as some of the actions that fall under domestic violence.<ref name=":0" />
=== Statistics === An estimated 5000 women are killed per year from domestic violence, with thousands of others maimed or disabled.<ref name="Hansar2" /> Lisa Hajjar, an Associate Professor at the [[University of California]], describes abuse against women in Pakistan as "endemic in all social spheres".<ref name="Hajjar">{{cite book|title=Women's Rights and Islamic Family Law: Perspectives on Reform|last=Hajjar|first=Lisa|publisher=Zed Books|year=2004|isbn=978-1842770955|page=265|chapter=Domestic Violence and Sharía: A Comparative Study of Muslim Societies in the Middle East, Africa and Asia|editor=Lynn Welchman}}</ref> In an [[observational study]] published in the ''Pakistan Journal of Medical Sciences'' based on a [[convenience sample]] of 218 women in the gynecology wards of three hospitals, 97% of the interviewed women said they had been victims of some form of assault, ranging from verbal abuse or threatened, to being subjected to beatings [[Rape in Pakistan|or non-consensual sex]].<ref name="Shaikh">{{cite journal|last=Shaikh|first=Masood Ali|year=2003|title=Is domestic violence endemic in Pakistan: perspective from Pakistani Wives|url=http://www.pjms.com.pk/issues/janmar03/article03.pdf|journal=Pakistan Journal of Medical Sciences|volume=19|issue=1|pages=23–28}} Cited in: {{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Domestic Violence|last=Hanser|first=Robert D.|publisher=Routledge|year=2007|isbn=978-0415969680|edition=1st|page=211|chapter=Cross-cultural examination of domestic violence in China and Pakistan|editor=Nicky Ali Jackson}}</ref> A study by the United Nations found that 50% of married women have experienced sexual violence and 90% have been psychologically abused.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Nasrullah|first=Muazzam|last2=Haqqi|first2=Sobia|last3=Cummings|first3=Kristin|year=2009|title=The epidemiological patterns of honour killing of women in Pakistan|url=|journal=European Journal of Public Health|volume=19|issue=2|pages=193–197|via=|doi=10.1093/eurpub/ckp021|pmid=19286837}}</ref> Studies by the Pakistan Nation Women's Division and Zakar et al. confirmed these statistics of high percentages of domestic violence in Pakistani households.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":8" />
Research has also shown high rates of domestic violence primarily in rural communities and Afghani refugees living in Pakistan.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Zakar|first=Rubeena|last2=Zakar|first2=Muhammad|last3=Abbas|first3=Safdar|year=2015|title=Domestic Violence Against Rural Women in Pakistan: An Issue of Health and Human Rights|url=|journal=Springer Science|volume=31|pages=15–25|via=|doi=10.1007/s10896-015-9742-6}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=2000|title=Violence Against Women: Mission to Pakistan and Afghanistan|url=http://evaw-global-database.unwomen.org/-/media/files/un%20women/vaw/country%20report/asia/pakistan/pakistan%20srvaw.pdf|journal=United Nations Economic and Social Council|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> A cross-sectional survey of 490 randomly selected women from a rural health center in Pakistan of reproductive age reported that 65% of those interviewed had experienced domestic violence.<ref name=":1" /> A special report by the United Nations of the state of violence against women in Pakistan reported that Afghani refugees are left out of Pakistani services and of Pakistani statistics.<ref name=":2" /> The report noted that violence against women like child abuse and domestic violence is considerably high, however, proper statistics on this population are difficult to obtain.<ref name=":2" />
==Types of abuse==
=== Physical violence ===
==== Dowry deaths ==== [[Dowry death]]s have been described by the [[United Nations]] as a form of domestic violence in Pakistan.<ref name="Van Wormer" /> Women are often attacked and murdered if their in-laws deem their [[dowry]] to have been insufficient.<ref name="Pickup">{{cite book|title=Ending Violence Against Women: A Challenge for Development and Humanitarian Work|last=Pickup|first=Francine|publisher=Oxfam|year=2000|isbn=978-0855984380|edition=|page=91|author2=Suzanne Williams|author3=Caroline Sweetman}}</ref> Amongst dowry-related violence, [[bride burning]]s, also known as "stove deaths",<ref name="Terzieff">{{cite news|url=http://womensenews.org/story/domestic-violence/021027/pakistans-fiery-shame-women-die-stove-deaths|title=Pakistan's Fiery Shame: Women Die in Stove Deaths|last=Terzieff|first=Juliette|date=October 27, 2002|newspaper=Women's eNews}}</ref> are widely reported. In 1988 a survey showed that 800 women were killed in this manner, in 1989 the number rose to 1100, and in 1990 it stood at 1800 estimated killings. According to the Progressive Women's Association, such attacks are a growing problem and, in 1994 on [[International Women's Day]], announced that various NGOs would join to raise awareness of the issue.<ref name="Rappaport">{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Women Social Reformers, Volume 1|last=Rappaport|first=Helen|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2001|isbn=978-1576071014|page=115}}</ref> Newspapers in [[Lahore]] in a six-month period (1997) reported on average 15 attacks a month.<ref name="Jilani">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=QWUKUF1MAu8C&pg=PA161#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Violence, Law and Women's Rights in South Asia|last=Jilani|first=Hina|publisher=Sage|year=2004|isbn=978-0761997962|page=161|chapter=Violence against Women: The Legal System and Institutional Responses in Pakistan|author2=Eman M. Ahmed|editor=Savitri Goonesekere|accessdate=3 August 2012}}</ref> [[Women's eNews]] reported that 4,000 women had been attacked in this manner in [[Islamabad]]'s surroundings over an eight-year period, and that the average age range of victims was between 18 and 35, with an estimated 30 percent being pregnant at the time of death.<ref name="Terzieff" /> The Human Rights Commission of Pakistan reported that about four women are killed in this manner every day, by either family members or husbands.<ref name="UNICEF">{{cite journal|last=Kapoor|first=Sushma|date=June 2000|title=Domestic Violence Against Women and Girls|url=http://www.unicef-irc.org/publications/pdf/digest6e.pdf|journal=Innocenti Digest|page=7|issn=1028-3528|number=6}}</ref> [[Shahnaz Bukhari]], who runs the [[Progressive Women's Association]] in Islamabad, has said of such attacks: "Either Pakistan is home to possessed stoves which burn only young housewives, and are particularly fond of genitalia, or looking at the frequency with which these incidences occur there is a grim pattern that these women are victims of deliberate murder."<ref name="Terzieff" />
==== Acid attacks ==== [[Acid throwing|Acid attacks]] in Pakistan came to international attention after the release of a documentary by [[Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy]] called ''[[Saving Face (2012 film)|Saving Face]]'' (2012).<ref name=Rodriguez /> According to Shahnaz Bukhari, the majority of these attacks occur in the summer when acid is used extensively to soak certain seeds [[Seed#Inducing germination|to induce germination]].<ref name=Ali>{{cite news|last=Ali|first=Sahar|title=Acid attack victim demands justice|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/3097469.stm|newspaper=BBC|date=July 28, 2003}}</ref> Various reasons have been given for such attacks, such as a woman dressing inappropriately or rejecting a proposal of marriage. The first known instance of an acid attack occurred in [[East Pakistan]] in 1967.<ref name=Weightman>{{cite book|last=Weightman|first=Barbara A.|title=Dragons and Tigers: A Geography of South, East, and Southeast Asia|year=2012|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-0470876282|edition=3rd|page=77}}</ref> According to the [[Acid Survivors Foundation]], up to 150 attacks occur every year. The foundation reports that the attacks are often the result in an escalation of domestic abuse, and the majority of victims are female.<ref name=Rodriguez>{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Alex|title=Pakistan offers little justice for victims of acid attacks|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/may/29/world/la-fg-pakistan-acid-attacks-20120529|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=May 29, 2012}}</ref>
==== Honour killing ==== A recent report noted that one in five homicides in Pakistan are attributed to [[Honor killing|honour killings]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Dobson|first=Roger|year=2009|title="Honour killings" are a public health problem for Pakistan|url=|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=338|pages=739|via=}}</ref> The prevalence of such honour killings that have been reported are around 2,000 killings every four years.<ref name=":5" /> Overall, out of all homicides of both men and women in Pakistan, honour killings of women constitute 21%.<ref name=":6" /> Moreover, the perpetrator in most honour killings is the husband.<ref name=":5" /> One study found as high as 92% of all honour killings are committed by the spouse.<ref name=":5" /> The highest occurring reason in spousal honour killings was alleged extramarital affairs.<ref name=":5" /> Much of the data has been collected by the Human Rights Commission of Pakistan through newspaper reports, however, it is clear there needs to be more systematic research by a health agency is needed to assess this public health crisis and effectively plan for solutions as many cases go unreported.<ref name=":5" /> Another analysis of this research states that a possible explanation of the high rate of honour killings towards married women could be attributed to the generally high statistics of domestic violence in Pakistan.<ref name=":6" />
=== Psychological abuse === Psychological abuse generally includes yelling, insulting, controlling behaviors, and threatening. In a study by Zakar et al., of 373 randomly selected married women of reproductive age interviewed in Pakistani hospitals, 60.8% reported as current victims of severe psychological violence with 15% having been victims in the past.<ref name=":8" /> The percentage of women going through current psychological violence far surpassed the percentages of women going through current sexual (27.3%) and physical (21.7%) violence. Moreover, more than half of these participants, 54%, reported being currently in a poor state of mental health.
==Factors== [[File:Smile of Poverty.jpg|thumb|A young girl in a rural area of the Sindh province of Pakistan is selling these baskets her family has made for a living.]]
=== Poverty === Associated with poverty is illiteracy and social stigma against domestic violence.<ref name="Dawn: factors 2">{{cite news|title=Poverty, illiteracy termed causes of domestic violence|url=http://archives.dawn.com/2006/03/04/nat41.htm|accessdate=6 September 2012|newspaper=Dawn|date=3 March 2006}}</ref> Lack of an education due to financial reasons accompanies a lack of awareness about women’s rights.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Bibi|first=Seema|last2=Ashfaq|first2=Sanober|last3=Shaikh|first3=Farhana|last4=Qureshi|first4=Mohammad|year=2014|title=Prevalence, instigating factors and help seeking behavior of physical domestic violence among married women of Hyderabad, Sindh|url=|journal=Pakistani Journal of Medicine Science|volume=30|pages=|via=}}</ref> Moreover, because mental health illiteracy is especially widespread in low-income areas, many women to not get appropriate treatment for the after effects of domestic violence.<ref name=":8" />
=== Patriarchalism === Another reason given for abuses is [[Patriarchal society|patriarchalism]] in Pakistani society, which marginalizes women’s role.<ref name="Zaman">{{cite book|title=Family, Law and Politics: Encyclopedia of Women and Islamic Cultures: 2|last=Zaman|first=Habiba|publisher=Brill|year=2004|isbn=978-9004128187|page=124|editor=Suad Joseph|editor2=Afsaneh Najmabad}}</ref> In some [[Traditional society|traditional societies]], a man is considered to have the right to physically beat his spouse on his wish.<ref name="Van Wormer">{{cite book|last=Van Wormer|first=Katherine|title=Human Behavior and the Social Environment, Macro Level: Groups, Communities|year=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0199740574|edition=2nd|author2=Fred H. Besthorn|page=149}}</ref> According to Rahel Nardos, it is "the dual constructs of women as the property of men and as the standard-bearers of a family's honour set the stage for culturally sanctioned forms of violence".<ref name="Hassan">{{cite book|last=Nardos|first=Rahel|title=Overcoming Violence Against Women and Girls: The International Campaign to Eradicate a World-wide Problem|year=2003|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers|isbn=978-0742525009|chapter=Cultural, Traditional Practices and Gender-Based Violence|pages=87–88|author2=Michael L. Penn|author3=Mary K. Radpour|author4=William S. Hatcher|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=yfpCY3PdpDoC&pg=PA87}}</ref> In some cases, women perpetuate patriarchalism and domestic abuse especially in regard to mothers-in-law.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Roomani|first=Fahad|last2=Tayyab|first2=Faiza|last3=Kamal|first3=Nudrat|last4=Siddique|first4=Kashif|year=2016|title=Role of Women in Perpetuating Violence against Women: Case Studies of Domestic Violence Victims|url=|journal=Pakistan Journal of Social Sciences|volume=36|pages=1185–1195|via=}}</ref><ref name=":12" /> Many women are expected to be homemakers and to perform key household duties, however, if a woman is not performing her duties by her mother-in-law's standards, the mother-in-law may seek to punish the woman through her son.<ref name=":9" />
In analysis of data from 3,867 married or previously married women from the 2012 - 2013 Pakistan Demographic and Health Survey, association was found between the intergenerational transfer of spousal violence and cultural views of women.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Aslam|first=Syeda|last2=Zaheer|first2=Sidra|last3=Shafique|first3=Kashif|year=2015|title=Is Spousal Violence Being "Vertically Transmitted" through Victims? Findings from the Pakistan Demographic and Health Survey 2012-13|url=|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=10|issue=6|pages=e0129790|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0129790|pmid=26083619|pmc=4470804}}</ref> Strikingly, 47% of these women agreed that beating of a spouse was justified if the wife had argued with her husband.<ref name=":10" /> Statistics such as this prove that patriarchalism within the Pakistani society has led many Pakistani women to believe that domestic violence is normal or even at times justified. This idea is enforced by a study done of 759 Pakistani women between the ages of 25 and 60 years old in which 27% admitted they had never told anyone of the spousal violence they had endured or were currently enduring.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ali|first=Tazeen|last2=Mogren|first2=Ingrid|last3=Krantz|first3=Gunilla|year=2013|title=Intimate Partner Violence and Mental Health Effects: A Population-Based Study among Married Women in Karachi, Pakistan|url=|journal=International Journal of Behavioral Medicine|volume=20|pages=131–139|via=}}</ref>
=== Child marriage === [[File:Women_and_girls_in_Qamber,_Shadadkot,_north-west_Sindh,_Pakistan_(8406155976).jpg|thumb|Women and girls in Qamber, Shadadkot, north-west Sindh, Pakistan (8406155976)]]Defined as marriage before the age of 18 years, child marriage is widespread in Pakistan and linked to spousal violence.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Nasrullah|first=Muazzam|last2=Zakar|first2=Rubeena|last3=Zakar|first3=Muhammad|year=2014|title=Child Marriage and Its Associations With Controlling Behaviors and Spousal Violence Against Adolescent and Young Women in Pakistan|url=|journal=Journal of Adolescent Health|volume=55|issue=6|pages=804–809|via=|doi=10.1016/j.jadohealth.2014.06.013|pmid=25123525}}</ref> Child marriage occurs most often in rural and low-income households where education is minimal.<ref name=":3" /> The Pakistan Demographic and Health Survey conducted from 2012 to 2013 reported that 47.5% of currently married women aged 15 to 24 had been married before the age of 18.<ref name=":3" /> Moreover, of those child marriages, one-third of those women reported spousal violence.<ref name=":3" />
=== Marriages within the extended family === [[Consanguinity|Consanguineous]] marriages, or those within blood relations such as first and second cousins, are considered marriages in ''biraderi,'' or brotherhood, within many Pakistani subcultures.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Shaikh|first=Masood|year=2016|title=Domestic violence in consanguineous marriages - findings from Pakistan Demographic and Health Survey 2012-13|url=|journal=Journal of Pakistan Medical Association|volume=66|pages=|via=}}</ref> Based on reported research, about two-thirds of all Pakistani marriages are within families.<ref name=":4" /> Analysis of a Pakistani Health Demographic Survey from 2012 to 2013 showed that women in consanguineous marriages are more likely to face psychological domestic abuse.<ref name=":4" /> However, findings in this study also reported the prevalence of domestic violence within the larger Pakistani population as well.<ref name=":4" />
=== Increased urbanization === Another factor given for the rise in domestic violence has been due to increased [[urbanization]]. As people move from villages and increasingly live apart from an extended family, assaults are less likely to be prevented by the intervention of family members, who in past times often intervened in domestic conflicts.<ref name="Weiss">{{cite book|title=India and Pakistan: The First Fifty Years|last=Weiss|first=Anita M.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1998|isbn=978-0521645850|page=146|chapter=Pakistan: Some progress, sobering challenges|editor=Selig S. Harrison|editor2=Paul H. Kreisberg|editor3=Dennis Kux}}</ref> In particular, women who move cities or areas after marriage away from their respective family are more at risk for domestic violence.<ref name=":8" /> These women are left without parental or familial support as the only contacts they have are now limited to their husband and husband's family.<ref name=":8" /> Violent spousal relationships are perpetuated by isolation of the victim and lack of social support.<ref name=":8" />
== Impact on women == === Physical and psychological health outcomes === Domestic violence leads to increased risk towards certain health outcomes like major depression, dysthymia, conduct disorder, and drug abuse.<ref name=":6" /> Moreover, because women are primary caretakers in Pakistan, children also face increased risk for depression and behavioural problems.<ref name=":8" /> Zakar et al. found in their study that of those interviewed (373 women from Pakistani hospitals) including women who had experienced severe domestic violence, 54% reported poor current mental health. Associated with this self-reported statistic of women in a poor state of mental health was also a high prevalence of mental health disorders with anxiety and depression being the most common.<ref name=":8" />
In particular, physical violence has long-term, negative psychological impacts on women with stigma against mental health serving as an impediment to treatment.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":8" /> At times, physical violence may cause permanent disfiguration of the body causing physical ailments that lead to a variety of psychological disorders like depression.<ref name=":8" /><ref name="Hassan" /> Furthermore, women are often unable to receive treatment for psychological disorders as mental health within the cultural realm of Pakistan is not considered a health matter.<ref name=":8" /><ref name="UNICEF" /> Mental health illiteracy leads to treatment of mental health disorders superstitiously or not at all.<ref name=":8" /><ref name="Hassan" />
Another study that examined domestic violence and pregnancy among Pakistani women found that 51% of respondents reported experiencing domestic violence in the six months prior to or after pregnancy.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Karmaliani|first=Rozina|last2=Irfan|first2=Farhana|last3=Bann|first3=Carla|last4=Mcclure|first4=Elizabeth|last5=Moss|first5=Nancy|year=2008|title=Domestic violence prior to and during pregnancy among Pakistani women|url=|journal=Acta Obstetricia et Gynecologica Scandinavica|volume=87|issue=11|pages=1194–1201|via=|doi=10.1080/00016340802460263|pmid=18951219}}</ref> The researchers of this study and others have suggested due to the prevalence of domestic violence in pregnant women that domestic violence be screened for during antenatal care.<ref name=":11" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mufiza|first=Farid|last2=Saleem|first2=Sarah|last3=Karim|first3=Mehtab|last4=Hatcher|first4=Juanita|year=2008|title=Clinical Article: Spousal abuse during pregnancy in Karachi, Pakistan|url=|journal=International Journal of Gynecology and Obstetrics|volume=101|pages=141–145|via=}}</ref>
=== Bargaining power === Women in domestic violence relationships often have no recourse of escaping due to fear of murder from the perpetrator.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Jacoby|first=Hanan|last2=Mansuri|first2=Ghazala|year=2010|title="Watta Satta": Bride Exchange and Women's Welfare in Rural Pakistan|url=|journal=American Economic Association|volume=100|issue=4|pages=1804–1825|via=|doi=10.1257/aer.100.4.1804}}</ref> A vivid example of this is the practice of ''watta satta'', or bride exchange, whereby <ref name=":4" /> a daughter from one family is swapped for a daughter of another in a brother-sister pair.<ref name=":13" /> Power dynamics between the families follow a revenge-based model. If a husband is harsh on his wife then the mutual threat exists of the husband's brother-in-law being harsh on his sister.<ref name=":13" /> These reciprocal threats leave women in positions with little to no bargaining power.<ref name=":13" /> This leaves women in a position where they cannot escape a marriage because of cross bride exchange family entanglement.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":8" /> Adding to the complexity, divorce is also highly stigmatized within the Pakistani culture.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":12" />
Bargaining power of women in domestic violence relationships is also minimal due to residence with the husband's family.<ref name=":13" /> Particularly, in rural areas, if a woman in a domestic violence relationship is living with her husband's family, she has little recourse to seek help or escape.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /> Studies on attitudes of domestic violence in Pakistan have shown that though these families in rural areas may wish to help their daughter, it is costly to continuously visit her.<ref name=":4" /> In other cases, domestic violence perpetrator families have been shown to taunt or ridicule those seeking justice.<ref name=":4" />
==Policy initiatives==
=== General legislation against domestic violence === In 2009 a Domestic Violence Protection bill was proposed by Yasmeen Rehman of the [[Pakistan People’s Party]]. It was passed in the [[National Assembly of Pakistan|National Assembly]]<ref name="Ghauri">{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C08%5C05%5Cstory_5-8-2009_pg7_4|title=NA passes law against domestic violence|last=Ghauri|first=Irfan|date=August 5, 2009|newspaper=Daily Times|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102124743/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C08%5C05%5Cstory_5-8-2009_pg7_4|archivedate=November 2, 2013|df=}}</ref> but subsequently failed to be passed in the second chamber of parliament, the [[Senate of Pakistan|Senate]], within the prescribed period of time.<ref name="Gishkori1">{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/360560/opposition-forces-government-to-defer-women-domestic-violence-bill/|title=Opposition forces government to defer women domestic violence bill|date=6 April 2012|publisher=The Express Tribune|author=Zahid Gishkori|accessdate=28 July 2012}}</ref> The [[Council of Islamic Ideology]] objected to the bill, claiming that in its current form it will increase divorces and argued that the bill considered women and children the only victims of domestic violence, ignoring elderly and weak men.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brightman|first=Sara|year=2015|title=Rights, women, and the state of Pakistan|url=|journal=Contemporary Justice Review|volume=18|issue=3|pages=334–351|via=|doi=10.1080/10282580.2015.1057706}}</ref> The council claimed that the punishments suggested by the bill were already enacted by other laws and suggested lack of action on these laws as the reason for increase in domestic violence.<ref name="Nasir Iqbal">{{cite news|url=http://archives.dawn.com/archives/41327|title=Domestic Violence Bill to push up divorce rate: CII|date=24 August 2009|accessdate=4 September 2012|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]|author=Nasir Iqbal}}</ref> After the passage of [[Eighteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Eighteenth constitutional amendment]], the matter pertaining to the bill became a provincial issue.<ref name="Ayesha Shahid">{{cite news|url=http://dawn.com/2012/04/07/domestic-violencebill-gets-new-look/|title=Domestic violence bill gets new look|date=7 April 2012|accessdate=6 September 2012|newspaper=Dawn|author=Ayesha Shahid}}</ref> It was re-tabled in 2012, but met with a deadlock in parliament because of stiff opposition from the [[Islamism|religious right]]. Representatives of Islamic organizations vowed resistance to the proposed bill, describing it as "anti-Islamic" and an attempt to promote "Western cultural values" in Pakistan. They asked for the bill to be reviewed before being approved by the parliament.<ref name="Gishkori2">{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/365842/citing-controversial-clauses-clerics-vow-to-resist-passage-of-domestic-violence-bill/|title=Citing ‘controversial’ clauses: Clerics vow to resist passage of Domestic Violence Bill|last=Gishkori|first=Zahid|date=April 17, 2012|newspaper=The Express Tribune}}</ref> The bill was passed for [[Islamabad Capital Territory]].<ref name="Ayesha Shahid" /><ref name="Original bill">{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.gov.pk/Legis%20Br/bill/Private%20Bills/viol-12.pdf|title=Domestic Violence (Prevention and Protection) Act, 2012|date=20 February 2012|publisher=Senate of Pakistan|format=PDF|accessdate=29 July 2012}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
=== Specific legislation against certain offenses ===
==== Dowry deaths ==== In 1976 the Pakistani government passed legislation on dowry and bridal gifts in an attempt to eliminate the custom but, because of cultural and societal norms combined with government ineffectiveness, such killings over inadequate dowries continue.<ref name="Zaman" />
==== Acid attacks ==== In 1999 the [[Senate of Pakistan]] rejected a resolution which would have condemned the practice of murdering women for the sake of family honour.<ref name="Ajmal 1999-08-25">{{cite news|title=World:South Asia Bride burning 'kills hundreds'|last=Ajmal|first=Umer Bin|date=25 August 1999|newspaper=Dawn}}</ref> In 2011 the Senate passed the ''Acid Control and Acid Crime Prevention Bill'' to repress acid attacks in the country; the senate also passed the prevention of anti-women practices bill.<ref name="Foreign and Commonwealth Office">{{cite book|title=Human Rights and Democracy: The 2011 Foreign and Commonwealth Office Report|publisher=TSO|year=2012|isbn=978-0101833929|page=292}}</ref>
==== Honour killing ==== On April 21, 2001, the national government leader [[Pervez Musharraf]] declared that [[Honour killing in Pakistan|honour killings]] were "vigorously condemned" by the government and would be treated as murder.<ref name="UNICEF2">{{cite journal|last=Kapoor|first=Sushma|date=June 2000|title=Domestic Violence Against Women and Girls|url=http://www.unicef-irc.org/publications/pdf/digest6e.pdf|journal=Innocenti Digest|page=6|issn=1028-3528|number=6}}</ref> The Ministry of Women Development set up ten crisis centres to help the victims of domestic violence and raise the awareness level of the people on this issue.<ref name="Shahina Imran">{{cite news|url=http://www.irinnews.org/Report/77226/PAKISTAN-Domestic-violence-endemic-but-awareness-slowly-rising|title=Pakistan: Domestic violence endemic, but awareness slowly rising|date=11 March 2008|agency=[[Integrated Regional Information Networks]]|location=Lahore|accessdate=4 September 2012|author=Shahina Imran}}</ref> Particularly in 2004, Pakistan's Criminal Law (Amendment) Act passed that provided legal protection for womenOn April 21, 2001, the national government leader [[Pervez Musharraf]] declared that [[Honour killing in Pakistan|honour killings]] were "vigorously condemned" by the government and would be treated as murder.<ref name="UNICEF2" /> The Ministry of Women Development set up ten crisis centres to help the victims of domestic violence and raise the awareness level of the people on this issue.<ref name="Shahina Imran" /> Particularly in 2004, Pakistan's Criminal Law (Amendment) Act passed that provided legal protection for women against any offense committed by family members for the sake of honour.<ref name=":6" /> However, Pakistan's legal system has done little to uphold this legislation.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Muhammad|first=N|last2=Omer|first2=F|last3=Mushtaq|first3=A|last4=Shah|first4=M|year=2012|title=Honor killing in Pakistan: An Islamic perspective|url=|journal=Asian Social Science|volume=10|pages=180–185|via=}}</ref> The National Commission on the Status of Women reports that Pakistan is doing little to bring justice to perpetrators.<ref name=":7" /> If the family of the victim forgives the perpetrator, then the perpetrator will be set free despite clear violation of Pakistani law.<ref name=":7" /> Oftentimes, families who are caught in an honour killing case come from rural areas where families must work together in a village on the daily to live.<ref name=":7" /> When an honour killing occurs, the family of the victim are highly likely to forgive the perpetrator based on what elders of the village advise them to do.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jamal|first=A|year=2015|title=Piety, Transgression, and the Feminist Debate on Muslim Women: Resituating the Victim-Subject of Honor-Related Violence from a Transnational Lens|url=|journal=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|volume=41|pages=55–79|via=|doi=10.1086/681771}}</ref>
== Support organizations == From both international and internal funding, there are a variety of NGO's that provide support to women who have endured or are enduring domestic violence. * Bedari (funded by [[United Nations Development Programme]])<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bedari.org.pk|title=Bedari: Awakening for human rights|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> * [[White Ribbon Campaign]] Pakistan<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whiteribbon.org.pk|title=White Ribbon Pakistan|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> * [[War Against Rape]] Pakistan * [[Acid Survivors Foundation]] Pakistan<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://acidsurvivorspakistan.org|title=Acid Survivors Pakistan|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080227222659/http://www.acidsurvivorspakistan.org/|archive-date=2008-02-27|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> * [[Chayn]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/599506/domestic-violence-within-the-four-walls/|title=Domestic violence: Within the four walls - The Express Tribune|date=2013-09-04|work=The Express Tribune|access-date=2017-09-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Domestic violence in India]] * [[Honor killing]] * [[Honour killing in Pakistan]] * [[Honour killing of Sadia Sheikh]] * [[Honour killing of Ghazala Khan]] * [[Acid throwing]] * [[Dowry death]] * [[Domestic violence]] * [[Child marriage]]

{{Infobox Wrestling event |name =El Protector (2017) |image = El Protector 2017.png |caption =Official poster for the tournament |promotion = [[International Wrestling Revolution Group]] |date = February 19, 2017<ref name=Protector2017/> |venue = [[Arena Naucalpan]]<ref name=Protector2017/> |city = [[Naucalpan, State of Mexico]]<ref name=Protector2017/> |liveevent = y |lastevent = [[IWRG Máscara vs. Cabellera (February 2017)|Máscara vs. Cabellera]] |nextevent =[[IWRG Triangular de la Muerte (2017)]] (2017) |event = [[IWRG El Protector|El Protector]] |lastevent2 = [[El Protector (2016)]] |nextevent2 = [[El Protector (2018)]] }} '''El Protector (2017)''' was an annual [[professional wrestling]] major event produced by Mexican [[professional wrestling promotion]] [[International Wrestling Revolution Group]] (IWRG), which took place on February 19, 2017 in [[Arena Naucalpan]], [[Naucalpan, State of Mexico]], Mexico. The 2017 El Protector was the eight annual event produced under that name and the fourth to be held in January. The focal point of the show was the El Protector [[tag team]] tournament where eight teams composed of a "rookie" and a "vet" team up to compete for a trophy.
Rookie [[Diablo Jr.]] teamed up with veteran [[Black Terry]] to win the 2017 El Protector tournament defeating [[Demonio Infernal]] and [[Negro Navarro]] in the finals. The tournament also saw the teams of Black Dragón and [[Pantera (wrestler)|Internacional Pantera]], [[El Hijo de Dos Caras]] and [[El Hijo del Alebrije]], [[Herodes Jr.]] and [[Imposible (wrestler)|Imposible]], Hip Hop Man and [[Electroshock (wrestler)|Mr. Electro]], [[Dragón Fly (wrestler)|Dragón Fly]] and [[Villano IV]], Alfa and [[Máscara Año 2000 Jr.]] participated in the tournament. The show also featured four non-tournament matches.
==Production== ===Background=== ''Lucha Libre'' has a tradition for a tournament where a rookie, or ''novato'', would be teamed up with an experienced veteran wrestler for a [[tag team]] tournament in the hopes of giving the ''Novato'' a chance to show case their talent and move up the ranks. [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] has held a [[CMLL Torneo Gran Alternativa|Torneo Gran Alternativa]] ("Great Alternative Tournament") almost every year since 1994, but the concept predates the creation of the Gran Alternativa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/emll/grand.html | title=CMLL Gran Alternativa | accessdate=August 1, 2015 | publisher=Pro Wrestling History}}</ref> The Mexican [[wrestling promotion|professional wrestling company]] [[International Wrestling Revolution Group]] (IWRG; at times referred to as ''Grupo Internacional Revolución'' in Mexico) started their own annual rookie/veteran tournament in 2010. The first two tournaments were called Torneo Relampago de Proyeccion a Nuevas Promesas de la Lucha Libre ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "Projecting a new promise lightning tournament") but would be renamed the [[IWRG El Protector|El Protector]] tournament in 2012. The El Protector shows, as well as the majority of the IWRG shows in general, are held in "Arena Naucalpan", owned by the promoters of IWRG and their main arena. The 2017 El Protector show was the eight time that IWRG promoted a show around the rookie/veteran tournament.
===Storylines=== The El Protector event featured 11 [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] with different wrestlers involved in pre-existing [[Screenplay|scripted]] feuds, [[plot (narrative)|plots]] and [[narrative thread|storylines]]. Wrestlers were portrayed as either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that portray the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they followed a series of tension-building events, which culminated in a wrestling match or series of matches.<ref>{{cite book | author= Madigan, Dan | title= Mondo Lucha a Go Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling | publisher= HarperColins Publisher | year= 2007 | chapter = "Okay... what is Lucha Libre?" | page = 31 | quote=featuring clearly distinguished good guys and bad guys, or técnicos and rudos | isbn=978-0-06-085583-3|location=New York, New York}}</ref>
===Tournament participants=== *Alfa {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Máscara Año 2000 Jr.]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *Black Dragón {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Pantera (wrestler)|Internacional Pantera]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *[[Demonio Infernal]] {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Negro Navarro]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *[[Diablo Jr.]] {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Black Terry]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *[[Dragón Fly (wrestler)|Dragón Fly]] {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Villano IV]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *[[El Hijo del Alebrije]] {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[El Hijo de Dos Caras]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *Hip Hop Man {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Electroshock (wrestler)|Mr. Electro]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/> *[[Imposible (wrestler)|Imposible]] {{small|(Rookie)}} and [[Herodes Jr.]] {{small|(Veteran)}}<ref name=Protector2017/>
==Event== During the fourth match of the night, [[Relámpago (wrestler)|Relámpago]] dove out of the ring at [[Apolo Estrada Jr.]], who moved out of the way at the last moment which caused Relámpago to crash into the steel barricade. As a result of the impact, Relámpago was unable to return to the ring and was counted out. It's unclear if this was the planned end or if Relámpago hit the guardrail harder than expected, rendering him unable to get back up.<ref name=Protector2017/>
==Aftermath== As a result of winning the 2017 El Protector Diablo Jr. and Black Terry earned a match for the [[IWRG Intercontinental Tag Team Championship]].<ref name=Estrellas/> A week after the tournament Diablo Jr. and Black Terry defeated Chicano and [[Veneno (wrestler)|Veneno]] to win the championship.<ref name=IWRGTag30>{{cite web | url=http://www.thegladiatores.com/las-dinastias-se-llevan-la-copa-high-power/ | title=Las Dinastías se llevan la Copa High Power| first=Diego | last=Mejía Eguiluz | date=February 27, 2017 | accessdate=February 28, 2017 | work=The Gladiatores | language=Spanish}}</ref> Their reign as champions lasted for 190 days and included two successful championship defenses until they were defeated by [[Black Warrior (wrestler)|Black Warrior]] and Warrior Jr. on September 3, 2017.<ref name=IWRGTag31>{{cite web | url=http://www.thegladiatores.com/eterno-gana-la-cabellera-de-bombero-infernal/ | title=Eterno gana la cabellera de Bombero Infernal. | date=September 4, 2017 | accessdate=September 19, 2017 | work=The Gladiatores | language=Spanish | first=Alfonso | last=Lizárraga}}</ref>
==Results== {{Pro Wrestling results table |results=<ref name=Protector2017>{{cite web | url=http://www.thegladiatores.com/diablo-jr-i-y-black-terry-ganan-el-protector-2017/ | title=Diablo Jr. I y Black Terry ganan El Protector 2017 | first=Jose | last=Lazaro Rodriguez | date=February 20, 2017 | accessdate=October 7, 2018 | work=The Gladiatores | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Estrellas>{{cite web | url=http://estrellasdelring.blogspot.com/2017/02/mas-sabe-un-temerario-por-diablo-black.html | title=Más sabe un Temerario por Diablo....¡¡¡ Black Terry y Diablo primero Jr se llevan El Protector!!! | date=February 19, 2017 | accessdate=October 7, 2018 | work=Estrellas del Ring | first=Eduardo | last=Reyes Ruiz | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Cage>{{cite web | url=https://www.cagematch.net//?id=1&nr=172834 | title=IWRG | date=February 19, 2017 | accessdate=October 7, 2018 | work=CageMatch}}</ref> |hide=all

[[Image:Emergency Room artwork clock.jpg|thumb|Emergency Room Entrance]] [[Image:ERAthens.jpg|thumb|200px|Emergency Room in Athens, 2007]] [[Image:ERdebate.jpg|thumb|200px|Participants debate after "The Passage"]] [[Image:ERParis.jpg|thumb|200px|Emergency Room in Paris, 2008. "The Passage""]] [[Image:ERHanoi.jpg|thumb|200px|Emergency Room in Hanoi, 2009 - Debate after "The Passage"]] [[File:Delaymus.jpg|thumb|200px|The Delay Museum, Poland 2011]] '''Emergency Room''' is an art exhibition format devised by [[Thierry Geoffroy]] for artists with desire to engage quickly in the current debate. Artists are invited to contribute with art works that are produced daily in response to ongoing social issues, contributing to a constantly changing exhibition. The format avoids the need for an artist to wait months or years before being able to exhibit their art. Emergency Room exhibitions have been held in a number of locations globally. == Emergency Room format ==
"''Artists, audience and media have been fighting for weeks in order to get to see and participate in the new and innovating exhibition that with its "art of the news" puts the art institution itself to debate. Reuters, The New Yorker and the TV-channel ABC News are some of the leading media that have brought the story about the original exhibition, and at P.S.1 more than a thousand visitors per day have been seeing it…''" said Danish newspaper ''[[Weekendavisen]]'' in March 2007.Nikolaj M. Lassen, [http://www.emergencyrooms.org/coverage/weekendavisen.pdf "Art = Retard" (in Danish)], ''Weekendavisen'', 30 March 2007.
Emergency Rooms are "carefully prepared environment[s] for hectic bursts of creation".[http://www.emergencyrooms.org/short.html The Emergency Room Format], Emergencyrooms.org. Retrieved 2013-04-30. Emergency Rooms can take place in several places across the world at the same time. When art institutions wish to host the Emergency Room format they are given a license to produce a version of the format.[http://www.artinasia.com/institutionsDetail.php?catID=9999&galleryID=1224&view=7&eventID=2104 Emergency Room Hanoi], ''artinasia.com'', October 2009. The Emergency Room format involves a system which is taught to the participating artists by Emergency Room staff. The system requires the artwork of the previous day to be removed daily (normally around 12.30 p.m.) and replaced by fresh artworks. Geoffroy calls this central element of the process "The Passage". The number of artists turning up for the Passage will vary, sometimes with nobody showing up. Other days the news of the day will stimulate responses from the artists and participation in the Passage increases. Emergency Room can be combined with the 'Delay Museum', a nearby exhibition space where yesterday’s artwork is archived and shown. This museum is no longer contemporary in the sense of the word used by Emergency Room. This delay of opinions and reactions are preserved. Geoffroy describes this as a critical way of thinking about contemporary art, with The Delay Museum becoming a place for studying the aesthetics of the fast moving 'emergency'. It is recorded externally by media coverage and internally usingf blogs, webcasting and artist interviews by the Emergency Room staff. Geoffroy describes the Emergency Room as a format where artists can "train their awareness muscle", encouraging experimentation and artistic daring.{{cite web|title=Q&A: Alternatives – Thierry Geoffroy|url=http://culturaldevelopmentconsulting.com/2013/03/16/7522/|website=Cultural Development Consultation|accessdate=12 October 2015}} == Contributing artists 2006 - present == The Emergency Room events involve large numbers of local and overseas artists. By November 2008 over 150 artists had been involved in the format in a number of locations internationally.{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Cyril|title=Le remède à la morosité : EMERGENCY ROOM (in French)|url=http://www.artnet.fr/magazine/portraits/thomas/emergency%20room.asp|accessdate=2013-04-25|newspaper=ArtNet.fr|date=13 November 2008}} The format has been activated in: * [[MoMA PS1]], [[New York City]] (2007)[http://ps1.org/exhibitions/view/130 Emergency Room], MOMA PS1. involving 30 artists, changing the entire display at 12.30pm each day.{{cite news|last=Dewille|first=James|title=Live From N.Y., It's Yesterday's News|url=http://www.columbiaspectator.com/2007/02/21/live-ny-its-yesterdays-news|accessdate=2013-04-25|newspaper=Columbia Daily Spectator|date=21 February 2007}} * University of Fine Arts, [[Hanoi]], [[Vietnam]] (2009) involving 25 local and overseas artists.{{cite news|title=Experimental exhibition opens in Hanoi |url=http://hanoitimes.com.vn/newsdetail.asp?NewsId=12894&CatId=12 |accessdate=2013-04-25 |newspaper=Hanoi Times |date=3 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004143817/http://www.hanoitimes.com.vn/newsdetail.asp?NewsId=12894&CatId=12 |archivedate=2011-10-04 |df= }} The event coincided with a Danish State visit to Hanoi in November 2009.[http://www.e-flux.com/shows/view/7369 "At Vietnam University of Fine Arts"], E-flux, 1 November 2009. * European Culture Congress, Wroclav (2011), involving 18 artists.[http://www.culturecongress.eu/en/event/format_emergency_room Emergency Room], European Culture Congress 2011. * Naples : PAN - Palazzo delle Arti Napoli (2009)[http://www.comune.napoli.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeBLOB.php/L/IT/IDPagina/9193 Emergency Room Napoli di Thierry Geoffroy/Colonel] (in Italian), Comune di Napoli. * Athens : Ileana Tounta Contemporary Art Center (2007)[http://www.art-tounta.gr/files/exhibitions/2007/2007-09emergency-press.html Emergency Room (press briefing)], Ileana Tounta Centre for Contemporary Art. * Paris : Galerie Taiss (2008). * Berlin : Galerie Olaf Stueber (2006) . * Copenhagen : Kunsthallen Nikolaj ( 2006). ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fIjrlUrLOkU Format Emergency Room at MOMA / PS1 New York. Report from ABC News 2007] * [http://www.revolver-books.de/w3NoM.php?nodeId=1084 Emergency Room Dictionary, published by Revolver Publishing] * [http://www.kunstakademiet.dk/more.php?id=923_0_2_0_M28 "THIERRY GEOFFROY / AKA COLONEL: EMERGENCY ROOM DICTIONARY" by The Royal Danish Academy of Arts] * [https://www.reuters.com/news/video?videoId=14672 Format Emergency Room at MOMA / PS1 New York. Report from Reuters 2007 The art of news ] * [http://www.wnyc.org/shows/bl/2007/mar/06/ The Brian Lehrer Show "Where art and Journalism Collide" (mp3, WNYC) PS1/MoMA, New York, 2007] * [http://www.artslant.com/par/articles/show/2829 Format Emergency Room in Paris / Emergency Case. By Natalie Hegert, 2008 ] * [http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x7izsy_emergency-room-galerie-taiss-paris_creation Emergency Room - Galerie Taiss - Paris] * [http://www.kopenhagen.dk/interviews/interviews/interviews_2008/interview_med_colonel/ Interview with Colonel on Kopenhagen.dk 2008] * [http://Format%20Emergency%20Room%20Hanoi%20on%20Kunsten.nu.%2026.%20Nov.%202009 http://www.kunsten.nu/artikler/artikel.php?thierry+Geoffroy+emergency+room] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0rNt4EiuuY Format Emergency Room Hanoi from 36pho TV news ] [[Category:Contemporary works of art]] [[Category:Performances]] [[Category:Danish contemporary art]]

{{infobox military person | honorific_prefix = Doctor | name = Frederick C. Bock | birth_date = {{Birth date|1918|1|18}} | birth_place = [[Greenville, Michigan]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2000|8|25|1918|1|18}} | death_place = [[Scottsdale, Arizona]] | allegiance = United States of America | branch = Army Air Force | rank = Major | unit = 509th Composite Group | battles = Second World War | awards = [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United States)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], [[Air Medal]] | spouse = Helen Lossman Bock | laterwork = Research Scientist }} [[File:Atomic cloud over Nagasaki from Koyagi-jima.jpeg|thumb|288x288px|Cloud over Nagasaki following the atomic blast]] '''Frederick C. Bock''' (January 18, 1918 – August 25, 2000) was a [[World War II]] pilot who took part in the atomic bombing of [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]] in 1945.
Bock attended the [[University of Chicago]] and went on to enroll in a graduate course in [[philosophy]].<ref name=":0" />
Upon the entry of the United States into the [[World War II|Second World War]] Bock enlisted in the [[United States Army Air Forces|Army Air Force]], becoming a pilot.<ref name=":0" />
Bock flew missions from [[India]] to [[China]] over the [[Himalayas]], a route known as [[the hump]]. He also participated in air raids on [[Japan]] flown from China.<ref name=":0" />
== Nagasaki Atomic Bomb Raid == {{See also|Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki}} On the Nagasaki Raid Bock flew the [[B-29 Superfortress|B-29]] bomber ''[[The Great Artiste]]'', which was used for scientific measurements and [[photography]] of the effects caused by the nuclear weapon.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/29/us/f-c-bock-82-monitor-of-nagasaki-bombing.html|title=F. C. Bock, 82, Monitor of Nagasaki Bombing|last=Saxon|first=Wolfgang|date=2000-08-29|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-04-28|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
A civilian observer was aboard ''The Great Artiste'' named [[William L. Laurence]] who was a science writer with the ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]].'' His account of the mission was to be awarded the 1946 [[Pulitzer Prize]].<ref name=":0" />
In his subsequent book ''Dawn Over Zero'' (Knopf 1946), Laurence describes the scene aboard the B-29;<ref name=":0" />
{{Quote|text=''I watched Capt. Frederick C. Bock, the pilot of our ship, go through the intricate motions of lifting a B-29 off the ground and marveled at the quiet efficiency of this Michigan boy who had majored in philosophy at Chicago University... I talked to him on the ground and I was amazed at the transformation that had taken place. Man and machine had become one, a modern centaur.''|sign=William L. Laurence|source=Dawn Over Zero (1946)}}
The bomber which actually dropped [[Fat Man]] was called ''[[Bockscar]]''<ref>[http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=2546 USAF Museum - Bockscar Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117185238/http://www.nationalmuseum.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=2546 |date=2007-11-17 }} Fact Sheet</ref> as it was usually flown by Frederick Bock. The staff was swapped just before the raid and Major [[Charles Sweeney]] piloted ''Bockscar'', which flew with ''The Great Artiste'' and another aircraft.
== Post War Career ==
After the war Bock returned to [[Chicago]] where he earned his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in [[zoology]] with a specialisation in mathematical statistics and [[genetics]].<ref name=":0" />
Working in Chicago based [[Research|research laboratories]] Dr. Bock created [[algorithm]]s for solving complex problems.<ref name=":0" />
Dr. Bock retired in 1986 from [[Baxter International|Baxter Travenol]] Laboratories. It was there he devised a mathematical model for [[peritoneal dialysis]].<ref name=":0" />
A native of [[Greenville, Michigan]], Bock died at his [[Arizona]] home in 2000, of cancer.<ref>http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-08-30/news/0008300191_1_mr-bock-great-artiste-nagasaki</ref>
