{{For|the US invasion of the similarly named Caribbean island|Invasion of Grenada}} {{Infobox military conflict |image=La Rendición de Granada - Pradilla.jpg |image_size=300px |partof=the [[Reconquista]] |caption=''The [[Capitulation of Granada]]'' by F. Pradilla: [[Muhammad XII of Granada|Muhammad XII]] (Boabdil) surrenders to Ferdinand and Isabella. |conflict=Granada War |date= February 1482 – January 2, 1492 |place=[[Geography of Spain|Southeastern Iberia]] |result=Granada annexed by Castile |combatant1= [[File:Coat of Arms of Queen Isabella of Castile (1492-1504).svg|18px]] [[Catholic Monarchs|Castile-Aragon Union]] |combatant2= [[File:Royal Standard of Nasrid Dynasty Kingdom of Grenade.svg|24px]] [[Emirate of Granada]] |commander1= [[File:Royal_Banner_of_Arag%C3%B3n.svg|22px]] [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]]
[[File:Banner of arms crown of Castille Habsbourg style.svg|22px|border]] [[Isabella I of Castile]] |commander2= [[File:Royal Standard of Nasrid Dynasty Kingdom of Grenade.svg|24px]] [[Abu l-Hasan Ali, Sultan of Granada|Abu l-Hasan Ali]] (Muley Hacén), 1481–1485
[[File:Royal Standard of Nasrid Dynasty Kingdom of Grenade.svg|24px]] [[Muhammed XIII, Sultan of Granada|Muhammed XIII]] (al-Zagal), 1485–1487
[[File:Royal Standard of Nasrid Dynasty Kingdom of Grenade.svg|24px]] [[Muhammad XII of Granada|Muhammad XII]] (Boabdil), 1487–1492 {{POW}} }} {{Campaignbox Reconquista}} {{History of Spain}} The '''Granada War''' ({{lang-es|Guerra de Granada}}) was a series of military campaigns between 1482 and 1491, during the reign of the [[Catholic Monarchs]] (''los Reyes Católicos'') [[Isabella I of Castile]] and [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]], against the [[Nasrid dynasty]]'s [[Emirate of Granada]]. It ended with the defeat of Granada and its annexation by Castile, ending all Islamic rule on the Iberian peninsula ([[al-Andalus]]). The ten-year war was not a continuous effort but a series of seasonal campaigns launched in spring and broken off in winter. The Granadans were crippled by internal conflict and civil war, while the Christians were generally unified. The Granadans were also bled economically by Castile, with the tribute (Spanish: ''paria'') they had to pay to avoid being attacked and conquered. The war also saw the effective use of artillery by the Christians to rapidly conquer towns that would otherwise have required a long siege. On January 2, 1492, [[Muhammad XII of Granada]] (King Boabdil) surrendered the Emirate of Granada, the city of [[Granada]], and the [[Alhambra]] palace to the Castilian forces. The war was a joint project between Isabella's [[Crown of Castile]] and Ferdinand's [[Crown of Aragon]]. The bulk of the troops and funds for the war came from Castile, and Granada was annexed into Castile's lands. The Crown of Aragon was less important: apart from the presence of King Ferdinand himself, Aragon provided naval collaboration, guns, and some financial loans. Aristocrats were offered the allure of new lands, while Ferdinand and Isabella centralized and consolidated power. The aftermath of the war ended ''convivencia'' ("live and let live") between religions In the Iberian peninsula: the Jews [[Alhambra Decree|were forced to convert to Christianity or be exiled]] in 1492, and by 1501, all of Granada's Muslims were [[Forced conversions of Muslims in Spain|obliged to convert to Christianity]], become slaves, or be exiled; by 1526 this prohibition spread to the rest of Spain. "New Christians" (''[[conversos]]'') came to be accused of [[crypto-Islam]] and [[crypto-Judaism]].{{cite book |last=Harvey |first=L. P. |year=2005 |title=Muslims in Spain, 1500 to 1614 |publisher=University Of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-226-31963-6 }} Spain would go on to model its national aspirations as the guardian of Christianity and Catholicism. The fall of the Alhambra is still celebrated every year by the City Council of Granada, and the Granada War is considered in traditional Spanish historiography as the final war of the [[Reconquista]]. At the same time, and uniquely in the "Reconquista", the Granada War is not called "the reconquest of Granada" but rather "the conquest of Granada". Granada in its current form had not been Christian before the Reconquista;Daniel Eisenberg, "No hubo una Edad 'Media' española", ''Propuestas teorico-metodológicas para el estudio de la literatura hispanica medieval'', ed. Lillian van der Walde, Mexico City: Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México-Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana, 2003, pp. 511-520, {{ISBN|9703207774}}, https://web.archive.org/web/20160312023250/http://users.ipfw.edu/jehle/deisenbe/other_hispanic_topics/nohuboun.htm, retrieved March 23, 2003. however the corresponding region was held by the Christian [[Visigothic Kingdom]] prior to the 8th century [[Umayyad conquest of Hispania]]. ==Iberia and Al-Andalus in the late 15th century== {{See also|Reconquista}} The [[Emirate of Granada]] had been the last Muslim state in Iberia for more than two centuries by the time of the Granada War. The other remnant [[al-Andalus]] states (the ''[[taifa]]s'') of the once powerful [[Caliphate of Córdoba]] had long been conquered by the Christians. Pessimism for Granada's future existed before its ultimate fall; in 1400, [[Ibn Hudayl]] wrote "Is [[Granada]] not enclosed between a violent sea and an enemy terrible in arms, both of which press on its people day and night?"Hillgarth, p. 367. Still, Granada was wealthy and powerful, and the Christian kingdoms were divided and fought amongst themselves. Granada's problems began to worsen after [[Yusuf III, Sultan of Granada|Emir Yusuf III]]'s death in 1417. Succession struggles ensured that Granada was in an almost constant low-level civil war. Clan loyalties were stronger than allegiance to the [[Emir]], making consolidation of power difficult. Often, the only territory the Emir really controlled was the [[Granada|city of Granada]]. At times, the emir did not even control all the city, but rather one rival emir would control the [[Alhambra]], and another the [[Albayzín]], the most important district of Granada.Hillgarth, p. 368. This internal fighting greatly weakened the state. The economy declined, with Granada's once world-famous porcelain manufacture disrupted and challenged by the Christian town of [[Manises]] near Valencia, in Aragon. Despite the weakening economy, taxes were still imposed at their earlier high rates to support Granada's extensive defenses and large army. Ordinary Granadans paid triple the taxes of (non-tax-exempt) Castilians. The heavy taxes that Emir [[Abu-l-Hasan Ali]] imposed contributed greatly to his unpopularity. These taxes did at least support a respected army; Hasan was successful in putting down Christian revolts in his lands, and some observers estimated he could muster as many as 7,000 horsemen.Hillgarth, p. 369. The frontier between Granada and the Castilian lands of Andalusia was in a constant state of flux, "neither in peace nor in war." Raids across the border were common, as were intermixing alliances between local nobles on both sides of the frontier. Relations were governed by occasional truces and demands for tribute should one side have been seen to overstep their bounds. Neither country's central government intervened or controlled the warfare much. [[Henry IV of Castile|King Henry IV of Castile]] died in December 1474, setting off the [[War of the Castilian Succession]] between Henry's daughter [[Joanna la Beltraneja]] and Henry's half-sister [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabella]]. The war raged from 1475–1479, setting Isabella's supporters and the [[Crown of Aragon]] against Joanna's supporters, [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portugal]], and [[Ancien Regime in France|France]]. During this time, the frontier with Granada was practically ignored; the Castilians did not even bother to ask for or obtain reparation for a raid in 1477. Truces were agreed upon in 1475, 1476, and 1478. In 1479, the Succession War concluded with Isabella victorious. As Isabella had married [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand of Aragon]] in 1469, this meant that the two powerful kingdoms of Castile and Aragon would stand united, free from inter-Christian war which had helped Granada survive.Hillgarth, p. 370. {{Multiple image |align=center |direction=horizontal |header=Maps of the Iberian peninsula and Granada in the 14th–15th centuries |footer= |width1=399 |image1=CastillaLeon 1360.png |alt1=The five kingdoms of Iberia in 1360. The territory of the Emirate of Granada was reduced by 1482, as it lost its grasp on [[Gibraltar]] and other western territories. |caption1=The five kingdoms of Iberia in 1360. The territory of the Emirate of Granada was reduced by 1482, as it lost its grasp on [[Gibraltar]] and other western territories. |width2=600 |image2=Reino Nazarí de Granada.png |alt2=Territory of the [[Nasrid dynasty]] during the 15th century. In light green are territories conquered by the Christian kings during the 13th century, including [[Ceuta]] on the African coast. |caption2=Territory of the [[Nasrid dynasty]] during the 15th century. In light green are territories conquered by the Christian kings during the 13th century, including [[Ceuta]] on the African coast. }} ==Chronology== ===Provocations and responses=== [[Image:IsabellaofCastile03.jpg|thumb|right|Queen Isabella's marriage with Ferdinand of Aragon ensured a united front of Castile and Aragon against Granada.]] The truce of 1478 was still theoretically in effect when Granada launched a surprise attack against [[Zahara de la Sierra|Zahara]] in December 1481, as part of a reprisal for a Christian raid. The town fell, and the population was enslaved. This attack proved to be a great provocation, and factions in favor of war in Andalusia used it to rally support for a counterstrike, quickly moving to take credit for it, and backed a wider war. The seizure of [[Alhama de Granada|Alhama]] and its subsequent royal endorsement is usually said to be the formal beginning of the Granada War. Abu Hasan attempted to retake Alhama by siege in March but was unsuccessful. Reinforcements from the rest of Castile and Aragon averted the possibility of retaking Alhama in April 1482; King Ferdinand formally took command at Alhama on May 14, 1482. The Christians next tried to besiege [[Loja, Granada|Loja]] but failed to take the town. This setback was balanced by a twist that would prove to aid them greatly: on the same day that Loja was relieved, Abu Hasan's son, Abu Abdallah or Boabdil, rebelled and styled himself [[Muhammad XII of Granada|Emir Muhammad XII]].Hillgarth, p. 381. The war continued into 1483. Abu Hasan's brother, al-Zagal, defeated a large Christian raiding force in the hills of the [[Axarquia]] east of [[Málaga]]. However, at [[Lucena, Córdoba|Lucena]] the Christians were able to defeat and capture King Boabdil. Ferdinand and Isabella had previously not been intent on conquering all of Granada. With the capture of King Boabdil, however, Ferdinand decided to use him to conquer Granada entirely. In a letter written in August 1483, Ferdinand wrote "To put Granada in division and destroy it We have decided to free him.... He [Boabdil] has to make war on his father." With Boabdil's release as a pseudo-Christian ally, the Granadan civil war continued. A Granadan chronicler commented that Boabdil's capture was "the cause of the fatherland's destruction." In 1485, the fortunes of the Granadan internal conflict shifted yet again. Boabdil was expelled from the Albayzín, his base of power, by Hasan's brother al-Zagal. Al-Zagal also took command of the nation, dethroning his aging brother, who died shortly thereafter.Hillgarth, p. 382. Boabdil was obliged to flee to Ferdinand and Isabella's protection. The continuing division within the Muslim ranks and the cunning of the Marquis of Cádiz allowed the western reaches of Granada to be seized with unusual speed in 1485. [[Ronda]] fell to him after fifteen days, thanks to his negotiations with the city's leaders. Ronda's fall allowed [[Marbella]], a base of the Granadan fleet, to come into Christian hands next. Boabdil was soon released from Christian protection to resume his bid for control of Granada. For the next three years, he acted as one of Ferdinand and Isabella's vassals. He offered the promise of limited independence for Granada and peace with the Christians to the citizenry; from the Catholic Monarchs, he extracted the title of Duke for whatever cities he could control.Hillgarth, p. 383–384. ===Siege of Málaga=== {{main|Siege of Málaga (1487)}} Málaga, the chief seaport of Granada, was the main objective of the Castilian forces in 1487. Emir al-Zagal was slow to march to attempt to relieve the siege and was unable to harass the Christian armies safely because of the ongoing civil war; even after he left the city to come to the aid of Málaga, he was forced to leave troops in the Alhambra to defend against Boabdil and his followers. The first main city to be attacked, [[Vélez-Málaga]], capitulated on 27 April 1487, with local supporters of Boabdil directly aiding the Christian besiegers. Málaga held out during an extended siege that lasted from 7 May 1487 until 18 August 1487; its commander preferred death to surrender, and the African garrison and Christian renegades (converts to Islam) fought tenaciously, fearing the consequences of defeat. Near the end, the notables of Málaga finally offered a surrender, but Ferdindad refused, as generous terms had already been offered twice.Prescott, p. 207. When the city finally fell, Ferdinand punished almost all the inhabitants for their stubborn resistance with slavery, while renegades were burned alive or pierced by reeds. The Jews of Malaga, however, were spared, as Castilian Jews ransomed them from slavery. Historian William Prescott considered the fall of Málaga the most important part of the war; as the chief port of Granada, Granada could not reasonably continue on as an independent state without it.Prescott, p. 211. ===Siege of Baza=== Al-Zagal lost prestige from the fall of Málaga, and Boabdil took over all of the city of Granada in 1487; he additionally controlled the northeast of the country with [[Vélez-Rubio]], [[Vélez-Blanco]], and Vera. Al-Zagal still controlled Baza, Guadix, and Almería. Boabdil took no action as the Christian forces took some of his land, perhaps assuming it would shortly be returned to him. In 1489, the Christian forces began a painfully long siege of [[Baza, Granada|Baza]], the most important stronghold remaining to al-Zagal. Baza was highly defensible as it required the Christians to split their armies, and artillery was of little use against it. Supplying the army caused a huge budget shortfall for the Castilians. Occasional threats of deprivation of office were necessary to keep the army in the field, and Isabella came personally to the siege to help maintain the morale of both the nobles and the soldiers. After six months, al-Zagal surrendered, despite his garrison still being largely unharmed; he had become convinced that the Christians were serious about maintaining the siege as long as it would take, and further resistance was useless without the hope of relief, of which there was no sign.Prescott, p. 224. Baza was granted generous surrender terms, unlike Málaga. ===Last stand at Granada=== [[Image:Alhambradesdegeneralife.jpg|250px|thumb|left|The [[Alhambra]].]] With the fall of Baza and the capture of al-Zagal in 1490, it seemed as if the war was over; Ferdinand and Isabella believed this was the case. However, Boabdil was unhappy with the rewards for his alliance with Ferdinand and Isabella, possibly because lands that had been promised to him were being administered by Castile. He broke off his vassalage and rebelled against the Catholic Monarchs, despite holding only the city of Granada and the [[Alpujarras]] Mountains.Hillgarth, p. 385. It was clear that such a position was untenable in the long term, so Boabdil sent out desperate requests for external aid. The [[Sultan of Egypt]] mildly rebuked Ferdinand for the Granada War, but the [[Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)|Mamluks]] that ruled Egypt were in a near constant war with the [[Ottoman Turks]]. As Castile and Aragon were fellow enemies of the Turks, the Sultan had no desire to break their alliance against the Turks. Boabdil also requested aid from the [[Kingdom of Fez]] (modern [[Morocco]]), but no reply is recorded by history.Hillgarth, p. 386. North Africa continued to sell Castile wheat throughout the war and valued maintaining good trade relations. In any case, the Granadans no longer controlled any coastline from where to receive overseas aid. No help would be forthcoming for Granada. [[File:Salida de la familia de Boabdil de la Alhambra.jpg|thumb|300px|Painting depicting Muhammad XII's family in the [[Alhambra]] moments after the fall of Granada]] An eight-month siege of Granada began in April 1491. The situation for the defenders grew progressively dire, as their forces for interfering with the siege dwindled and advisers schemed against each other. Bribery of important officials was rampant, and at least one of the chief advisers to Boabdil seems to have been working for Castile the entire time. After the Battle of Granada a provisional surrender, the [[Treaty of Granada (1491)|Treaty of Granada]], was signed on November 25, 1491, which granted two months to the city.{{cite book|last=Prescott|first=William Hickling|editor=Munro, Wilford Harold|title=History of the reign of Ferdinand and Isabella, the Catholic|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bAZpAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA242|accessdate=23 November 2015|volume=II|year=1904|publisher=J. B. Lippincott Company|page=242}} The reason for the long delay was not so much intransigence on either side, but rather the inability of the Granadan government to coordinate amongst itself in the midst of the disorder and tumult that gripped the city. After the terms, which proved rather generous to the Muslims, were negotiated, the city capitulated on January 2, 1492. The besieging Christians sneaked troops into the Alhambra that day in case resistance materialized, which it did not.Hillgarth, p. 373. Granada's resistance had come to its end. ==Tactics and technology== {{See also|Medieval warfare|Early Modern warfare}} The most notable facet of the Granada War was the power of [[Bombard (weapon)|bombards]] and [[cannon]]s to greatly shorten the many [[siege]]s of the war.Hillgarth, p. 376. The Castilians and Aragonese started the war with only a few artillery pieces, but Ferdinand had access to French and Burgundian experts from his recent wars, and the Christians aggressively increased their artillery forces.Prescott, p. 30. The Muslims, however, lagged far behind in their use of artillery, generally only using the occasional captured Christian piece.Prescott, p. 29. The historian Weston F. Cook Jr. wrote "Gunpowder firepower and artillery siege operations won the Granadan war, and other factors in the Spanish victory were actually secondary and derivative."Prescott, p. 27. By 1495, Castile and Aragon controlled 179 pieces of artillery total, a vast increase from the paltry numbers seen in the War of the Castilian Succession.Hillgarth, p. 377. Primitive [[arquebus]]es also saw use in the war, though only to a small degree. Heavy cavalry knights were a much smaller factor in the Granada War than seen in earlier warfare.Prescott, p. 18. Light cavalry [[jinete]]s took on a more prominent role instead. The open-field battles in which cavalry were the most important were rare; the Granadans, badly outnumbered, generally avoided such battles.Hillgarth, p. 374. The Castilians also employed a large number of supporting men; a huge force of workers were mustered in 1483 to destroy crops and pillage the countryside rather than engage directly in battle. Coordination and logistics was difficult given the mountainous terrain, but the Christians diligently built a series of roads through the mountains to deliver food and supplies to their troops. Politically, many nobles insisted on controlling their own forces, but Ferdinand and Isabella were still able to exercise a large degree of control in directing the army as a whole. The Granadans, meanwhile, were beset with civil war, preventing the establishment of a unified command. The Christian army was almost completely Castilian; Aragonese and foreign mercenary participation was minimal.Hillgarth, p. 378. Of the Castilian army, Andalusia contributed far more troops than the other territories, with much of its population conscripted into the war. The nobility provided the majority of the expensive cavalry. ==Strength of the armies involved== Concerning the real strength of the armies involved, according to original sources the Castilian armies reached between 50,000 and 70,000 soldiers the years of the greatest military effort (1482, 83, 86, 87, 89 and 91), or 10,000 to 29,000 in the quieter ones (1484, 85, 88 and 90), strength which is accepted by modern scholars as Ladero Quesada.Ladero, Granada, p. 100 and 108, and Irving. Nevertheless, according to García de Gabiola, to keep, pay and feed armies of such strength were beyond the resources of the recently birthed modern states. For the campaigns in Italy (1494–1503) the Spanish armies were of 5,000, 9,000 or 15,000 men maximum, so it is rather surprising the numbers recorded 5–10 years before for Granada. If we take into account the revenues of Castile during the period (130 to some 200 millions of maravedies per year) it is hardly difficult that Castile could have organized more than 8,000 to 20,000 soldiers.Amounts calculated by García de Gabiola, p. 63, from revenues registered by Ladero, Granada, p. 121-127, and Ladero, Hermandad, p. 52-58, 67. In fact, Ladero Quesada register the number of grain loads contracted by Castile in several years and García de Gabiola has calculated the number of soldiers that could have been fed through these grain loads, and his conclusions are 12,000 men for 1482 (siege of Loja); 8,000 men for 1483 and 1484 (Granada fields sacking); 10,000 men in 1485 (Ronda siege); 10–12,000 soldiers in 1486 (2nd Loja siege); 12,000 for 1487 (Malaga siege); 10–12,000 in 1488 (1st Baza siege); 20,000 soldiers in 1489 (2nd Baza siege, the greatest grain loads contracted, that also coincides with the largest revenue of Castile during the campaign, some 200 millions); and 10–12,000 men for 1490–91 (final siege of Granada). A 20% of them should be cavalry.Amounts calculated by García de Gabiola, pp. 63–69, from grain loads registered by Ladero Quesada. In relation to Muslim armies, according to García de Gabiola,García de Gabiola, pp. 63–64. the strengths mentioned by the sources (15,000 to 50,000 infantry, or 4,500–7,000 cavalry) should also be discarded. More plausible strengths mentuioned are the 3,000 horses (1482), 1,000 to 1,500 (1483, 1485 and 1487) or even 3-400 riders (1489 and 1491). Concerning the infantry, De Miguel Mora states that a Muslim soldier captured by the Castilians during the siege of Baza confessed that the real infantry strength of the garrison was 4,000 men and not 15,000.De Miguel Mora, p. 12 and 16. So, the Muslim armies could not exceed some 4,000 infantry. At the end of the war the ratio was 2 or 3-to-1 in favor of the Castilian armies. The Granada War would prove to be valuable training for the [[Italian Wars]], where the Castilian armies and tactics such as the ''[[tercio]]'' would acquit themselves well.Prescott, p. 16. ==Consequences== [[File:Capitulação de Granada - Vicente Barneto y Vazquez.png|thumb|left|The Surrender of Granada, by Vicente Barneto y Vazquez]] The surrender of Granada was seen as a great blow to Islam and a triumph of Christianity. Other Christian states offered their sincere congratulations to Ferdinand and Isabella, while Islamic writers reacted with despair. In Castile and Aragon, celebrations and bullfights were held. People rejoiced in the streets.Hillgarth, p. 388. The treaty's terms for Granada's surrender were quite generous to the Muslims, considering how little they had left to bargain with.Hillgarth, p. 387. They were similar to the terms offered to towns which surrendered earlier, when the outcome of the war was in doubt. For three years, Muslims could emigrate and return freely. They were allowed to keep weapons, though not firearms, a provision that however was to be annulled a month later. No one would be forced to change religion, not even former Christians who had converted to Islam. Boabdil was offered money and the rulership of a small principality in the mountainous [[Alpujarras]], an area that would have been difficult to control in any case. At first, most of conquered Granada was treated respectfully and was therefore predominantly stable for seven years, though the [[Alhambra Decree]] of 1492 expelled the Jews that were not [[converso]] [[Marrano]]s. King Boabdil soon found his position intolerable. He left for Morocco in October 1493, where he would die some forty years later.Hillgarth, p. 390. Eventually, Castile started to revoke some of the more tolerant attributes of the treaty. This initiative was led by [[Francisco Jiménez de Cisneros|Archbishop Cisneros]], who ordered mass conversions, the burning of valuable Arabic manuscripts and other measures detrimental to the Muslims (and Jews). This sparked [[Rebellion of the Alpujarras (1499–1501)|a revolt]] that ended in many Muslims being forced to choose between baptism, exile, or execution. Tensions from then onward would remain high, and Castile was obliged to maintain a large military force in Granada to deter future revolts. Isabella also strengthened the [[Spanish Inquisition]], and Ferdinand brought the Inquisition to Aragon where previously it had not held power. Castile was the main beneficiary of the war, as it had also spent by far the majority of the money and manpower to prosecute it, and completely annexed Granada. The conquest of Granada meant little for Aragon's strategic position, but it did help secure Castilian support in Italy and France, where Aragon's interests lay.Hillgarth, p. 393. Increasing oppression of the Moors—now known as [[Moriscos]] or "New Christians"—led to the [[Rebellion of the Alpujarras (1568–71)]]. After the defeat of the Moors, which was not easy, almost all the Moriscos of the former Kingdom of Granada were exiled to other parts of Spain. ==Cultural influence== An entire genre, ''romances fronterizos'', developed around stories of the war and the battles on the Granadan frontier which reached their culmination in Granada's fall. [[Ginés Pérez de Hita]] wrote an early example of [[historical fiction]], ''Guerras civiles de Granada'', a romantic account of the war that emphasized chivalry and heroism on both sides. A number of stories and songs appear to have been sponsored by the royal government to help steel morale for the long struggle; ''Sobre Baza'' was a poem written in 1479 encouraging persistence in the long siege. The song "''Setenil, ay Setenil''", written in 1484, hoped that Ferdinand would conquer "as far as Jerusalem."Hillgarth, p. 371. The song "''Una sañosa porfía''" by [[Juan del Encina]] puts the depiction of the war in the lips of King Boabdil himself. English playwright [[John Dryden]] wrote a [[heroic drama]] ''[[The Conquest of Granada]]'', published in 1672, which focuses on a romantic love triangle and clashing loyalties in two feuding Granadan factions, leaving the besieging Castilians in the background. The [[Día de la Toma de Granada]] is a civic and religious festival held each year in Granada on the anniversary of the city's conquest, January 2. ==See also== * [[Timeline of the Muslim presence in the Iberian Peninsula#Castile-Arag.C3.B3n conquers the kingdom of Granada .281481.E2.80.931491.29|Timeline of the Muslim presence in the Iberian peninsula § Castile-Aragón conquers the kingdom of Granada (1481–1491)]] * [[Islam in Spain]] * [[Morisco revolt|Morisco Rebellions in Granada]] * [[Border of Granada]] ==References== * This article incorporates text translated from the [[Spanish Wikipedia]] article [[:es:Guerra de Granada|''Guerra de Granada'']], licensed under {{srlink|Wikipedia:Text of Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License|Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike (cc-by-sa)}}. {{Reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * Benito Ruano, Eloy. {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = | name = John F. Colburn | honorific-suffix = | image = John F. Colburn.jpg | image_upright = .91 | caption = | office = [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]
[[Ministry of the Interior (Hawaii)|Minister of the Interior]] | term = | term_start = January 13, 1893 | term_end = January 17, 1893 | monarch = [[Liliuokalani]] | predecessor = [[George Norton Wilcox]] | successor = [[James A. King]] | birth_date = {{Birth date|1859|9|30}} | birth_place = [[Honolulu]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1920|3|16|1859|9|30}} | death_place = [[Honolulu]], [[Territory of Hawaii]] | restingplace = [[Oahu Cemetery]] | nationality = [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]
United States | alma_mater = | occupation = | spouse = | relations = | children = | residence = }} '''John Francis Colburn''' (September 30, 1859 – March 16, 1920) was a businessman and politician of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. He served as the last [[Ministry of the Interior (Hawaii)|Minister of the Interior]] of Queen [[Liliuokalani]]. Even though he was part Hawaiian ancestry on his maternal side, Colburn was a key figure in the [[overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy]] and was a proponent of annexation to the United States. Colburn was the treasurer of the estate of [[Queen Kapiolani]]. ==Early life== He was born in [[Honolulu]], the youngest of three children of auctioneer and local fire warden John F. Colburn{{cite news|last1=|title=A New Auctioneer|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1854-01-21/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Polynesian.|date=January 21, 1854|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} and Elizabeth Maughan, descended from Don [[Francisco de Paula Marín]] and one of his Hawaiian wives. The elder Colburn was a naturalized citizen of Hawaii who could trace his family back to the [[Siege of Boston]] at the 1775 [[Battle of Bunker Hill]]; when he died in 1861, the younger Colburn was only two years old.{{cite news|last1=|title=Another Citizen Gone|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1861-12-12/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=December 12, 1861|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Elizabeth Maughan died May 22, 1889.{{cite news|last1=|title=Died|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1889-05-23/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=May 23, 1889|location= Honolulu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} == Political career == Early in 1892, Colburn ran for a position on the Road Board, and came in ninth in a field of thirteen candidates.{{cite news|last1=|title=Here's Another Lone Independent Candidate for Member of the Road Board: John F. Colburn|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-01-15/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=January 15, 1892|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Road Board|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-02-04/ed-1/seq-3//|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=February 4, 1892|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Soon afterwards, however, Queen [[Liliuokalani]] appointed him to the Board of Health.{{cite news|last1=|title=By Authority|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-02-08/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=February 8, 1892|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} On January 13, 1893, she appointed him to the Ministry of the Interior to the final Parker Cabinet with [[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]], [[William H. Cornwell]] and [[Arthur P. Peterson]], after her previous cabinet was voted out by the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|legislature of the kingdom]].{{cite web |url=http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/import/import/Government%20Office%20Holders%20-%20Name%20IMJ/C/Colburn,%20John%20F.jpg |title=Colburn, John F. office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate=June 17, 2014 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}; {{cite news|title=A New Cabinet – Some New Ministers for the Public to Swallow|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 14, 1893|volume=XVII|issue=3277|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-01-14/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 12, 2016}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=The New Ministry|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1893-01-13/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=January 13, 1893|location=Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{harvnb|Forbes|2003|pp=476–479}} She had chosen these men specifically to support her plan of promulgating a new constitution while the legislature was not in session.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=581–583}} Publisher and philanthropist [[Thurston Twigg-Smith]], the grandson of annexation leader [[Lorrin A. Thurston]], made the case that Colburn was part of a royal inner [[cabal]] of the queen's own cabinet ministers who worked to oust the monarchy.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=61}} She attempted to promulgate a [[Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|new constitution]],{{refn|group=FN| Historian Ralph S. Kuykendall noted in 1961 that most Hawaiians were supportive of a strong monarchy, and resented the [[Bayonet Constitution]] they felt had been forced upon King [[Kalākaua]]. When Liliuokalani was elected upon his death, her ability to govern was limited by a fractured legislature and the terms of the Bayonet Constitution. Her proposed new constitution was similar to the 1864 constitution in effect prior to the forced Bayonet Constitution. {{harvnb|Kuykendall|Day|1961|pp=171–177}}; Thurston Twigg-Smith was strongly opposed to Hawaiian Sovereignty. His perspective of the queen's proposed new constitution was that it would weaken the power of the legislature and be a move back to an absolute monarchy. {{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|pp=xv, 10}}}} but Colburn and the rest of the cabinet were either opposed to or reluctant to sign the new constitution. Their opposition was one of the causes which ultimately led to her [[Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii|overthrow]].{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|pp=64–67, 95–97}} The [[Committee of Safety (Hawaii)|Committee of Safety]] was being formed on January 14 and was in the process of drawing up a petition for 700–800 gathered opposition participants, when Colburn and Peterson arrived, joined at some point by Cornwell and Parker. Speaking before the large crowd, Colburn revealed the details of a meeting the ministers had just had with the queen to discuss the proposed constitution, rousing the crowd to prepare for action. After an hours-long meeting to digest the information presented by Colburn, the Committee of Safety headed by Thurston joined with the ministers in defying the plans for a new constitution, believing there was no alternative but to remove her from power. The cabinet ministers were all present during the overnight session and fully briefed on the committee's plan of action by the following morning, January 15.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|pp=64–67, 95–97}} {{Quote box |quote =Liliuokalani has abdicated and my hands are untied. Annexation is now the goal for me. |source =John F.Colburn, 1895{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=xi}} |width=25% |align = left }} Liliuokalani was deposed by the Committee of Safety on January 17 and replaced by the [[Provisional Government of Hawaii|Provisional Government]], who also removed Colburn and the rest of the cabinet.{{harvnb|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918|p=188}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=A Provisional Government|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1893-01-18/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=January 18, 1893|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Simultaneously, the ''[[USS Boston (1884)|USS Boston]]'' was in Honolulu Harbor, and United States Minister [[John L. Stevens]] brought the [[United States Marine Corps|marines]] ashore, ostensibly to protect American assets, but what has historically been viewed as part of a wider conspiracy to seize the Hawaiian Islands.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=5}} A week later, Colburn resigned from the Board of Health rather than sign a loyalty oath to the provisional government.{{cite news|last1=|title=Local and General|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-01-27/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=January 27, 1893|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} In February 1893, Colburn wrote a letter to his uncle-in-law J. H. Ganz in Missouri detailing the events of the overthrow; Ganz in turn forwarded the letter to President [[Benjamin Harrison]], with a cover letter of his own. The two missives together were reprinted in numerous newspapers in the United States.{{cite news|last1=|title=Local and General|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87060190/1893-02-09/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 13, 2016|work=The Evening Bulletin.|date=February 9, 1893|location= Marysville, KY|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} [[Grover Cleveland]] succeeded Harrison as president on March 4, and dispatched Congressman [[James Henderson Blount]] to investigate the events, and the resulting [[Blount Report|report]] concluded that Stevens had acted in coordination with the conspirators.{{refn|group=FN|The United States Senate subsequently launched their own investigation, published as the [[Morgan Report]], and cleared Stevens of any wrongdoing in the overthrow. {{harvnb|Kuykendall|Day|1961|pp=178–179}}; {{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=39}}; {{harvnb|Blume|2016|pp=68–69}}}} In spite of the role he played in the overthrow, in October 1893 Colburn penned a letter to [[Celso Caesar Moreno]], Kalakaua's former [[Kuhina Nui|Prime Minister]] of Hawaii, asking for restoration of the monarchy and indemnity for the royalists.{{cite news|last1=|title=Now John F.Colburn Demands Indemnity for Needy Royalists|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1893-10-24/ed-1/seq-6/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Hawaiian Gazette|date=October 24, 1893|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=The Situation in Hawaii|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84025891/1893-10-14/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Washington Bee|date=October 14, 1893|location= Washington D. C.|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} A year later, he petitioned the [[Republic of Hawaii]] for his unpaid four days of salary before the overthrow.{{cite news|last1=|title=John F. Colburn Wants His Four Days of Salary|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1894-09-14/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=September 14, 1894|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} After Liliuokalani abdicated on January 24, 1895, Colburn became temporary chairman of Hawaiians for Annexation.{{harvnb|Twigg-Smith|1998|p=344}};{{cite news|last1=|title=Hawaiians for Annexation|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-02-14/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 6, 2016|work=The Daily Bulletin.|date=February 4, 1895|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} ==Later life and family== Upon the death of [[Queen Kapiolani]] on June 24, 1899,{{cite news|last1=|title=Beloved Alii Lives No More|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1899-06-27/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 8, 2016|work=The Hawaiian Gazette.|date=June 27, 1899|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} [[Prince David Kawānanakoa]] and [[Jonah Kūhiō Kalanianaʻole|Prince Jonah Kūhiō Kalanianaʻole]] were appointed administrators of her estate. With the formation of Kapiolani Estate Limited, Kawānanakoa was elected as president, Kūhiō as vice president, and Colburn as treasurer. Morris Kahai Keohokalole was elected as the secretary and auditor.{{cite news|last1=|title=The Princes Appointed|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1899-08-19/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 8, 2016|work=The Hawaiian Star.|date=August 19, 1899|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} A dispute between Kuhio and Colburn in 1916 led to Colburn's resigning from his position with the estate.{{cite news|last1=|title=John F. Colburn Out as Manager Kapiolani Est.|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1916-11-22/ed-2/seq-1/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin.|date=November 22, 1916|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Prior to his political career, Colburn served as the company auditor for the Kona Coffee and Fruit Co. Ltd., and imported and sold hay and grain. After the overthrow of the monarchy, he ran a restaurant and had success as an oyster farmer.{{cite news|last1=|title=Kona Coffee and Fruit Co. Ltd|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1891-02-07/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser.|date=February 7, 1891|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Advertisement "John F. Colburn, Importer and Dealer in Hay and Grain"|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047239/1886-12-28/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=November 5, 2016|work=The Daily Herald.|date=December 28, 1886|location= Honolulu, Hawaiian Islands|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Home Oyster Culture|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1897-04-02/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 2, 2016|work=Evening Bulletin.|date=April 2, 1897|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Mr. Colburn's Treat|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1896-11-19/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 15, 2016|work=Evening Bulletin.|date=November 19, 1896|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} On December 4, 1890, Colburn married Julia Naoho (1859–1916), a relative of [[Samuel Kamakau]]. He had nine children with her and adopted the five children she had with his first husband Charles Long, including Territory of Hawaii legislators [[Carlos A. Long]] and Elia A. C. Long. She preceded him in death on March 23, 1916.{{cite web|author=Hawaiʻi State Archives|year=2006|title=Colburn marriage record|work=Marriages – Oahu (1832–1910)|volume=1|via=Ulukau, the Hawaiian Electronic Library|url=http://ulukau.org/algene/cgi-bin/algene?e=d-001off-algene--00CL1%2e9--2----0--010---4-------0-1l--10en-Zz-1---20-about---00-1-1-00-0-0-000utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=algene&cl=CL1.9&d=09-000044|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}; {{cite web|author=Hawaiʻi State Archives|year=2006|title=Long marriage record|work=Marriages – Oahu (1832–1910)|volume=1|via=Ulukau, the Hawaiian Electronic Library|url=http://ulukau.org/algene/cgi-bin/algene?e=d-001off-algene--00CL1%2e10--2----0--010---4-------0-1l--10en-Zz-1---20-about---00-1-1-00-0-0-000utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=algene&cl=CL1.10&d=10-000080|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}; {{cite web|author=Hawaiʻi State Archives|year=2006|title=Colburn marriage record|work=Marriages – Oahu (1911–1929)|volume=1|via=Ulukau, the Hawaiian Electronic Library|url=http://ulukau.org/algene/cgi-bin/algene?e=d-001off-algene--00CL1%2e11--2----0--010---4-------0-1l--10en-Zz-1---20-about---00-1-1-00-0-0-000utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=algene&cl=CL1.11&d=11-000160|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}; {{cite web|author=Hawaiʻi State Archives|year=2006|title=Long marriage record|work=Marriages – Oahu (1911–1929)|volume=1|via=Ulukau, the Hawaiian Electronic Library|url=http://ulukau.org/algene/cgi-bin/algene?e=d-001off-algene--00CL1%2e11--2----0--010---4-------0-1l--10en-Zz-1---20-about---00-1-1-00-0-0-000utfZz-8-00&a=d&c=algene&cl=CL1.11&d=11-000587|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=|title=Death Ends Illness of Mrs. J. F. Colburn|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1916-03-24/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Hawaiian Star-Bulletin.|date=March 24, 1916|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Mrs. J. F. Colburn Dies in Sanitarium|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1916-03-24/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 7, 2016|work=The Hawaiian Gazette.|date=March 24, 1916|location= Honolulu, Oahu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}{{cite book|last1=Long|first1=Elia Austin|last2=Dolan|first2=Paul A.|title=Elia Austin Long|url=http://www.outriggercanoeclubsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Elia-Austin-Long-2002.pdf|date=April 23, 2002|publisher=Historical Committee of the Outrigger Canoe Club|location=Honolulu}} His older brother Marcus Rexford Colburn died March 20, 1901, of a prolonged illness. The eldest of the Colburn siblings, sister Sarah (Mrs. Gilbert) Parmenter, died in 1903 from a gunshot wound to the head, inflicted by her former son-in-law E. M. Jones during a family dispute in which her daughter was murdered.{{cite news|last1=|title=Marcus Colburn|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1901-03-20/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 9, 2016|work=The Independent.|date=March 20, 1901|location= Honolulu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}}; {{cite news|last1=|title=Mrs. Parmenter Dead|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1903-08-27/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=November 10, 2016|work=The Independent.|date=August 27, 1903|location= Honolulu, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} Colburn died at his home in Honolulu, on March 16, 1920, at the age of sixty.{{cite news|last1=|title=John F. Colburn Dies in Honolulu – 60 Years|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1920-03-19/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=November 2, 2016|work=The Maui News.|date=March 19, 1920|location= Wailuku, Maui, Hawaii|via=Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress.}} He was buried at the [[Oahu Cemetery]] in Honolulu.{{cite sign|title=Grave Marker of John F. Colburn|type=|location=Honolulu, HI|institution=[[Oahu Cemetery]]}} ==Notes== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|group=FN}} === Citations === {{Reflist|30em}} == References == * {{cite book|last1=Blume|first1=Kenneth L.|date=2016|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|location=Lanham, MI|isbn=978-1-4422-7332-0|title=Historical Dictionary of U.S. Diplomacy from the Civil War to World War I|ref=harv|edition=2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BI4xDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&dq=Morgan+Report+%22John+L.+Stevens%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiysaq127DQAhXorVQKHSIDBlYQ6AEILzAD#v=onepage&q=Morgan%20Report%20%22John%20L.%20Stevens%22&f=false}} * {{cite book|last1=Forbes|first1=David W.|title=Hawaiian National Bibliography, 1780–1900: Volume 4: 1881–1900|date=2003|publisher=University Of Hawai'i Press|location=Honolulu, HI|isbn=978-0-8248-2636-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jAuzOipG26YC&pg=PA479&dq=%22John+F.+Colburn%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiW1ryitpfQAhVX5mMKHd45BY4Q6AEIIzAB#v=onepage&q=%22John%20F.%20Colburn%22&f=false|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|author=Hawaii|editor-last=Lydecker|editor-first=Robert Colfax|volume=|title=Roster Legislatures of Hawaii, 1841–1918|location=Honolulu|publisher=Hawaiian Gazette Company|year=1918|url=https://archive.org/details/rosterlegislatur00hawarich|oclc=60737418|ref={{harvid|Hawaii|Lydecker|1918}}}} * {{cite book|last1=Kuykendall|first1=Ralph Simpson|last2=Day|first2=A. {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}}
The '''Little Ships of Dunkirk''' were about 850 private boats<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/events/dunkirk_evacuation | title = BBC History - Britain retreats from France }}</ref> that sailed from [[Ramsgate]] in England to [[Dunkirk]] in France between 26 May and 4 June 1940 as part of [[Operation Dynamo]], helping to rescue more than 336,000 British and French soldiers who were [[Battle of Dunkirk|trapped on the beaches at Dunkirk]] during the [[Second World War]].
==Overview==
The situation of the troops, who had been cut off from their advance into France by a pincer movement from the German army, was regarded by the British prime minister [[Winston Churchill]] as the greatest military defeat for centuries; it appeared likely to cost Britain the war, as the majority of the [[British Expeditionary Force (World War II)|British Expeditionary Force]] was trapped, leaving the country vulnerable to invasion by [[Nazi Germany|Germany]].<ref name=Birkett>Birkett, Peter. [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/once-more-unto-the-beach-for-ships-that-saved-an-army-715466.html "Once more unto the beach for ships that saved an army"], ''The Independent'', 3 June 2000.</ref><ref name=history>[http://www.adls.org.uk/ "History"], The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships, Retrieved 1 April 2008.</ref><ref>Safire, William. ''Lend Me Your Ears: Great Speeches in History''. W. W. Norton & Company, 2004, p. 146.</ref> Because of the shallow waters, British destroyers were unable to approach the beaches, and soldiers were having to wade out to the boats, many of them waiting hours shoulder deep in water.
On 27 May, the small-craft section of the British [[Minister of Shipping|Ministry of Shipping]] telephoned boat builders around the coast, asking them to collect all boats with "shallow [[Draft (hull)|draft]]" that could navigate the shallow waters. Attention was directed to the pleasure boats, private yachts and launches moored on the [[River Thames]] and along the south and east coasts. Some of them were taken with the owners' permission – and with the owners insisting they would sail them – while others were requisitioned by the government with no time for the owners to be contacted. The boats were checked to make sure they were seaworthy, fuelled, and taken to [[Ramsgate]] to set sail for Dunkirk. They were manned by Naval Officers, [[Naval rating|Ratings]] and experienced volunteers. Very few owners manned their own vessels, apart from fishermen and one or two others.<ref name=history/>
When they reached France, some of the boats acted as shuttles between the beaches and the destroyers, ferrying soldiers to the warships. Others carried hundreds of soldiers each back to Ramsgate, protected by the [[Royal Air Force]] from the attacks of the [[Luftwaffe]].
According to the Association of Dunkirk Little Ships, the term "Little Ship" applies to all craft that were originally privately owned and includes commercial vessels such as barges, fishing vessels and pleasure steamers; the Association does include some ex-Service vessels, which are now privately owned, and ex-lifeboats.
==Notable boats== *''[[MV Royal Daffodil (1939)|Royal Daffodil II]]'' – not to be confused with the smaller River Mersey ferry which did not go to Dunkirk, this vessel owned by the [[General Steam Navigation Company]] of London evacuated 7,461 service personnel from Dunkirk in five trips between 28 May and 2 June, among them the French historian [[Marc Bloch]],<ref name="bloch">{{cite book |title=Marc Bloch: A Life in History |last=Fink |first=Carole |year=1991 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-521-40671-4 |page=229}}</ref> who served as a French army captain in the campaign. This was the largest number evacuated by a single passenger vessel in the operation.{{cn|date=February 2018}} On 2 June, she was attacked by six German aircraft. A bomb dropped by one of them penetrated two of her decks and blew a hole below the water line, but she managed to limp back to port. *''[[Medway Queen]]'' – the [[paddle steamer]] made the most round trips – seven – rescuing 7,000 men and earning herself the nickname "Heroine of Dunkirk". Restored and rededicated in 2013, she can now be visited at the [[Fort Gillingham|Gillingham Pier]] in [[Kent]].<ref name="GMB">{{cite web|url=http://www.gmb.org.uk/newsroom/rebuilt-medway-queen-journey-to-kent|title=Rebuilt Medway Queen Journey To Kent|date=21 October 2013|publisher=GMB Newsroom|accessdate=19 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Visit and Contact |url=https://www.medwayqueen.co.uk/visit-and-contact.html|work=The Medway Queen Preservation Society|accessdate=19 December 2015}}</ref> *''[[Massey Shaw]]'' – the London-based [[fireboat]] initially went to Dunkirk to help fight fires, however it ended up making three trips across the channel rescuing over 500 troops, including 30 troops from the ''Emil de Champ'' which had hit a mine in the Channel. *''[[Sundowner (yacht)|Sundowner]]'' – [[Motor yacht]] owned by [[Charles Lightoller]], former second officer of the ''[[RMS Titanic|Titanic]],'' was requisitioned by the Admiralty on 30 May. Lightoller insisted that, if anyone was going to take her to Dunkirk, it would be him and his eldest son, Roger, together with [[Sea Scout]] Gerald Ashcroft. The men transported 130 soldiers back to [[Ramsgate]], reportedly packed together like sardines, almost capsizing when they reached the shore.<ref>[http://www.adls.org.uk/shipinfo.cfm?id=63&RestTrust=0 "Sundowner."] ''The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships.'' Retrieved 1 April 2008.</ref> She is a [[museum ship]] at the [[Ramsgate Maritime Museum]]. *''[[Bluebird of Chelsea]]'' – the yacht made two round trips to [[Kent]], carrying hundreds of men.<ref name=Birkett/> *''[[Tamzine]]'' – a fishing boat less than {{convert|15|ft|m}} in length; the smallest boat to take part in the evacuation and now preserved by the [[Imperial War Museum]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/582 |title=Tamzine |author=Association of Dunkirk Little Ships |date=2009–2010 |work=adls.org.uk |accessdate=18 March 2012}}</ref> *''Marchioness'' – built in 1923, in 1989 she was involved in a [[Marchioness disaster|collision with ''Bowbelle'']] on the River Thames with the loss of 51 lives. *{{SS|Clan MacAlister|1930|6}} – a 6,900-ton cargo ship from [[Glasgow]]. It was the largest merchant vessel used during the evacuation, and was sunk off the beach on 29 May. As it sank, it happened to settle evenly to the bottom in shallow water with the decks above water, and thereafter served as an unintentional decoy target for German Stuka dive-bombers. The British Admiralty later estimated the ''Clan MacAlister'' saved over a million pounds (sterling) worth of shipping.
===RNLI lifeboats at Dunkirk=== {{see also|Royal National Lifeboat Institution lifeboats}} See also individual stations for more information in many cases. * [[RNLB Abdy Beauclerk (ON 751)|''Abdy Beauclerk'' (ON 751)]], a {{Lbc|Watson}} lifeboat from [[Aldeburgh Lifeboat Station]]<ref name=DunkirkLAB>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/508|work= Abdy Beauclerk|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> No.1 Station. * [[RNLB Cecil and Lilian Philpott (ON 730)|''Cecil and Lilian Philpott'' (ON 730)]], a Watson-class lifeboat from [[Newhaven Lifeboat Station|Newhaven]], [[East Sussex|Sussex]].<ref name=DunkirkLVISCLPOT>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/stenoa-previously-cecil-and-lilian-philpott |work=The Cecil and Lilian Philpott |publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> She evacuated 51 soldiers but was left high and dry on the beach for 4 hours until the next day when she resumed the evacuation. * [[RNLB Charles Cooper Henderson (ON 761)|''Charles Cooper Henderson'' (ON 761)]], a {{Lbc|Beach}} lifeboat from [[Dungeness (headland)|Dungeness]], [[Kent]].<ref name=DunkirkLCOOP>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/caresana-previously-charles-cooper-henderson|work=The Lord Southborough|publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> The lifeboat was taken to Dunkirk with a crew of naval ratings. She got back to Dungeness but had sustained some damage. *[[RNLB Charles Dibdin (Civil Service No. 2) (ON 762)|''Charles Dibdin (Civil Service No. 2)'' (ON 762)]], a ''Beach''-class lifeboat from [[Walmer Lifeboat Station|Walmer]], Kent.<ref name=DunkirkLCDNo2>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/579|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Cyril and Lilian Bishop (ON 740)|''Cyril and Lilian Bishop'' (ON 740)]], a ''Self-righting''-class lifeboat from [[Hastings Old Town|Hastings]], East Sussex.<ref name=DunkirkLCLBISH>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/566|work=The Cyril and Lilian Bishop|publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Edward Dresden (ON 707)|''Edward Dresden'' (ON 707)]], a ''Watson''-class lifeboat from [[Clacton-on-Sea]]. Worked along with E.M.E.D. (ON 705) in Dunkirk harbour. One of only a few boats taken to Dunkirk by her own crew. * [[RNLB E.M.E.D. (ON 705)|''E.M.E.D.'' (ON 705)]], a ''Watson''-class lifeboat from Walton and Frinton station.<ref name=DunkirkLEMED>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/576|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> The lifeboat survived three enemy air attacks off [[Gravelines]]. * [[RNLB Greater London (Civil Service No. 3) (ON 704)|''Greater London (Civil Service No. 3)'' (ON 704)]], a {{Lbc|Ramsgate}} lifeboat from [[Southend-on-Sea Lifeboat Station|Southend-on-Sea]].<ref name=DunkirkLGLON>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/575|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Guide of Dunkirk (ON 826)|''Guide of Dunkirk'' (ON 826)]], a new and unnamed ''Watson''-class lifeboat at the time of the evacuation.<ref name=DunkirkLGD>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/568|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Herbert Sturmey (ON 664)|''Herbert Sturmey'' (ON 664)]], a ''Self-righting''-class lifeboat from {{Lbs|Cadgwith}}.<ref name=halifax>{{cite web|title=RNLI lifeboats used in the Dunkirk evacuation|url=http://www.halifaxlifeboat.org/rnlihistory_41478.html|publisher=Halifax Lifeboat|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Jane Holland (ON 673)|''Jane Holland'' (ON 673)]],<ref name=DunkirkJANEHOLLAND>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/jane-holland-now-reporter-0 |work=The Jane Holland Lifeboat|publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> a ''Self-righting''-class lifeboat from {{Lbs|Eastbourne}}, East Sussex.<ref name=halifax /> She was holed when a [[Motor Torpedo Boat]] rammed her and her engine failed after being machine gunned by an aircraft. She was abandoned but later found adrift, towed back to Dover and repaired. She returned to service on 5 April 1941.<ref>{{cite work|last1=Morris|last2=Hendy|first1=Jeff|first2=Dave|title=The story of the Eastbourne lifeboats|date=2006|pages=13–14|publisher=RNLI|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Story_of_the_Eastbourne_Lifeboats.html?id=B52jnQEACAAJ&redir_esc=y|accessdate=13 July 2014}}</ref> * [[RNLB Louise Stephens (ON 820)|''Louise Stephens'' (ON 820)]], a ''Watson''-class lifeboat from [[Great Yarmouth and Gorleston Lifeboat Station|Gorleston and Great Yarmouth]].<ref name=DunkirkLSLS>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/louise-stephens|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> She was taken to Dunkirk by a naval crew. She came back with a hole in her after endbox. * [[RNLB Lucy Lavers (ON 832)|''Lucy Lavers'' (ON 832)]], a {{Lbc|Liverpool}} lifeboat from [[Aldeburgh]]<ref name=DunkirkLLL>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/565|work= Lucy Lavers|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> No: 2 station. * [[RNLB Lord Southborough (Civil Service No. 1) (ON 688)|''Lord Southborough (Civil Service No. 1)'' (ON 688)]], a ''Watson''-class lifeboat from [[Margate]], Kent.<ref name=DunkirkLVISCTS578>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/578|work=The Lord Southborough|publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> After arriving on the beaches for a second time, she evacuated over 500 men to the destroyer [[HMS Icarus (D03)|HMS Icarus]]. * [[RNLB Mary Scott (ON 691)|''Mary Scott'' (ON 691)]], a {{Lbc|Norfolk and Suffolk}} lifeboat from [[Southwold Lifeboat Station|Southwold]].<ref name=DunkirkLMARYS>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/mary-scott|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> She was towed to Dunkirk by the paddle steamer ''Emperor of India'' together with two other small boats. Between them they took 160 men to their mother ship, then 50 to another transport vessel before her engine failed and could not be restarted.<ref name=DunkirkLMS/> She was beached and abandoned at La Panne, east of Dunkirk. She eventually was refloated and returned to Southwold. * [[RNLB Michael Stephens (ON 838)|''Michael Stephens'' (ON 838)]], a 46' ''Watson''-class lifeboat from [[Lowestoft Lifeboat Station|Lowestoft]].<ref name=DunkirkLMS>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/571|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> She worked inside the harbour in Dunkirk and was rammed twice by [[Germany|German]] MTBs (motor torpedo boats), but she returned to Dover under her own power. * [[RNLB Prudential (ON 697)|''Prudential'' (ON 697)]], a {{Lbc|Ramsgate}} lifeboat (a prototype) from [[Ramsgate Lifeboat Station#Dunkirk evacuation|Ramsgate]].<ref name=DunkirkLPRU>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url= http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/trimilia-previously-prudential|publisher= Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=2 September 2013}}</ref> One of only a few boats taken to Dunkirk by her own crew, who collected 2,800 men from the beaches. * [[RNLB Rosa Woodd and Phyliss Lunn (ON 758)|''Rosa Woodd and Phyliss Lunn'' (ON 758)]], a ''Watson''-class lifeboat from {{Lbs|Shoreham Harbour}}.<ref name=halifax /> She made three trips between Dover and Dunkirk. * [[RNLB Thomas Kirk Wright (ON 811)|''Thomas Kirk Wright'' (ON 811)]], a {{Lbc|Surf}} lifeboat from [[Poole Lifeboat Station|Poole]]<ref name=Dunkirk-Poole>{{cite web|title=Poole Lifeboat at Dunkirk|url=http://www.poole-lifeboats.org.uk/dunkirk.shtm|publisher=Poole Lifeboat|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> * [[RNLB Viscountess Wakefield (ON 783)|''Viscountess Wakefield'' (ON 783)]], a ''Beach''-class lifeboat from [[Hythe, Kent|Hythe]], Kent.<ref name=DunkirkLVISCTS577>{{cite web|title= The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/577|work=The Viscountess Wakefield|publisher= Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> She ran aground on the sands of [[De Panne|La Panne]], the only lifeboat to be sunk during the operation.
===Thames sailing barges=== Thirteen [[Thames sailing barge]]s made the crossing, six from R & W Paul Ltd, grain and agricultural merchants of Harwich. *[[SB Ena|''Ena'']] her crew were ordered to abandon her. She was beached but then refloated by Lt Colonel W G Mc Kay and men of the 19th Field Regiment, Royal Artillery, and taken back to Ramsgate, notable as none of them was a sailor.<ref name="nhs199">{{cite web|title=Ena {{!}} National Historic Ships|url=http://www.nationalhistoricships.org.uk/register/199/ena|website=www.nationalhistoricships.org.uk|accessdate=10 April 2018|ref=harv|language=en}}</ref>
===Isle of Man Steam Packet Company=== [[File:Dunkirk 1940 HU1145.jpg|thumb|Isle of Man Steam Packet Company vessel ''Mona's Queen,'' pictured as she struck a mine on the approach to Dunkirk, 29 May 1940.]] At the outbreak of war, 10 of the 16 vessels in the fleet of the [[Isle of Man Steam Packet Company]] were requisitioned. Four were lost.
Eight of the company's ships took part in the Dunkirk evacuation. [[Mona's Isle (1905)|''Mona’s Isle'']] was the first to leave Dover, and the first vessel to complete a round trip. By the end of operations, the fleet had rescued a total of 24,699, 1 in 14 of those evacuated from Dunkirk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steam-packet.com/en/AboutUs/|title=About Us|publisher=Steam Packet|accessdate=7 September 2011}}</ref>
Whilst the evacuation is widely regarded as the Isle of Man Steam Packet Company's ''"finest hour"'', it also saw its blackest day. Three of its ships were lost in one day, 29 May 1940. * [[Mona's Queen (1934)|''Mona's Queen'']], mined off Dunkirk; * [[SS Fenella (1936)|''Fenella'']], sunk by air attack whilst berthed alongside the East Pier; * [[King Orry (1913)|''King Orry'']] sustained heavy damage in several air attacks on 29 May, and consequently sank off the beaches in the early hours of 30 May.
===Dutch coasters=== Thirty-nine Dutch [[Coastal trading vessel|coasters]] had escaped the occupation of the [[Netherlands]] by the Germans on 10 May 1940 and were asked by the Dutch shipping bureau in London or by the Royal Navy to assist. The Dutch coasters, able to approach the beaches very closely due to their flat bottoms, rescued 22,698 men in total.
The {{MV|Rian}}, a {{convert|35|m|ft|adj=on}} ship of 300 tons dwt built in 1934 in the province of [[Groningen (province)|Groningen]], saved 2,542 men between 28 and 31 May 1940 under Captain D. Buining, the most men saved amongst the Dutch coasters. The vessel had already saved the crew of the British coaster {{SS|Highwave}} on 30 January 1940. Other Dutch coasters that saved more than 1,000 men each were: * {{MV|Hondsrug}}: 1,455 * {{MV|Patria}}: 1,400 * {{MV|Hilda}}: 1,200 * {{MV|Doggersbank}}: 1,200 * {{MV|Horst}}: 1,150 * {{MV|Twente}}: 1,139 * {{MV|Friso}}: 1,002
Of these ships, seven were lost at Dunkirk or during the evacuation nearer the British coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wivonet.nl/operatiedynamo.htm|title=Operation Dynamo|publisher=wivonet.nl|accessdate=27 May 2010|language=nl}}</ref>
===Belgian ships=== The [[Belgian Army]], commanded by [[Leopold III of Belgium|King Leopold III]], had surrendered to the Germans on 28 May. However, numerous ships from the fishing fleet and small ''[[Belgian Navy|Corps de Marine]]'' were involved in Operation Dynamo. In total, 65 Belgian ships participated, including 54 fishing boats, 4 ''Corps de Marine'' units, 4 tugs and 2 patrol vessels.<ref name=KLMMRA1>{{cite web|title=Dunkerque|publisher=[[KLM-MRA]] Séction Marine|url=http://www.marine-mra-klm.be/dunkerque_044.htm|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref> The Belgian fishing fleet itself transported 4,300 British and French soldiers to the English coast.<ref>{{cite web|title=Royal Navy Section Belge|url=http://www.marine-mra-klm.be/royal_navy_section_belge_047.htm|publisher=[[KLM-MRA]]|accessdate=28 September 2013}}</ref>
Among the notable Belgian ships to participate in the evacuation were:
*[[Belgian ship A5|Patrol vessel A5]] *{{ship|Z25|De Ruyter||}} *[[Belgian ship H75]]
===Irish Marine and Coastwatching Ship=== An Irish Marine and Coastwatching Service [[Motor Torpedo Boat]] (MTB) made two separate trips to rescue allied soldiers during the Dunkirk evacuation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pressreader.com/ireland/the-irish-mail-on-sunday/20170716/282239485673782|title=Irish Navy sailors and Dunkirk|work=[[The Irish Mail on Sunday]]|accessdate=16 July 2017}}</ref>
==Results== In nine days, 192,226 British and 139,000 French soldiers – more than 331,000 total – were rescued by the 700 little ships and around 220 warships. The rescue operation turned a military disaster into a story of heroism which served to raise the morale of the British.
It was in describing the success of the operation to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] on 4 June 1940 that Churchill made his famous "[[we shall fight on the beaches]]" speech:
<blockquote>We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island, whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender ...<ref>Churchill, Winston. [http://www.fiftiesweb.com/usa/winston-churchill-fight-beaches.htm "We shall fight on the beaches"], House of Commons, June 4, 1940.</ref></blockquote>
==Legacy== [[File:ADLS Letterhead-Logo.tif|alt=|thumb|Association of Dunkirk Little Ships House Flag]] {{anchor|Dunkirk jack}} [[File:Tug Challenge.jpg|thumb|ST ''Challenge'']] The phrase "Dunkirk spirit" is still used to describe courage and solidarity in adversity.<ref>Knowles, David J. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/765004.stm "The 'miracle' of Dunkirk"], BBC News, 30 May 2000.</ref>
The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships is an association for owners of Dunkirk Little Ships, founded in 1965.<ref>[http://www.adls.org.uk/ ADLS website]</ref> The Association organises a memorial crossing of Little Ships to Dunkirk every five years, escorted by the Royal Navy. Its flag is the [[St George's Cross]] [[Defacement (flag)|defaced]] with the arms of Dunkirk flown from the [[jackstaff|jack staff]], known as the Dunkirk [[Maritime flag#Jacks|jack]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/content/history-association-dunkirk-little-ships|website=History of The Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref>
The '''Dunkirk Little Ships Restoration Trust''' is a [[Charitable organization|registered charity]]<ref>{{EW charity|1021088|Dunkirk Little Ships Restoration Trust}}</ref> established in 1993 to preserve and restore Dunkirk Little Ships. Its collection includes the steam tug ST ''Challenge'',<ref>[http://www.stchallenge.org/ ST Challenge official website]</ref> a vessel in the [[National Historic Fleet]].<ref>[http://www.nationalhistoricships.org.uk/register/13/challenge National Historic Ships Register]</ref>
At least twelve<ref>Or fourteen, according to ''The Daily Mail'': {{cite web|author1=Jim White|title=The making of movie epic Dunkirk|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/event/article-4715384/The-making-movie-epic-Dunkirk.html|website=Mail Online|publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd|accessdate=11 May 2018|date=22 July 2017}}</ref> actual Little Ships were used in the 2017 film [[Dunkirk (2017 film)|''Dunkirk'']].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vincent|first1=Alice|title=The real Little Ships seen in Christopher Nolan's Dunkirk, and the stories behind them|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/2017/07/21/stories-little-ships-survived-dunkirk-star-christopher-nolans|accessdate=10 May 2018|work=The Telegraph|date=21 July 2017}}{{subscription}}</ref>
One of the Little Ships, the [[Red Funnel]] paddle steamer, ''Princess Elizabeth'' is now owned by the City of Dunkirk and is permanently moored in the harbour as a floating conference centre.<ref>{{cite web|title=Princess Elizabeth|url=http://www.adls.org.uk/t1/node/615|website=Association of Dunkirk Little Ships|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox galaxy | name = MACS 1423-z7p64 | epoch = [[J2000]] | constellation name = [[Boötes]] | ra = {{Deg2HMS|215.942406|sup=yes}}<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" /> | dec = {{Deg2DMS|24.069655|sup=yes}}<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" /> | z = 7.640 ± 0.001<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" /> | h_radial_v = | dist_ly = | type = | mass = | size = | appmag_v = | appmag_b = | absmag_v = | size_v = | names = }} '''MACS 1423-z7p64''' is a [[galaxy]] listed in the [[MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS)]], and announced on 10 April 2017 in the journal [[Nature (journal)|''Nature Astronomy'']],<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature">{{cite journal|bibcode=2017NatAs...1E..91H|doi=10.1038/s41550-017-0091|arxiv=1704.02970|title=Spectroscopic confirmation of an ultra-faint galaxy at the epoch of reionization|journal=Nature Astronomy|volume=1|issue=5|pages=0091|year=2017|last1=Hoag|first1=Austin|last2=Bradač|first2=Maruša|last3=Trenti|first3=Michele|last4=Treu|first4=Tommaso|last5=Schmidt|first5=Kasper B|last6=Huang|first6=Kuang-Han|last7=Lemaux|first7=Brian C|last8=He|first8=Julie|last9=Bernard|first9=Stephanie R|last10=Abramson|first10=Louis E|last11=Mason|first11=Charlotte A|last12=Morishita|first12=Takahiro|last13=Pentericci|first13=Laura|last14=Schrabback|first14=Tim}}</ref> as being the most distant source of [[reionization]] known at this time, with a [[redshift]] z = 7.640 ± 0.001 (lookback time >13.1 Gyr).<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" />
==Discovery== MACS 1423-z7p64 was discovered through [[gravitational lensing]] by [[MACS J1423.8+2404]] (z = 0.545), a cluster that magnified its brightness by a factor of 10. To identify the galaxy, the astronomers used the slitless [[grism]] [[spectrograph]] of the [[Wide Field Infrared Survey Telescope]] on the [[Hubble Space Telescope]], and to determine its distance the [[W. M. Keck Observatory#Instruments|Multi-Object Spectrometer for Infra-Red Exploration (MOSFIRE)]] detector of the [[Keck Observatory]].<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" /><ref name="2017-04-11_ABC">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/science/2017-04-11/faintest-galaxy-from-early-universe-ever-detected/8428846|title=Astronomers detect ultra-faint galaxy from the very early universe]author=Weule, Genelle|publisher=[[ABC News Online]]|date=2017-04-11}}</ref>
Nature received the paper on 27 October 2016.)<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" />
==Importance== With a redshift z = 7.640 ± 0.001, and being an [[order of magnitude]] lower in intensity than the four other Lyman-α emitters currently known at z > 7.5, it is probably the most distant representative source of reionization found to date.<ref name="2017-04-10_Nature" /> This is from a time when the universe was around 700 million years old.<ref name="2017-04-11_ABC" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.nature.com/articles/s41550-017-0091 Nature article] ** [https://dx.doi.org/10.1038/s41550-017-0091 doi reference]
