{{redirect|Yemeni Crisis|other crises in Yemen|Yemeni Civil War (disambiguation)}} {{Yemeni Crisis (2011–present)}} {{Campaignbox Yemeni Crisis}} The '''Yemeni Crisis''' began with the [[Yemeni Revolution|2011–12 revolution]] against President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], who had led [[Yemen]] for more than three decades.<ref name="crisis">{{cite news|agency=Yahoo! News|url=https://news.yahoo.com/yemens-crisis-reflects-arc-arab-spring-revolts-115411382.html|title=Yemen's crisis reflects arc of Arab Spring revolts|first=Hamza|last=Hendawi|date=12 October 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/07/world/middleeast/yemen-rebels-take-over-a-struggling-country.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&module=photo-spot-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news|agency=The New York Times|title=In Yemen, Hard Times Remain a Constant as Rebels Take Charge|first=Mona|last=al-Naggar|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> After Saleh left office in early 2012 as part of a mediated agreement between the [[government of Yemen|Yemeni government]] and opposition groups, the government led by Saleh's former vice president, [[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]], struggled to unite the fractious political landscape of the country and fend off threats both from [[Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula]] and [[Houthis|Houthi militants]] that had been waging a protracted [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|insurgency in the north]] for years.<ref name="meet">{{cite news|agency=BuzzFeed|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/gregorydjohnsen/meet-the-group-that-now-rules-yemen#.rxPB6yvew|title=Meet The Group That Now Rules Yemen|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/perspective/analysis/2013/12/08/Al-Qaeda-thrives-in-Yemen-amid-weak-security-stalled-dialogue.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Al-Qaeda thrives in Yemen amid weak security, stalled dialogue|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> In 2014, Houthi fighters [[Battle of Sana'a (2014)|swept into the capital of Sana'a]] and forced Hadi to negotiate a "unity government" with other political factions. The rebels continued to apply pressure on the weakened government until, after his presidential palace and private residence came under attack from the militant group, Hadi resigned along with his ministers in January 2015. The following month, the Houthis [[2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état|declared themselves in control of the government]], dissolving [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|Parliament]] and installing an interim [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] led by [[Mohammed Ali al-Houthi]], a cousin of Houthi leader [[Abdul-Malik al-Houthi]].<ref name="takeover">{{cite news|url=http://www.columbian.com/news/2015/feb/06/yemen-shiite-rebels-takeover-country/|agency=The Columbian|title=Yemen's Shiite rebels announce takeover of country|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015|first=Ahmed|last=al-Haj}}</ref><ref name="installs">{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/houthi-militia-installs-presidential-council-run-yemen-1600545027|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Houthi militia installs 'presidential council' to run Yemen|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref> However, Hadi escaped to [[Aden]], where he declared that he remains Yemen's legitimate president, proclaimed the country's temporary capital, and called on loyal government officials and members of the military to rally to him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aa.com.tr/en/politics/481862--yemens-hadi-denies-aden-secession|agency=Anadolu Agency|title=Yemen's Hadi denies Aden secession|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e0340c8c-bd9f-11e4-8cf3-00144feab7de.html#axzz3V8LWgg3o|agency=Financial Times|title=UN and Gulf back Yemeni president Hadi amid fears of civil war|date=26 February 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015|first=Simeon|last=Kerr}}</ref> On 27 March 2015, [[BBC]] reported that Hadi had "fled rebel forces in the city of Aden" and subsequently "arrived in Saudi Arabia's capital Riyadh" as "Saudi authorities began air strikes in Yemen".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32078817|agency=BBC|title=President Hadi leaves Yemen as Saudi-led raids continue|date=27 March 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}}</ref> [[Yemeni Civil War (2015-present)|Civil War]] subsequently erupted between Hadi's government and the Houthis. Since 2017 the separatist [[Southern Transitional Council]] (STC) has also fought against the government.
==Background== The wave of protests known as the [[Arab Spring]] did not take long to arrive in Yemen after the [[Tunisian Revolution]]. Yemen was a poor country with a government widely acknowledged to be corrupt, with a large amount of weapons in private hands. By 2011, the country was already facing challenges from [[al Qaeda]]-linked militants and [[Southern Movement|separatists]] in the south and [[Zaydi]] [[Shia Islam|Shia]] rebels in the north. Yemen had only been unified since 1990, and deep divisions persisted between the [[North Yemen|north]] and [[South Yemen|south]].
===Ecological Crisis=== Yemen's political instability has been compounded and partly caused by the severe ecological crisis in the country. The average Yemeni has access to only 140 cubic meters of water per year for all uses, (101 gallons per day) while the Middle Eastern average is 1000 m<sup>3</sup>/yr, and the internationally defined threshold for water stress is 1700 cubic meters per year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/180.htm|title=Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability|publisher=|accessdate=25 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626113733/http://www.grida.no/climate/ipcc_tar/wg2/180.htm|archive-date=26 June 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Water supply and sanitation in Yemen|Yemen's groundwater]] is the main source of water in the country but the water tables have dropped severely leaving the country without a viable source of water. For example, in [[Sana'a]], the water table was 30 meters below surface in the 1970s but had dropped to 1200 meters below surface by 2012. The groundwater has not been regulated by Yemen's governments.<ref name=IRIN>{{cite news|title=YEMEN: Time running out for solution to water crisis|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/96093/yemen-time-running-out-for-solution-to-water-crisis|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=[[IRIN]]|date=13 August 2012}}</ref> Even before the revolution, Yemen's water situation had been described as increasingly dire by experts who worried that Yemen would be the "first country to run out of water".<ref name="Time Ecocentric">{{cite news|last1=Mahr|first1=Krista|title=What If Yemen Is the First Country to Run Out of Water?|url=http://science.time.com/2010/12/14/what-if-yemen-is-first-country-to-run-out-of-water/|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=[[TIME Magazine]]|date=Dec 14, 2010}}</ref> Agriculture in Yemen takes up about 90% of water in Yemen even though it only generates 6% of GDP - however a large portion of Yemenis are dependent on small-scale subsistence agriculture. Half of agricultural water in Yemen is used to grow [[khat]], a narcotic that most Yemenis chew. This means that in such a water-scarce country as Yemen, where half the population is food-insecure, 45% of the water withdrawn from the ever-depleting aquifers is used to grow a crop that feeds nobody.<ref name = "IRIN"/>
This water insecurity has a direct impact on political stability. Outsiders hear most about the [[proxy war]] between factions supported by other countries, but according to the Yemeni newspaper [[Al-Thawra (Yemen)|Al-Thawra]], 70% to 80% of conflicts in the country's rural regions are water-related. The country's Interior Ministry has estimated that across the country, water and land related disputes kill 4,000 people a year - more than terrorism.<ref name=Heffez>{{cite news|last1=Heffez|first1=Adam|title=How Yemen Chewed Itself Dry|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/139596/adam-heffez/how-yemen-chewed-itself-dry|accessdate=17 April 2015|agency=Foreign Affairs|date=23 July 2013}}</ref> In [[Al-Jawf Governorate]], a dispute over a well's placement has led to a blood feud that has continued for more than 30 years<ref name = "IRIN"/> In 2007, Yemen's minister of Water and Natural Resources suggested that the Sana'a might have to be evacuated if it runs out of water.<ref>Kirby, Alex:[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/6530453.stm "Yemen's khat habit soaks up water."] BBC News, Sana’a, 7 April 2007</ref> Although the government was unable to move the capital in an orderly and peaceful way, the war and political crisis has rendered Sana'a and most of Yemen into a battleground that people have been forced to flee.
Additional environmental catastrophes have battered Yemen as the war has progressed. In late 2015, [[2015 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Extremely Severe Cyclonic Storm Chapala|two historic cyclones]] struck the country. The first of these, [[Cyclone Chapala]], struck the island of [[Socotra]] before hitting the port of [[Mukalla]] on Yemen's south coast, where it caused catastrophic flash flooding.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fritz|first1=Angela|title=Historic Cyclone Chapala ravages coastal Yemen with catastrophic flash flooding|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2015/11/03/historic-cyclone-chapala-ravages-coastal-yemen-with-catastrophic-flash-flooding/|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=Washington Post|date=3 November 2015}}</ref> This storm, combined with the following [[Cyclone Megh]], left enough moisture in the soil for [[locusts]] to breed. These locusts can fly 100 miles in a day and destroy any crop they encounter.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Oakford|first1=Samuel|title=Battered By Civil War and Historic Cyclones, Yemen Now Faces Swarms of Locusts|url=https://news.vice.com/article/battered-by-civil-war-and-historic-cyclones-yemen-now-faces-swarms-of-locusts|accessdate=12 December 2015|work=[[Vice News]]|date=12 November 2015}}</ref>
==History== ===Revolution (2011–12)=== Yemen's political crisis began in 2011, amid the [[Arab Spring]] and the ongoing [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|Houthi insurgency]].
====Protests against Saleh==== [[File:Yemeni Protests 4-Apr-2011 P01.JPG|thumbnail|upright=1.1364|Protesters in [[Sana'a]] on 4 April 2011, during the early stages of the [[Yemeni Revolution]].]] {{Main|Yemeni Revolution}} Popular protests broke out in early 2011, led by both secular and [[Islamism|Islamist]] opposition groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/middleeast/28yemen.html|agency=The New York Times|title=Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government|date=27 January 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> Longtime rebel groups like the [[Houthis]] and the [[Southern Movement]] also participated in the protests.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0211/As-Mubarak-resigns-Yemenis-call-for-a-revolution-of-their-own|agency=Christian Science Monitor|title=As Mubarak resigns, Yemenis call for a revolution of their own|date=11 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2012/02/27/yemens-houthi-movement-and-the-revolution/|agency=Foreign Policy|date=27 February 2012|accessdate=8 February 2015|title=Yemen’s Houthi movement and the revolution}}</ref> Saleh responded with a violent crackdown, and the country nearly disintegrated into an all-out civil war as several army elements broke with the government and joined the protesters, beginning in March.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011320180579476.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Top army commanders defect in Yemen|date=21 March 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/05/yemens-crackdown-on-protesters-escalates-to-air-strikes-risking-war/239054/|agency=The Atlantic|title=Yemen's Crackdown on Protesters Escalates to Air Strikes, Risking War|date=18 May 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
Saleh was almost killed when a bomb went off in a mosque where he and other top government officials were praying on 3 June, apparently in an assassination attempt.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/06/26/uk-yemen-president-idUKTRE75P0NO20110626|agency=Reuters|title=Yemen's Saleh injured by planted bomb – source|date=26 June 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-13892502|agency=BBC News|accessdate=8 February 2015|title=Yemen: President Saleh 'was injured by palace bomb'|date=23 June 2011}}</ref> While his condition initially appeared grave, Saleh recovered and returned to work on 23 September after several months of medical treatment in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/yemeni-president-ali-abdullah-saleh-returns-from-saudi-arabia/2011/09/23/gIQAdfrhpK_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh makes unexpected return from Saudi Arabia|date=24 September 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> He left Vice President Hadi in charge during his absence. As acting president, Hadi met with the opposition and reportedly expressed openness to political reforms. However, he rejected the idea of forcing Saleh from power without the president's consent.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/yemens-opposition-meets-with-acting-president/2011/06/13/AGrPblTH_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=Yemen’s opposition meets with acting president|date=13 June 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015|first=Sudarsan|last=Raghavan}}</ref>
====Deal brokered==== The [[Gulf Co-operation Council]] applied no small amount of pressure on Saleh to negotiate an end to the uprising by stepping down.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/middle-east/gcc-expects-end-to-yemen-crisis-as-pressure-builds-on-saleh-to-depart|agency=The National|title=GCC ‘expects end to Yemen crisis’ as pressure builds on Saleh to depart|first=Mohammed|last=Al Qadhi|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> Weeks after returning from Saudi Arabia, Saleh finally agreed on 23 November to resign in exchange for immunity. As part of the deal, the opposition agreed to allow Hadi to stand unopposed for the presidency in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/report-torture-excessive-force-used-in-bahrain-crackdown-but-no-iranian-links/2011/11/23/gIQAOOgtoN_story.html|agency=The Washington Post|title=Yemen president Saleh to step down; Bahrain acknowledges that crackdown used torture, excessive force|date=23 November 2011|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
====Siege of Dammaj==== {{Main|Siege of Dammaj}} Meanwhile, the [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|insurgent]] [[Houthis]] in northern Yemen laid siege to a [[Salafi]] town in [[Saada Governorate]], [[Dammaj]]. Fighting was worst in November and December. The Yemeni military was unable to restore order due to the crisis elsewhere in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/100214/yemen-shia-militia-sunni-madrassa |agency=The New Republic|title=A Militia, a Madrassa, and the Story Behind a Siege in Yemen|date=30 January 2012|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
===Transitional period (2012–14)=== The [[Yemeni Revolution]] came to an apparently successful conclusion in 2012 for the opposition, as Saleh left office. However, unrest continued in both northern and southern Yemen.
====Election of Hadi==== [[File:Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi 2013.jpg|upright|thumbnail|right|[[Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi]], the second [[President of Yemen]].]] {{Main|Yemeni presidential election, 2012}} Hadi's election on 24 February 2012 peacefully introduced a new government in Yemen, with only a small percentage of voters spoiling their ballots in the single-candidate contest.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/25/world/middleeast/yemen-to-get-a-new-president-abed-rabu-mansour-hadi.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Yemen Gets New Leader as Struggle Ends Calmly|accessdate=8 February 2015|date=24 February 2012}}</ref> Hadi, a southerner, especially enjoyed support in former South Yemen, quieting the murmurs of separatism,<ref name="dialogue">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/12/20/us-yemen-south-dialogue-idUSBRE8BJ0HT20121220|agency=Reuters|title=Some Yemeni separatists to join national dialogue|first=Mohammed|last=Mukhashaf|date=20 December 2012|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> although the [[Southern Movement]] boycotted the presidential election, as did the Houthis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1542/news/246/Houthis-and-Southern-Movement-to-boycott-February-election.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=Houthis and Southern Movement to boycott February election |date=30 January 2012|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> Hadi did not give the restive Houthis any seats in his cabinet.<ref name="crisis"/>
====Dammaj clashes continue==== The [[siege of Dammaj|conflict]] in Dammaj was renewed in April when fighting broke out between Houthi tribesmen and Salafi students. Both sides accused the other of breaking a truce agreement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1566/news/745/Houthi-Salafi-confrontations-renewed-in-Sa%E2%80%99ada.htm|agency=Yemen Times|title=Houthi-Salafi confrontations renewed in Sa'ada|date=22 April 2012|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
====Hadi makes inroads==== National reconciliation talks were held with the participation of many separatist elements, as well as the Houthis.<ref name="crisis"/><ref name="dialogue"/>
Nine years after the death of [[Hussein Badreddin al-Houthi]], the Yemeni government turned over the remains of the Houthi patriarch to his family and he was buried in northern Yemen in June 2013, with a representative of the Hadi administration in attendance.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/06/2013669532870100.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Houthi rebel leader laid to rest|date=6 June 2013|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
Hadi visited the [[United States]], a key overseas ally, in July 2013. The U.S. also lifted a ban on transferring detainees from its [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]] in [[Cuba]] to Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/25/obama-yemeni-president_n_3654380.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Obama To Host Yemeni President Abdo Rabby Mansour Hadi At White House|first=Jim|last=Kuhnhenn|date=25 July 2013|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
Meanwhile, [[Saudi Arabia]] deported as many as 300,000 to 400,000 Yemeni migrant workers to their home country during 2013, causing an influx of poor, landless Yemenis into northern Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/pomegranate/2013/12/deported-yemeni-migrant-workers|title=Down and out|date=10 December 2013|accessdate=8 February 2015|agency=The Economist}}</ref>
====Renewed clashes==== The conflict between Houthis and Salafis in [[Saada Governorate]] was renewed in October and November. Saada government officials accused Houthi fighters of attacking a Salafi mosque in [[Dammaj]] in an attempt to drive the [[Sunni Islam|Sunnis]] out, while the Houthis accused the Salafis of using the religious institute as a staging ground for foreign Sunni fighters. The government attempted to intervene to stop the fighting.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/11/03/world/meast/yemen-violence/|agency=CNN|title=Yemen: Sectarian fighting kills dozens|date=3 November 2013|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
Sectarian fighting in [[Al Jawf Governorate]] lasted throughout the year. [[Dhamar Governorate]] also saw clashes between the Houthis and Salafis toward the end of the year.<ref name="how">{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1813/report/4294/The-Houthis-From-a-local-group-to-a-national-power.htm|title=THE HOUTHIS: FROM A LOCAL GROUP TO A NATIONAL POWER|date=4 September 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015|agency=Yemen Times}}</ref>
===Houthi rebellion (2014–15)=== In a dramatic turn of events, the rebel Houthis took broad control of northern Yemen, including the capital of Sana'a itself, in 2014.
====Shia–Sunni conflict spreads==== {{Main|Battle of Amran}} Clashes in Dammaj spread to the [[Amran Governorate]] by January 2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2014/Jan-05/243146-clashes-kill-at-least-23-in-north-yemen.ashx#axzz2oNa3sbT8|agency=The Daily Star|title=Clashes kill at least 23 in north Yemen|date=5 January 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> The Houthis achieved victory in Saada when the Yemeni government brokered a deal under which Salafi fighters and their families were evacuated to the neighboring [[Al Hudaydah Governorate]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/837244.shtml#.UtU6aNJDvAk|title=Yemeni gov't evacuates Salafis from northern conflicts|date=13 January 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> According to reports, the Houthis then blocked government troops from fully deploying throughout the territory, in spite of a signed agreement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/salafis-forced-flee-dammaj-government-forces-unable-protect-them-they-say|agency=ReliefWeb|title=Salafis forced to flee Dammaj, government forces unable to protect them, they say|date=15 January 2014|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref>
Fighting in the Amran Governorate intensified during the year, with clashes between Houthis and supporters of the [[Islamism|Islamist]] [[Al-Islah (Yemen)|Islah Party]] eventually leading to a Houthi takeover of the entire governorate. The conflict spread to the [[Sana'a Governorate]] by July.<ref name="how"/>
====Houthis take Sana'a==== {{Main|Battle of Sana'a (2014)}} The [[Houthis]] began protesting against Hadi's government to demand concessions in order to resolve a years-long [[Houthi insurgency in Yemen|insurgency]] they had been waging against the Yemeni state in mid-2014.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yementimes.com/en/1813/news/4284/Houthis-block-roads-in-Sana%E2%80%99a.htm|title=Houthis block roads in Sana'a |date=4 September 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> The uprising escalated dramatically as Houthi fighters swept into [[Sana'a]], the capital, and effectively seized control of the city from the Yemeni military within a couple of days in September. The forces of General [[Ali Mohsen al-Ahmer]] surrendered to the Houthis after a brief fight.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/fr/in-depth/features/yemenis-are-shocked-houthi-s-quick-capture-sanaa-690971750|agency=Middle East Eye|title=Yemenis are shocked by Houthis' quick capture of Sana'a|accessdate=7 February 2015|date=September 2014|first=Saeed|last=Al-Batiti}}</ref> [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], the former president, was widely suspected of aiding the Houthis behind the scenes and helping pave the way for their takeover.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/26/world/middleeast/yemeni-parliament-cancels-meeting-on-presidents-resignation.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Shifting Alliances Play Out Behind Closed Doors in Yemen|date=25 January 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015|first=Mona|last=El-Naggar}}</ref> Prime Minister [[Mohammed Basindawa]] resigned on 21 September as part of a deal meant to end the standoff.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/09/21/Clashes-in-Yemeni-capital-cast-doubt-on-deal-signing.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Houthis sign deal with Sanaa to end Yemen crisis|date=21 September 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
====Unity government formed==== The Houthis and the government agreed on 21 September to form a "unity government" within one month.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/09/21/us-yemen-security-idUSKBN0HG04T20140921|agency=Reuters|title=Houthi rebels sign deal with Yemen parties to form new government|first=Mohammed|last=Ghobari|date=21 September 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> However, the Houthis rejected Hadi's original choice of prime minister, [[Ahmad Awad bin Mubarak]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29530635|agency=BBC News|title=Yemen's Houthi rebels reject Ahmed Awad bin Mubarak as PM|date=7 October 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> and Oil Minister [[Khaled Bahah]] was appointed instead with the armed group's approval.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/10/new-yemeni-prime-minister-appointed-20141013112111586298.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen appoints new PM to end crisis|date=13 October 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> The Houthis and the [[General People's Congress (Yemen)|General People's Congress]] led by Saleh announced abruptly on 8 November that they would not participate in the unity government, claiming it was unacceptable to them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2407344&Language=en|agency=KUNA|title=Yemen's GPC, Houthis oppose new gov't|date=11 October 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> The boycott prompted sanctions against Saleh and senior Houthi leaders from the [[United Nations Security Council]] and the [[United States Department of the Treasury]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/saleh-and-houthis-boycott-new-yemen-government-1190152028|agency=Middle East Eye|title=US blacklists Yemen ex-president Saleh, Houthi commanders|date=9 November 2014|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
===War in Yemen (2015–present)=== Yemen was riven in 2015, with the Houthis establishing a new government in Sana'a and Hadi retreating with his supporters to Aden, and later Saudi Arabia. The Arab League, led by the Saudis, began a bombing campaign and mobilization of various armed forces in the region for a possible invasion.
====Houthis consolidate power==== [[File:Houthi Declaration 6-2-2015.png|thumbnail|upright=1.03|A [[Houthis|Houthi]] official announces the dissolution of [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|House of Representatives]] and the formation of a Houthi-led transitional authority on 6 February 2015.]] {{Main|2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état}} The Houthis stepped up their pressure on Hadi's weakened government, seizing the presidential palace and strategic military installations in [[Sana'a]] and shelling the president's private residence on 20 January. The following day, they took control of Hadi's home, stationing armed guards outside to keep him under virtual house arrest.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/1/20/yemen-crisis-negotiations.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen rebels seize presidential palace|date=21 January 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> Hadi, Prime Minister [[Khaled Bahah]], and the cabinet resigned the following day, saying they could not continue to work under the conditions the Houthis had imposed. The rebel group welcomed Hadi's resignation, but continued to keep him under house arrest. The news prompted four southern governorates to announce they would disregard all orders from Sana'a.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/01/22/Yemen-government-offers-resignation.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Yemeni President Hadi resigns from office|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> The [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|House of Representatives]] was to meet on 25 January to discuss whether to accept or reject Hadi's resignation under the [[Constitution of Yemen|Yemeni constitution]], but the session was cancelled after the Houthis took control of the parliament building. The [[United Nations]] stepped in to attempt a negotiated resolution to what many in Yemen regarded as a Houthi coup.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/yemen-parliament-session-canceled-1422199790|agency=Wall Street Journal|title=Protests in Yemen Support President as Factions Negotiate His Future|date=25 January 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
UN negotiations were fruitless, and a Houthi ultimatum to Yemen's political factions to find a solution was not met. On 6 February, the Houthis declared themselves in total control of the Yemeni government, dissolving parliament and installing a [[Revolutionary Committee (Yemen)|Revolutionary Committee]] led by [[Mohammed Ali al-Houthi]] to lead the state in an interim capacity. The announcement sparked protests in Sana'a and other cities, especially in the south.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/world/yemen-s-shiite-rebels-say-they-re-in-charge-now-1.2224147|agency=CTV News|title=Yemen's Shiite rebels say they're in charge now|first=Ahmed|last=al-Haj|date=6 February 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/thousands-protest-houthi-coup-yemen-150207082035654.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Thousands protest against Houthi coup in Yemen|date=7 February 2015|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
====Post-coup developments==== {{Main|Aftermath of the 2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état}} Reactions to the Houthi takeover were broadly negative, with the [[Arab League]], [[Gulf Cooperation Council]], [[United Nations]], and [[United States]] refusing to recognise the "constitutional declaration" and several [[governorates of Yemen|governorates]] rejecting the Houthis' authority. With most political parties criticising the coup, [[Jamal Benomar]], the UN envoy to Yemen, announced a resumption of [[National Dialogue Conference|national talks]] over the future of Yemen on 8 February. Benomar said the Houthis had agreed to participate in the talks.<ref>{{cite news|first=Ahmed|last=al-Haj|agency=ABC News|date=8 February 2015|accessdate=8 February 2015|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/envoy-back-yemen-crisis-deepens-28809093|title=UN Envoy Says Yemen National Talks Will Resume Amid Crisis}}</ref> UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] called for Hadi to be reinstated as president.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/yemen/un-calls-for-yemen-president-hadi-s-reinstatement-1.1453472|agency=Gulfnews.com|title=UN calls for Yemen President Hadi’s reinstatement|date=8 February 2015|accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref>
The Houthis and other factions reached a tentative agreement, announced on 20 February, to keep the [[House of Representatives (Yemen)|House of Representatives]] in place despite the "constitutional declaration" dissolving it two weeks prior. The agreement also stipulated that a "people's transitional council" would be established to represent southerners, women, youth, and other political minorities.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/yemen-parties-agree-transitional-council-says-united-nations-envoy-1424424249|agency=The Wall Street Journal|date=20 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015|title=Yemen Parties Agree to Transitional Council, U.N. Envoy Says}}</ref> The next day, Hadi traveled to [[Aden]], where he said all Houthi-directed actions since 21 September 2014 were invalid, and condemned the coup d'état.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/02/yemen-leader-hadi-leaves-sanaa-weeks-house-arrest-150221090018174.html|agency=Al Jazeera|title=Yemen's Hadi says Houthis decisions unconstitutional|date=21 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/World/2015/02/22/Yemens-ousted-president-Hadi-calls-for-Houthis-to-quit-capital/|agency=The Star Online|title=Yemen's ousted president Hadi calls for Houthis to quit capital|date=22 February 2015|accessdate=21 February 2015}}</ref>
====Civil war erupts==== {{Main|Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)}} [[Battle of Aden (2015)|Fighting broke out]] over [[Aden International Airport]] on 19 March, with special forces loyal to ex-president [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]] attempting to seize the airport before they were defeated by troops and militiamen under orders from the Hadi administration.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/20/world/middleeast/yemen-aden-airport-battle.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Battle for Aden Airport Stokes Fears of Wider Conflict in Yemen|date=19 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref> The following day, in an apparently unrelated incident, four suicide bombers [[2015 Sana'a mosque bombings|detonated themselves in Sana'a mosques]] packed with Houthi congregants, killing at least 142. The [[Sunni Islam]]ist group [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant's]] [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant – Yemen Province|Yemen branch]] claimed responsibility.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.albawaba.com/news/two-mosques-yemen-attacked-suicide-bombers-during-friday-prayers-many-injured-671470|agency=Albawaba News|title=BREAKING: Death toll hits 137 from suicide bomb attacks in Yemen mosques|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/03/20/Yemen-mosque-attacks-kill-35-during-Friday-prayers.html|agency=Al Arabiya|title=Death toll in Yemen bombing rises to 142|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref>
Hadi declared Aden to be Yemen's temporary capital on 21 March while Sana'a remains under Houthi control.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/yemens-president-hadi-declares-new-temporary-capital/a-18332197|agency=Deutsche Welle|title=Yemen's President Hadi declares new 'temporary capital'|date=21 March 2015|accessdate=21 March 2015}}</ref> The next day, Houthi forces advanced toward Aden, capturing key parts of Yemen's third city of [[Taiz]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/23/world/middleeast/houthi-rebels-taiz-yemen.html?_r=0|agency=The New York Times|title=Rebels Seize Key Parts of Yemen’s Third-Largest City, Taiz|date=22 March 2015|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> They consolidated their grip on much of the south and [[Battle of Aden (2015)|seized much of Aden itself]] by early April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3771848/yemen-houthis-fighting-saudi-arabia-air-strikes/|agency=TIME|title=The Crisis in Yemen Intensifies as Houthi Fighters Push Deeper Into Aden|date=6 April 2015|accessdate=6 April 2015}}</ref>
=====Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen===== {{Main|Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen}} {{see also|Human rights violations during the Yemeni Civil War (2015–present)}} On 26 March, [[Saudi Arabia]] and several other countries announced that they had begun military operations in Yemen against Houthi rebels. [[Bahrain]], [[Kuwait]], [[Qatar]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] issued a statement along with Saudi Arabia saying their goal is to "repel Houthi aggression" in Yemen. [[Egypt]], [[Jordan]], [[Morocco]], and [[Sudan]] are also members of the coalition.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-32061632|title=Saudi Arabia launches military operation in Yemen - envoy|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
In addition to airstrikes against targets throughout Yemen, which the General People's Congress blamed for causing dozens of civilian casualties,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/26/middleeast/yemen-saudi-arabia-airstrikes/|agency=CNN|title=Saudi-led coalition strikes rebels in Yemen, inflaming tensions in region|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref> Egyptian warships reportedly shelled a Houthi column as it advanced toward Aden on 30 March,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/126506/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-warships-shell-Houthis-outside-Yemeni-cit.aspx|agency=Ahram Online|date=30 March 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015|title=Egyptian warships shell Houthis outside Yemeni city of Aden: Reports}}</ref> and Saudi and Houthi forces traded artillery and rocket fire across the border between Saudi Arabia and Yemen.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/yemen-crisis-saudi-arabia-forces-houthi-rebels-clash-border-yemen-calls-ground-troops-1865976|agency=International Business Times|title=Yemen Crisis: Saudi Arabia Forces, Houthi Rebels Clash On Border As Yemen Calls For Ground Troops|first=Kukil|last=Bora|date=1 April 2015|accessdate=1 April 2015}}</ref>
The 8 October 2016 attack by the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen|Saudi Arabian-led coalition]] killed at least 140 people and injured more than 600 in [[Sana'a]]. This was one of the single worst death tolls in the two-year war. Saudi Arabia and its allies accepted the internal review's finding, by the Joint Incidents Assessment Team (JIAT), that the coalition's bombardment of this funeral ceremony was based on faulty information, i.e., that this was a gathering of armed Houthi leaders.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-37613440 Yemen conflict: 'Saudi-led coalition plane' hit funeral (BBC)]</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/998181/middle-east |title=JIAT: Yemen funeral targeted based on wrong information; Coalition accepts findings |date=15 October 2016 |accessdate=16 October 2016 |publisher=Arab News}}</ref>
====Cholera epidemic====
A severe [[cholera]] epidemic has begun in Yemen during the civil war. In July 2017, the [[United Nations]] Humanitarian Relief coordinator said that over 320,000 cases had been reported.<ref name="Yemenis die" /> He also blamed the epidemic on the war and on international forces supporting the combatants.<ref name="Yemenis die"> {{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/yemen-united-nations-cholera-famine-war-houthi-rebels-saudi-arabia/ |title=U.N. warned "we should all feel deeply guilty" as Yemenis die |last=Falk |first=Pamela |date=13 July 2017 |website=[[CBS News]] |publisher=CBS News |language=English }} </ref> As of October 2017, it was described as already the worst cholera outbreak in recorded history, with over 800,000 cases.<ref> {{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2017/oct/12/yemen-cholera-outbreak-worst-in-history-1-million-cases-by-end-of-year|title=Yemen's cholera outbreak now the worst in history as millionth case looms|last=Lyons|first=Kate|date=2017-10-12|website=[[The Guardian]]|language=en|access-date=3 March 2018}}</ref>
